translated: And just as you say to the Naiyāyika that by perception only a particular effect pervaded by a person is established,

original: kiṃ tvavāntarameva ghaṭajātīyaṃ kāryamiti tathā nākāramātramabhyāsapūrvakaṃ sidhyati /
analyzed: kim tu avāntaram eva ghaṭa jātīyam kāryam iti tathā na ākāra mātram abhyāsa pūrvakam sidhyati
translated: but not just any effect belonging to the class of pots, so too it is not established that mere form is preceded by practice,

analyzed: kim tu avāntaram eva yuvatī ākāra sāmānyam iti vyaktam eva
translated: but only a particular universal form of the young woman. This is quite clear.

analyzed: na ca abhyāsa kāryaḥ sphuṭībhāvaḥ
translated: And vividness is not the effect of practice,

analyzed: tad abhāve pi svapne darśanāt
translated: because it is seen even in the absence of that, in dreams.

original: kiṃ ca sarvavido 'pi yadi caturāryasatyaparijñānataḥ sarvajñatāsthitiḥ /
analyzed: kim ca yadi catur ārya satya parijñānataḥ sarvajña tā sthitiḥ
translated: Moreover, if omniscience is established by the complete knowledge of the four noble truths,

original: tarhi ghaṭādikatipayavastujñāne 'pi sarvajñateti sādhvī śuddhiḥ / api ca
analyzed: tarhi ghaṭa ādi katipaya vastu jñāne sarvajña tā iti sādhvī śuddhiḥ api ca
translated: then omniscience would follow even from the knowledge of a few things like pots. This is a good purification. And further,

analyzed: jñānavān mṛgyate kaścid tad ukta pratipattaye
translated: Someone who knows is sought after for understanding what he says,

analyzed: ajña upadeśa karaṇe vipralambhana śaṅkibhiḥ
translated: by those who suspect deception in the teaching of an ignorant person.

analyzed: iti yuṣmābhiḥ eva ucyate
translated: This is what you yourself say.

analyzed: na ca sarva jñānavān viśeṣa niṣṭha tayā adhigantum śakyate
translated: And one who possesses all knowledge cannot be known by being limited to a particular [object].

analyzed: na ca asya sattā mātra siddhau kaścid upayogaḥ
translated: And there is no use in merely establishing its existence.

analyzed: pravṛtteḥ anaṅga tvāt iti sarvam asamañjasam
translated: Because engagement is not a part [of the means of valid knowledge], all this is incoherent.

analyzed: atrā ucyate na vayam sākṣāt sarvajña sattā pratijñāyām hetu vyāpāram anumanyāmahe
translated: To this we reply: We do not agree that the function of a reason is in the proposition that the existence of an omniscient being is directly perceived,
like the existence of fire which depends on the existence of a mountain.

original: kintu caturāryasatyākārasvarūpe dharmiṇi sphuṭābhatvasya sādhyasyāyogavyavacchedārthaṃ parvate 'gnimātrāyogavyavacchedavat /
analyzed: kintu catur ārya satya ākāra svarūpe dharmiṇi sphuṭa ābha tvasya sādhyasya ayoga vyavaccheda artham parvate gni mātra ayoga vyavaccheda vat
translated: But in order to exclude the impossibility of the probandum, namely, the state of being clearly perceived, in the case of the property-possessor which is the nature of the four noble truths, like the exclusion of the impossibility of mere fire on a mountain,

analyzed: sphuṭa ābha tvam tu kāminī ākāra ādi dṛṣṭānte dṛṣṭam eva
translated: the state of being clearly perceived is indeed seen in the example of the form of a beloved woman, etc.

analyzed: tat ca parvatīya agni vat
translated: And that is like the fire on a mountain.

analyzed: pakṣa dharmatā balataḥ satya catuṣṭaya adhikaraṇam sidhyat sarvajña tām ācakṣmahe
translated: By the power of the property of the subject, we call the establishment of the basis of the four noble truths omniscience.

analyzed: yathā uktam  iti abhyāsa balāt parisphuṭa daśā koṭiḥ sphurat saṃbhavī
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: heya ādeya tad aṅga lakṣaṇa guṇaḥ sarvajña tā sā eva naḥ iti
translated: Thus, by the power of practice, the state of being clearly perceived, which is the peak of the stage, is manifest. The quality of the object to be abandoned, the object to be accepted, and its auxiliaries, that very omniscience is ours.

original: tadatrābhyāsasahitacaturāryasatyākāraḥ samagro dharmī sāmagryamabhyāsaviśiṣṭacetoguṇatvamātraṃ hetuḥ sphuṭībhāvayogyatāsādhyam /
analyzed: tat atra abhyāsa sahita catur ārya satya ākāraḥ samagraḥ dharmī sāmagryam abhyāsa viśiṣṭa cetaḥ guṇa tva mātram hetuḥ sphuṭībhāva yogyatā sādhyam
translated: Here, the subject is the complete four noble truths along with practice, and the mere quality of the mind distinguished by practice is the reason, to be accomplished by the fitness for clear manifestation.

analyzed: yathā sa agni tva anagni tva sandehe
translated: Just as in the doubt about whether it has fire or not,
the subject is the mountain, cognized by valid cognition.

analyzed: tathā atra api sarvajña tva asarvajña tva vivāde hi pratyātma viditaḥ satya catuṣṭaya ākāraḥ dharmī
translated: Similarly, here too, in the dispute about omniscience or non-omniscience, the subject is the four noble truths cognized by oneself.

original: tasmāt sphuṭābhatvena sādhyena dṛṣṭānte vyāptisiddherastyeva tatpratibaddhaliṅganiścayaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt sphuṭa ābha tvena sādhyena dṛṣṭānte vyāpti siddheḥ asti eva tad pratibaddha liṅga niścayaḥ
translated: Therefore, since the pervasion is established in the example by the probandum clear manifestation, the ascertainment of the inferential mark that is dependent on that does indeed exist.

analyzed: sādhya sandehe pi dharmiṇaḥ catur ārya satya ākārasya siddheḥ na trividha doṣa jāteḥ avasaraḥ
translated: Even when there is doubt about the probandum, since the subject, which is the four noble truths, is established, there is no opportunity for the three kinds of faults.

analyzed: yogyatāyāḥ prasādhanena ca kāraṇāt kārya pratītau anaikāntika tvam iti api anabhyupagama pratihatam
translated: And the argument that it is inconclusive because the cognition of the effect is from the establishment of fitness is also countered by the non-acceptance.

original: yogyatā ca sāntaraiva sādhyate /🔽iyaṃ ca na gamayatu nāmaikāntataḥ kāryasattvam /
analyzed: yogyatā ca sa antarā eva sādhyate  iyam ca na gamayatu nāma ekāntataḥ kārya sattvam
translated: And fitness is established as having an interval.🔽And let this not convey the existence of the effect in one way or the other.

analyzed: an upapadyamānam punar asya saṃbhavam ākṣipati eva
translated: But it does raise the question of the possibility of its non-occurrence.

original: tadā bhāvini kārye sandehe 'pi kāraṇayogyatā niścīyata eva /
analyzed: tadā bhāvini kārye sandehe pi kāraṇa yogya tā niścīyate eva
translated: Then, even in the case of a future effect, when there is doubt, the fitness of the cause is certainly ascertained.

analyzed: brīhi ādau bhāvi phala aniścaye pi yogyatā niścayena pravṛtteḥ
translated: Because even when there is no certainty about the future result in rice etc., one engages in activity due to the certainty of fitness.

analyzed: anyathā śilā śakala ādeḥ api upādāna prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, even a piece of stone would have to be accepted as a cause.

analyzed: tad jātīyasya śarāva stha paṅka uptasya sāmarthyam upalabdham iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the capacity of that kind, when in the form of a pot, is observed,

original: atrāpi kāminyākāre bhāvanājātīyasya sphuṭībhāvakaraṇayogyatā dṛṣṭeti samānam /
analyzed: atrā api kāminī ākāre bhāvanā jātīyasya sphuṭībhāva karaṇa yogya tā dṛṣṭā iti samānam
translated: then it is the same here also, as the capacity to bring about manifestation is seen in the form of the beloved woman, which belongs to the class of impressions.

analyzed: evam yogya tā mātra sādhanena eva kṛtārthaḥ sādhana vādī
translated: Thus, the proponent of the proof has accomplished his purpose merely by establishing fitness.

analyzed: sarvajña kāraṇa bhāvāt tad abhāva vādinām nirdalanāt  kāryasya traikālikasya sambhāvanā prasādhanāt
translated: Because those who deny the existence of an omniscient cause are refuted.🔽Because the possibility of an effect at all times is established.

analyzed: muttkī arthinām ca pravṛtteḥ avirodhāt
translated: And because engagement of those who desire the result is not contradicted.

analyzed: vādinaḥ pi tad mātra sādhanasya abhipreta tvāt
translated: Because the proponent also intends to prove merely that.

analyzed: ataeva kaḥ prastāvaḥ sarvajña sattā vivāde sphuṭībhāva sādhanasya ityādi api anavakāśam
translated: For this very reason, the statement What occasion is there for proving manifestation in the debate on the existence of an omniscient being? is also irrelevant.
Because by the word omniscient, fitness for manifestation is intended.

analyzed: tathā kārya kāraṇa pratītiḥ api saṃbhavati eva
translated: Similarly, the cognition of cause and effect is also possible.

original: tathā hi kāminyabhyāsasantatisahacāri saṃbhramakāyavacodarśanameva kāminyākārasya tadbhāvanāyāśca darśanam /
analyzed: tathā hi kāminī abhyāsa santati sahacāri saṃbhrama kāya vacaḥ darśanam eva kāminī ākārasya tad bhāvanāyāḥ ca darśanam
translated: For example, the appearance of the body and speech of a passionate woman, which accompanies the continuum of practice with a passionate woman, is the appearance of the form of that passionate woman and the cultivation of that.

analyzed: tathābhūta kāya vacaḥ darśanam eva bhāvanāyāḥ adarśanam
translated: The non-appearance of such a body and speech is the non-appearance of the cultivation.

analyzed: evam sphuṭa pratibhāsa santati sahacāri viśiṣṭa kāya vacaḥ darśanam sphuṭa pratibhāsa darśanam
translated: Similarly, the appearance of a body and speech that accompanies a continuum of clear appearances is the appearance of a clear appearance.

analyzed: tathā avasthita kāya vacaḥ darśanam eva sphuṭa pratibhāsa adarśanam iti asti eva prastute pi pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva pratītiḥ
translated: The non-appearance of a body and speech in that state is the non-appearance of a clear appearance. Thus, even in the present case, the cognition of the relation of cause and effect through perception and non-perception exists.

analyzed: iyam ca tathā avastha kāma ātura śarīra vacana grahaṇe tad eka deśa bhūta yuvati ākāra abhyāsa sphuṭa pratibhāsa grahaṇa vyavasthā vyāvahārikeṇa avaśyam svīkartavyā
translated: And this arrangement of grasping the body and speech of a passionate person in that state, and grasping the form of a young woman who is a part of that, and the clear appearance of the practice, must necessarily be accepted by the conventional.

analyzed: anyathā citya caitya rūpa rasa gandha sparśa paramāṇu puñja ādi ātmakasya kumbhakāra ghaṭa pradeśa ādeḥ api
translated: Otherwise, even the part of a potter's pot, which consists of the mass of atoms of form, taste, smell, and touch,

analyzed: rūpa eka deśa grāhakam cakṣuḥ pratyakṣam na samudāya vyavasthāpakam iti sarva vyāvahārika pramāṇa uccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And visual perception, which apprehends only a part of the form, does not establish the whole, so there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all worldly valid cognition.

original: tathā bāhyaghaṭakāminyādīnāṃ śaktikṛtasya mahato jātibhedasya saṃbhavādanyajātīyavyāptigrahe 'nyajātīyād buddhimadanumānamayuktam /
analyzed: tathā bāhya ghaṭa kāminī ādīnām śakti kṛtasya mahataḥ jāti bhedasya saṃbhavāt anya jātīya vyāpti grahe buddhimat anumānam ayuktam
translated: Similarly, since there is a great diversity of species created by the power of external potters, lovers, etc., it is not proper to infer an intelligent being from something of a different species when grasping the pervasion of something of a different species.

original: saṃkalpārūḍhānāṃ tu jalajvalanayuvatyākārādīnāṃ bāhyatvenādhyastānāmapi vijñānaikasvarūpatayaikajātīyatvamastīti bhāvanāsahitākāramātreṇaiva 🔽vaiśadyavyāptirastu //
analyzed: saṃkalpa ārūḍhānām tu jala jvalana yuvati ākāra ādīnām bāhya tvena adhyastānām api vijñāna eka svarūpa tayā eka jātīya tvam asti iti bhāvanā sahita ākāra mātreṇa eva  vaiśadya vyāptiḥ astu
translated: But for forms such as water, fire, and young women that are superimposed as external but have the same nature as consciousness, there is the same species, so let there be the pervasion of clarity only through the form accompanied by meditation.

analyzed: na ca svapne sphuṭa tā avyabhicāraḥ
translated: And there is no inconstancy of clarity in dreams.

analyzed: bhāvanā siddha lakṣaṇayoḥ hetvoḥ jāti bhede tad kāryayoḥ ekatva abhimāne pi jāti bhedasya avaśyam svīkartavya tvāt
translated: Even if there is the notion of oneness between the effects of the two causes that are established by meditation, which are of different species, the difference of species must necessarily be accepted.

original: dṛśyate hi siddhasādhyā vaiśadyajātiranapekṣya viparītabhāvanāṃ nidrāvicchede vicchidyamānā /
analyzed: dṛśyate hi siddha sādhyā vaiśadya jātiḥ an apekṣya viparīta bhāvanām nidrā vicchede vicchidyamānā
translated: For the species of clarity, which is established by meditation, is seen to cease upon the cessation of sleep without depending on the opposite meditation.

original: bhāvanābhāvinī tu na vinā vipakṣābhyāsaṃ jāgrato 'pi yadāhuḥ
analyzed: bhāvanā bhāvinī tu na vinā vipakṣa abhyāsam yat āhuḥ
translated: But that which arises from meditation does not occur even when awake without practice of the opposite, as they say:

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: svapne sphuṭatā tathā eva na tathā api ekatvam eva anayoḥ
translated: Even in a dream, the clarity is the same, yet they are not the same.

analyzed: prākāra sama tvam eva sama tām jāteḥ samām aṃgati
translated: The equality of the genus is understood to be the equality of the same form.

analyzed: anyannidha nirodha bādhyam itarat bādhyam prayatnaiḥ punar
translated: One is to be refuted by cessation, the other is to be refuted by efforts again.

original: vaiśadyaṃ viparītabhāvanabalān nairghṛṇyabhede yathā // iti //🔽yadapi ghaṭādikatipayajñāne 'pi sarvajñaḥ syādityuktam / tatrāpi🔽ghaṭādiprakṛtāśeṣavedane 'pi bhayaṃ bhavād
analyzed: vaiśadyam viparīta bhāvana balāt nairghṛṇya bhede yathā iti  yat api ghaṭa ādi katipaya jñāne sarvajñaḥ syāt iti uktam tatra api  ghaṭa ādi prakṛta aśeṣa vedane pi bhayam bhavāt
translated: The clarity is by the power of the meditation on the opposite, as in the case of the distinction of cruelty.🔽And what is said that one would be omniscient even in the knowledge of a few things like a pot, even there,🔽If one would have fear from existence even in the knowledge of all things like a pot,

original: dhīyet yadi ko doṣaḥ so 'pi sarvajñatāṃ vrajet /
analyzed: dhīyet yadi kaḥ doṣaḥ saḥ u pi sarvajña tām vrajet
translated: then what is the fault? He too would attain omniscience.

analyzed: saṃsāra duḥkha mokṣāya spṛhayantaḥ vayam punar
translated: But we, desiring liberation from the suffering of worldly existence,

analyzed: bhajema tad upāya jñam sthātum tad gītavartmani
translated: would again worship him who knows the means to that, to remain on the path sung by him.

analyzed: iti uttaram draṣṭavyam
translated: This is the reply to be seen.

original: tathā sattāmātre vipratipannān prati sattaiva kevalā prasādhitā /
analyzed: tathā sattā mātre vipratipannān prati sattā eva kevalā prasādhitā
translated: Thus, for those who are opposed to mere existence, only existence is established.

original: viśeṣajijñāsāyāṃ tu pramāṇopapannakṣaṇikanairātmyavādina eva sugatasya bhagavataḥ sarvajñatā /
analyzed: viśeṣa jijñāsāyām tu pramāṇa upapanna kṣaṇika nairātmya vādinaḥ eva sugatasya bhagavataḥ sarvajña tā
translated: But in the inquiry into distinctions, the omniscience of the Blessed One, the Sugata, who teaches the doctrine of momentary selflessness, is established by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: atas etat api nirastam yat āha bhaṭṭaḥ
translated: For this reason, this is also refuted, which is said by Bhatta:

original: sugato yadi sarvajñaḥ kapilo neti kā pramā /
analyzed: sugataḥ yadi sarvajñaḥ kapilaḥ na iti kā pramā
translated: If the Sugata (Buddha) is omniscient, what is the proof that Kapila is not so?

original: athobhāvapi sarvajñau matabhedaḥ kathaṃ tayoḥ // iti //
analyzed: atha ubhau api sarvajñau mata bhedaḥ katham tayoḥ iti
translated: If both are omniscient, how is there a difference of opinion between them?

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Therefore,

original: uktakrameṇa munirājanaye pramāyāḥ śaktirvyanakti gatimapramitāṃ kṛpāṃ ca /
analyzed: ukta krameṇa muniḥ ājanaye pramāyāḥ śaktiḥ vyanakti gatim apramitām kṛpām ca
translated: In the said manner, the power of the Muni's (Buddha's) knowledge manifests itself in an immeasurable way, and his compassion.

original: anyatra tu dvayamudastamado 'stamāne tenaika eva śaraṇaṃ sa nirātmavādī //
analyzed: anyatra tu dvayam udastam adaḥ stamāne tena ekaḥ eva śaraṇam sa nirātma vādī
translated: But in others, both are set aside, and the darkness (of ignorance) is dispelled. Therefore, he alone is the refuge, the one who teaches non-self.

original: iti viśeṣasiddhirapyanavadyeti sarvamanākulamākulādhayaḥ pare na pratipadyante /
analyzed: iti viśeṣa siddhiḥ api anavadyā iti sarvam an ākulam ākula ādhayaḥ pare na pratipadyante
translated: Thus, even the establishment of distinction is faultless. But the others, whose minds are disturbed, do not understand all this without confusion.

analyzed: sādhane smin avadye durnīti dahana dagdha buddhayaḥ punar api etat ācakṣate
translated: Even in this faultless proof, those whose minds are burned by the fire of bad policy say this again:

original: bādhakapramāṇasadbhāvāt sarvajñasyāsadvyavahāro yuktaḥ sadvyavahārapratiṣedho vā prasādhakapramāṇābhāvādveti //
analyzed: bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāvāt sarvajñasya asat vyavahāraḥ yuktaḥ sat vyavahāra pratiṣedhaḥ vā prasādhaka pramāṇa abhāvāt vā iti
translated: Because there is an opposing valid cognition, it is proper to treat the omniscient one as non-existent or to negate the notion of his existence, because there is no proof.

original: atra vicāryate kiṃ punarasya bhagavato bādhakaṃ pramāṇaṃ pratyakṣamanumānaṃ śabdādikaṃ veti vikalpāḥ //
analyzed: atra vicāryate kim punar asya bhagavataḥ bādhakam pramāṇam pratyakṣam anumānam śabda ādikam vā iti vikalpāḥ
translated: Here it is considered: What, then, is this opposing valid cognition of the Blessed One - perception, inference, verbal testimony, etc.? These are the alternatives.

analyzed: na tāvat pratyakṣam
translated: First of all, it is not perception.

original: pratyakṣaṃ hi kevalapradeśādau pravartamānaṃ svapravṛttiyogyameva tatra vastu pratiṣedhati /
analyzed: pratyakṣam hi kevala pradeśa ādau pravartamānam sva pravṛtti yogyam eva tatra vastu pratiṣedhati
translated: For perception, when operating on a mere place, etc., only denies the existence of an object there that is suitable for its own operation.

analyzed: na vastu mātram
translated: Not just any object.

analyzed: na ca sarvajñasya pratyakṣa pravṛtti yogyatā asti
translated: And there is no suitability for the perception of an omniscient being to operate.

analyzed: svabhāva viprakṛṣṭa tvāt tasya
translated: Because that is distant from its nature.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bond

original: syādetat / na vayaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pravartamānamabhāvaṃ sādhayatīti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: syāt etat na vayam pratyakṣam pravartamānam abhāvam sādhayati iti brūmaḥ
translated: This may be said: We do not say that perception, when operating, establishes non-existence.

analyzed: kim tarhi
translated: What then?

analyzed: nivartamānam
translated: When it turns away.

original: tathā hi yatra vastuni pratyakṣasya nivṛttistasyāsadbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi yatra vastuni pratyakṣasya nivṛttiḥ tasya asadbhāvaḥ
translated: For thus, where there is the cessation of perception regarding an object, that is non-existence.

analyzed: yathā śaśaviṣāṇa ādeḥ
translated: Like the horn of a rabbit, etc.

original: yatra tu pratyakṣasya pravṝttistasya sadbhāvo yathā ghaṭādeḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu pratyakṣasya pravṝttiḥ tasya sadbhāvaḥ yathā ghaṭa ādeḥ
translated: But where there is the operation of perception, that is existence, like a pot, etc.

analyzed: asti ca sarvajñe pratyakṣa nivṛttiḥ
translated: And there is the cessation of perception regarding an omniscient being.

analyzed: tat asya api abhāvaḥ kena nivāryate iti
translated: By what is his non-existence prevented?

original: ucyate / nivartamānaṃ pratyakṣamabhāvaṃ sādhayatīti ko 'rthaḥ /🔽kiṃ pratyakṣasya yā nivṛttistato 'bhāvasiddhiḥ /🔽nivṛttisahitādvā pratyakṣāt /
analyzed: ucyate nivartamānam pratyakṣam abhāvam sādhayati iti kaḥ rthaḥ  kim pratyakṣasya yā nivṛttiḥ tatas bhāva siddhiḥ  nivṛtti sahitāt vā pratyakṣāt
translated: It is said: What is the meaning of perception, when turning away, establishes non-existence?🔽Is the establishment of non-existence from the cessation of perception?🔽Or from perception accompanied by cessation?

analyzed: nivṛttāt vā pratyakṣāt iti
translated: Or from ceased perception?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The first position is not so.

analyzed: sati api vastuni pratyakṣa nivṛtteḥ upalabhyamānāyāḥ vastu abhāva niya ta tva asiddheḥ
translated: Even if the object exists, the non-existence of the object is not established because of the impossibility of the perception of the absence of perception.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor is the second.

analyzed: sva abhāvena saha kasyacid sāhitya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the co-existence of anything with its own nature is not possible.

analyzed: anyathā tad nivṛtta tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, its cessation would not be possible.

analyzed: na ca tṛtīyaḥ
translated: And not the third.

original: tathā hi nivṛttāt pratyakṣādabhāvasiddhirityasataḥ pratyakṣādityuktaṃ bhavati /

translated: Nor is the cultivation [of the idea of the specific characteristic] the object of that [scripture and inference].

original: tadagrāhyamapi svalakṣaṇaṃ tadadhyavaseyatayā tadviṣaya iti tadyonirapi bhāvanā tadviṣayeti tatprakarṣastadvaiśadyaheturiti cet / na /
analyzed: tat agrāhyam api sva lakṣaṇam tad adhyavaseya tayā tad viṣayaḥ iti tad yoniḥ api bhāvanā tad viṣayā iti tad prakarṣaḥ tad vaiśadya hetuḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that although the specific characteristic is not the object of that [scripture and inference], it is the object of that [cultivation] because it is to be ascertained by that [scripture and inference], and therefore the cultivation [of the idea of the specific characteristic] is also the object of that [scripture and inference], and therefore the intensity of that [cultivation] is the cause of the clarity of that [specific characteristic], [we say] no.

analyzed: tad adhyavaseyasya api paramārtha sattva abhāvāt
translated: Because that which is to be ascertained by that [scripture and inference] also does not ultimately exist.

original: tathā hi yadanumānena gṛhyate yaccādhyavasīyate te dve apyanyanivṛttī / na vastunī /
analyzed: tathā hi yat anumānena gṛhyate yat ca adhyavasīyate te dve api anya nivṛttī na vastunī
translated: For what is grasped by inference and what is ascertained, both of those are exclusions of other, not real things.

analyzed: sva lakṣaṇa avagāhi tve bhilāpa saṃsarga yogya pratibhāsa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because if it were to penetrate the particular characteristic, the appearance suitable for connection with verbal expression would be impossible.

analyzed: mā bhūt tayoḥ sva lakṣaṇam viṣayaḥ  tad prabhava bhāvanā prakarṣa paryanta janmanaḥ tu
translated: Let the particular characteristic not be the object of those two.

analyzed: nibandh viśada ābhasya cetasaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But it will be the cause of the clear appearance of the mind born at the end of the culmination of the meditation that arises from that.

analyzed: kāminī vikalpa prabhava bhāvanā prakarṣāt iva kāma āturasya kāminī sva lakṣaṇa sākṣātkāraḥ
translated: Just as the perception of the particular characteristic of a beloved woman occurs to one who is passionate due to the culmination of meditation arising from the imagination of a beloved woman.

original: karikumbhakaṭhorakucakalaśahāriṇi hariṇaśāvalolalocane campakadalāvadātagātralate lāvaṇyasarasi nirantaralagnalalitadoḥkandalīmūla māliṅganamaṅgane
analyzed: kari kumbha kaṭhora kuca kalaśa hāriṇi hariṇa śāva lola locane campaka dala avadāta gātra late lāvaṇya sarasi nirantara lagna lalita dos kandalī mūla āliṅganam aṅgane  /
translated: O beloved, take me in your arms, O lady with breasts that steal the hearts of elephants, with eyes darting like a fawn, with limbs as fair as champaka flowers, in the lake of beauty, with the roots of your charming arms constantly attached.

analyzed: preyasitare prayaccha
translated: O beloved, give to the other one.

analyzed: sañjīvaya jīvita īśvari  smi tava caraṇa nalinayoḥ iti vacana kāya ceṣṭayoḥ upalabdheḥ
translated: Revive, O mistress of life.🔽Thus, the utterance and bodily movements are perceived.

original: asti ca vikalpāvikalpayoḥ kathañcit samānaviṣayateti nātiprasaṅga iti cet /
analyzed: asti ca vikalpa avikalpayoḥ kathañcid samāna viṣaya tā iti na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is some similarity of object between conceptual and non-conceptual cognitions, so there is no over-extension,

analyzed: satyam
translated: it is true.

analyzed: saṃbhavati ayam anubhavaḥ na punar asya arthe prāmāṇya saṃbhavaḥ
translated: This experience is possible, but the possibility of validity in its object does not exist.

analyzed: a tad utpatteḥ a tad ātmanaḥ tad avyabhicāra niyama ayogāt
translated: Because it is not produced from that, because it is not of the nature of that, and because it is not possible to have an invariable concomitance with that.

analyzed: a tādātmyam ca arthasya vijñānāt atirekāt
translated: And the non-identity of the object with consciousness is due to its being separate from consciousness.

analyzed: an atireke ca vijñānānām anyonyasya bhedāt a tādātmyāt
translated: And even if there is no separation, due to the difference between one consciousness and another, there is non-identity.

analyzed: ekasya vijñānasya itara vijñāna vedanā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because one consciousness cannot experience another consciousness.

original: vijñānasvalakṣaṇaikatvābhyupagame ca tannityamekamadvitīyaṃ brahmābhyasanīyamiti kṣaṇikanairātmyābhyāsābhyupagamo dattajalāñjaliḥ prasajyeta
analyzed: vijñāna sva lakṣaṇa ekatva abhyupagame ca tat nityam ekam advitīyam brahma abhyasanīyam iti kṣaṇika nairātmya abhyāsa abhyupagamaḥ datta jalāñjaliḥ prasajyeta
translated: And if the identity of the individual characteristic of consciousness is accepted, then it would follow that Brahman, which is eternal, one, without a second, should be meditated upon. Thus the acceptance of the practice of momentariness and selflessness would be like offering water libations.

analyzed: tat na tādātmyāt tasya avyabhicāraḥ
translated: Therefore, its invariable concomitance is not due to identity with that.

analyzed: na api tad kārya tvāt
translated: Nor is it due to being its effect.

analyzed: bhāvanā prakarṣa kāryam khalu etat na viṣaya kāryam
translated: For this is the effect of the culmination of meditation, not the effect of the object.

analyzed: yadi ucyeta pāramparyeṇa tat kāryam anumāna vat
translated: If it is said that it is indirectly its effect, like inference,

original: yathā hi vahnisvalakṣaṇāddhūmasvalakṣaṇam /🔽tato dhūmānubhavastato dahana vikalpaḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi vahni sva lakṣaṇāt dhūma sva lakṣaṇam  tatas dhūma anubhavaḥ tatas dahana vikalpaḥ
translated: just as the individual characteristic of smoke is from the individual characteristic of fire,🔽then from that there is the experience of smoke, then the conception of fire,

original: tataścānumānamutpannamiti pāramparyeṇa vahnipratibandhāt prāpakaṃ ca vahnerdāhapākakāriṇaḥ
analyzed: tatas ca anumānam utpannam iti pāramparyeṇa vahni pratibandhāt prāpakam ca vahneḥ dāha pāka kāriṇaḥ
translated: and then the inference arises. Thus, because it is indirectly connected with fire, it is the means of knowing the burning and cooking fire.

analyzed: tathā idam api anumāna janita bhāvanā prakarṣa paryanta jam pāramparyeṇa artha prasūta tayā
translated: And this also, born from the culmination of meditation produced by inference, is indirectly produced by the object.

analyzed: tad avyabhicāra niyamāt tatra pramāṇam iti
translated: And this also, arising from the culmination of meditation produced by inference, is a means of valid knowledge there, because it is indirectly produced by the object,🔽and because of the invariable rule of non-deviation.

original: tat kimanumānena vahniṃ vyavasthāpya bhāvayato yadvahniviṣayamativiśadavijñānaṃ tatpramāṇamiti /
analyzed: tat kim anumānena vahnim vyavasthāpya bhāvayataḥ yat vahni viṣayam ati viśada vijñānam tat pramāṇam iti
translated: Is it that when one, having established fire by inference, meditates on it, the very clear cognition of fire is a means of valid knowledge?

original: omiti brubāṇasya parvatanitambārohaṇe satīndriyasannikarṣajanmano dahanavijñānasya bhāvanādhipatya viśadābhavijñānena saha saṃvādaniyamaprasaṅgaḥ
analyzed: om iti brubāṇasya parvata nitamba ārohaṇe sati indriya sannikarṣa janmanaḥ dahana vijñānasya bhāvanā ādhipatya viśada ābha vijñānena saha saṃvāda niyama prasaṅgaḥ
translated: When one says Om and ascends the mountain slope, the cognition of fire produced by sense-object contact is invariably in agreement with the clear cognition due to the influence of meditation.

analyzed: visaṃvādaḥ ca bahulam upalabhyate
translated: And disagreement is often observed.

original: lakṣaṇayogini ca vyabhicārasaṃbhave tallakṣaṇameva bādhitamiti viśadābhamapi prātibhamiva saṃśayākrāntamapramāṇam /
analyzed: lakṣaṇa yogini ca vyabhicāra saṃbhave tad lakṣaṇam eva bādhitam iti viśada ābham api prātibham iva saṃśaya ākrāntam apramāṇam
translated: And when there is possibility of deviation in what possesses the characteristic, that characteristic itself is contradicted. Therefore, even the clear cognition, like the cognition produced by imagination, is subject to doubt and is not a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tad bhāvanāyāḥ bhūta artha tvam na tad ja viśada ābha vijñāna prāmāṇya hetuḥ
translated: The reality of that meditation is not the cause of the validity of the clear cognition produced by it.

analyzed: vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of deviation.

analyzed: evam ca prāsarpakasya iva saktu karkarī prāpti mūla lābha manoratha paramparā hitaḥ dva viṇa saṃbhāra sākṣātkāraḥ tathāgatasya nirātmaka samasta vastu sākṣātkāra
translated: And thus, just as for one who is crawling, the attainment of a handful of molasses is accompanied by a series of wishes for the acquisition of the means, in the same way, for the Tathāgata, the direct realization of the accumulation of wealth is accompanied by the direct realization of all things as devoid of self.

analyzed: iti āpatitam
translated: This is what follows.

analyzed: sarva artha vastu bhāvanā parikarmita citta santāna varti vijñānam pratyālambana pratyaya tvam artha mātrasya
translated: The mere object is the objective condition for the consciousness that exists in the mind-stream purified by the cultivation of all meaningful things.

original: tathā ca tadutpatteḥ tadavyabhicāraniyama iti cet / na /
analyzed: tathā ca tad utpatteḥ tad avyabhicāra niyamaḥ iti ced na
translated: And thus, because it arises from that, there is the rule of invariable concomitance with that. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: arthasya hi ālambana pratyaya tva vijñānam prati indriya apekṣa tvena vyāptam
translated: For the consciousness of an object as the objective condition for consciousness is pervaded by dependence on a sense faculty.

analyzed: tat ca asmāt sva viruddha upalabdhyā
translated: And that, being excluded by the perception of its opposite,
also excludes the object's status as the objective condition.

original: na khalvindhanaviśeṣo dhūmaheturiti vināpi dahanaṃ sahasreṇāpi saṃskārairdhūbhamādhate /
analyzed: na khalu indhana viśeṣaḥ dhūma hetuḥ iti vinā api dahanam sahasreṇa api saṃskāraiḥ dhūbham ādhate
translated: For a particular fuel is not the cause of smoke. Even without burning, it does not produce smoke even with a thousand modifications.

analyzed: tad ādhāne vā samasta kārya hetu anumāna uccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Or if it does produce it, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of inference based on cause and effect.

original: bhāvanāyāśca bhūtārthāyā arthānapekṣāyā eva viśadavijñānajananasāmarthyamupalabdha🔽kāmāturādivartinyā iti bhūtārthāpi tannirapekṣaiva samartheti nārthasyālambanapratyayatvaṃ śakyāvagamam /
analyzed: bhāvanāyāḥ ca bhūta arthāyāḥ artha anapekṣāyāḥ eva viśada vijñāna janana sāmarthyam upalabdha  kāma ātura ādi vartinyāḥ iti bhūtārthā api tad nirapekṣā eva samarthā iti na arthasya ālambana pratyaya tvam śakya avagamam
translated: And it is observed that even the cultivation of the true meaning, which is independent of the object, has the ability to generate clear consciousness.

original: api ca ālambanapratyayā api ta evāsya kṣaṇā yujyante /
analyzed: api ca ālambana pratyayāḥ api te eva asya kṣaṇāḥ yujyante
translated: Like that of one afflicted with desire, etc. Thus, even the true meaning is capable of functioning independently of that [object]. Therefore, it is not possible to understand that the object is the condition of the object of cognition.

original: ye tasya purastāttanā avyavadhānāstathā ca ta evāsya grāhyā na punaḥ pūrvatarāḥ /
analyzed: ye tasya purastāttanāḥ a vyavadhānāḥ tathā ca te eva asya grāhyāḥ na punar pūrvatarāḥ
translated: Moreover, only those moments of it that are immediately preceding and unobstructed are considered to be its objective conditions. And only those [moments] are its objects, not the earlier ones.

analyzed: tad kālāḥ anāgatāḥ ca iti na sarva viṣaya tā
translated: [The cognition] does not have all [objects] as its domain, [but only] those that exist at the time [of the cognition] and those that are future.

analyzed: atha dṛśyamānāḥ dhātu traya paryāpannāḥ prāṇabhṛtaḥ janma antara parivarta upātta atīta anāgata skandha kadambaka upādāna upādeya ātmānaḥ
translated: If [the objects] are the living beings belonging to the three realms that are seen, who have taken rebirth in other lives, and who are the aggregates of past and future that are to be taken up and taken on,

analyzed: iti tat darśanam dṛśyamāna tādātmyena tad viśeṣaṇa tayā atīta anāgatam api gocarayati
translated: then that [cognition] perceives the past and future by means of the identity of what is seen, as its qualification.

analyzed: na ca asmat ādi darśanasya api tathātva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And it is not the case that the cognition of one like us would also be like that.

analyzed: rāga ādi mala āvṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is covered by the impurities of passion, etc.

original: tasya ca bhagavato nirmṛṣṭanikhilakleśopakleśamalaṃ vijñānamanāvaraṇaṃ paritaḥ pradyotamāna mālambanapratyayaṃ sarvākāraṃ gocarayet /
analyzed: tasya ca bhagavataḥ nirmṛṣṭa nikhila kleśa upakleśa malam vijñānam anāvaraṇam paritas pradyotamāna mālambana pratyayam sarvākāram gocarayet
translated: And that consciousness of the Blessed One, free from the stain of afflictions and secondary afflictions, unobstructed, shining all around, would cognize the object-condition in all aspects.

original: tasya ca sākṣāt paramparayā ca kathañcit sarveṇa saṃbandhād deśkālaviprakīrṇavastumātraviśiṣṭasvabhāvatayā tathaiva gocarayet /
analyzed: tasya ca sākṣāt paramparayā ca kathañcid sarveṇa saṃbandhāt deśa kāla viprakīrṇa vastu mātra viśiṣṭa svabhāva tayā tathā eva gocarayet
translated: And that would cognize it as distinguished by the mere thing scattered in space and time, by some connection, direct or indirect, of that with all of it.

original: na caitat sarvagrahaṇamantareṇeti sarvaviṣayamasya vijñānamanāvaraṇaṃ siddham /
analyzed: na ca etat sarva grahaṇam antareṇa iti sarva viṣayam asya vijñānam anāvaraṇam siddham
translated: And this is not possible without grasping all of it. Thus it is established that its consciousness has all objects as its domain, being unobstructed.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: vicāra asaha tvāt
translated: Because it cannot withstand scrutiny.

original: tathā hīyamālambanapratyayasya sarvaviśiṣṭātmatā bhāvikī na vā /
analyzed: tathā hi iyam ālambana pratyayasya sarva viśiṣṭa ātma tā bhāvikī na vā
translated: For thus, is the nature of the object-condition distinguished by all in reality or not?

analyzed: bhāvikī ced  na tāvat sarvasmin ālambana pratyaye ca ekā saṃbhavati
translated: If it is in reality,🔽then first of all, one cannot exist in all object-conditions.

analyzed: ekasya aneka vṛtti tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because one cannot be present in many.

analyzed: nānā ced  ālambana pratyayāḥ ca sarve ca iti tattvam
translated: If it is many,🔽then it is the truth that the object-conditions are all.

original: tathā ca na saṃbandha iti na tadgrahaṇe sarvagrahaṇam /
analyzed: tathā ca na saṃbandhaḥ iti na tad grahaṇe sarva grahaṇam
translated: And in that case, there is no connection, so grasping it does not mean grasping all of it.

original: vikalpāropitatayā tvavikalpakaṃ samastavastuviṣayaṃ sarvatra pratīyata iti subhāṣitam /🔽svālambanapratyayamātragocaramevāvikalpakaṃ samastavastuviśiṣṭālambanādhyavasāyajananam /
analyzed: vikalpa āropita tayā tu avikalpakam samasta vastu viṣayam sarvatra pratīyate iti subhāṣitam  sva ālambana pratyaya mātra gocaram eva avikalpakam samasta vastu viśiṣṭa ālambana adhyavasāya jananam
translated: But it is well said that the non-conceptual [cognition] is perceived everywhere as having all things as its object, because it is superimposed by conceptual [cognitions].🔽The non-conceptual [cognition] has only its own object as its condition, and it generates the ascertainment of the object distinguished by all things.

analyzed: tena adhyavasāya anugata vyāpāram avikalpakam api samasta vastu viṣayam bhavati
translated: Therefore, even the non-conceptual [cognition] has all things as its object, because it has the function of following the ascertainment.

analyzed: yat āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: vyavasyanti īkṣaṇāt eva sarva ākārāt mahā dhiyaḥ
translated: The great mind ascertains all aspects from the very moment of seeing.

original: iti cet / atha katipayavastvālambanānubhavasya kutastya eṣa mahimā yataḥ samastavastvavasāya iti /
analyzed: iti ced atha katipaya vastu ālambana anubhavasya kutastyaḥ eṣa mahimā yatas samasta vastu avasāyaḥ iti
translated: If it is said that the non-conceptual [cognition] has all things as its object because it is the cause of the ascertainment of all things, then how could this greatness come from the experience of an object with only a few things, by which there is the ascertainment of all things?

analyzed: rāga ādi āvaraṇa vigamāt iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is due to being free from the obscurations of attachment and so on,

analyzed: tarhi yathāvat vastūni paśyet
translated: then it would see things as they are.

analyzed: na punar asmāt apārtha tvam asya iti
translated: But it is not that this [non-conceptual cognition] is useless.

analyzed: tat ayuktam vikalpa nirmāṇa kauśalam asya yujyeta
translated: That would not be right. It would be proper for it to have the skill of creating conceptual [cognitions].

original: tattvāvarakatā hi sulabhamalānāṃ kleśādīnāṃ na punarvikalpanirmāṇapratibandhatā /
analyzed: tattva āvaraka tā hi sulabha malānām kleśa ādīnām na punar vikalpa nirmāṇa pratibandha tā
translated: For it is easy for the defilements such as afflictions to obscure the truth, but it is not a hindrance to the creation of conceptual [cognitions].

analyzed: tasmāt bhāvanā prakarṣa mātra ja tvāt
translated: Therefore, because it arises merely from the culmination of meditation,

analyzed: artha avyabhicāra niyama abhāvāt
translated: and because there is no restriction of non-deviation from the object,

analyzed: viśada ābham api saṃśaya ākrānta tvāt apramāṇam apratyakṣam ca iti sāmpratam  nibandh
translated: It is reasonable that even clear cognition is not a valid means of knowledge and is not perception, because it is overcome by doubt.

analyzed: yat api sat artha prakāśanam buddheḥ svabhāvaḥ sat artha tvam ca āgantukam iti
translated: The nature of cognition is to illuminate real objects, and the appearance of unreal objects is adventitious.

analyzed: asati bādhake sat artha tvam eva iti
translated: If there is no contradiction, it is only real objects.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

original: anumitabhāvitavahniviṣayaviśadābhajñāna prāmāṇyaprasaṅgāt tadvidhasya kvacid bādhadarśanādaprāmāṇyamihāpi samānam /
analyzed: anumita bhāvita vahni viṣaya viśada ābha jñāna prāmāṇya prasaṅgāt tadvidhasya kvacid bādha darśanāt aprāmāṇyam iha api samānam
translated: Because it would follow that the clear cognition of fire inferred by inference would be a valid means of knowledge, and because the same applies here, where there is no contradiction.

analyzed: anyatra abhiniveśāt
translated: Because of attachment to something else.

original: tadiha yadi viśadābhavijñānahetutvaṃ bhāvanāyā viśeṣaṇatrayayogena sādhyate /
analyzed: tat iha yadi viśada ābha vijñāna hetu tvam bhāvanāyāḥ viśeṣaṇa traya yogena sādhyate
translated: Therefore, if the cause of clear cognition is being proven here by the three qualifications of cultivation,

analyzed: tatas siddha sādhanam
translated: then it is a futile effort.

analyzed: bhavatu tathāgataḥ tathābhūta vijñānavān
translated: Let the Tathāgata have such a cognition.

analyzed: na tu etat vijñānam asya pratyakṣam apramāṇa tvāt
translated: But this cognition is not his perception, because it is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca apakṣa dharma tayā hetoḥ asiddha tā
translated: And thus, because it is a property of the subject, the reason is unestablished.

analyzed: prasiddha dharmaṇaḥ dharmiṇaḥ jijñāsita viśeṣa tayā anumeya tva abhāvāt
translated: Because that which has well-known properties is not to be inferred due to the absence of desire to know its specific properties.

original: atha pratyakṣavijñānahetutā bhāvanāyāḥ paraṃ pratyasiddhā sādhyate /
analyzed: atha pratyakṣa vijñāna hetu tā bhāvanāyāḥ param sādhyate
translated: Or if the cause of perceptual cognition is being proven to be cultivation by the other party, it is unestablished.

analyzed: tathā ca sati sādhya viparyaya vyāpteḥ viruddha tā hetoḥ
translated: And if that were so, the reason would be contradictory because it pervades the opposite of the probandum.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa trayavatyāḥ api bhāvanāyāḥ viśada ābha bhrānta vijñāna janaka tvāt
translated: Because even a bhāvanā with three qualifications produces a clear and non-erroneous cognition.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntasya ca sādhya hīna tvāt
translated: And because the example lacks the probandum.

analyzed: yadā ca bhūta artha bhāvanā janita tve pi nā asya prāmāṇyam abhūta artha tvāt
translated: And when, even though it is produced by a bhāvanā of a real object, it is not valid because it has an unreal object,

analyzed: tadā yat ucyate  nirupadrava bhūta artha svabhāvasya viparyayaiḥ
translated: then what is said:🔽Even though one makes an effort, there is no contradiction of a cognition whose nature is a harmless real object,

analyzed: na bādhā yatnavat tve pi buddheḥ tad pakṣapātataḥ
translated: because it is biased towards that.

analyzed: iti tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

original: bhūtārthatve 'pi hi buddheḥ tatpakṣapātitā bhūtārthaiḥ pratipakṣairbādho na bhavet /
analyzed: bhūta artha tve hi buddheḥ tad pakṣapāti tā bhūta arthaiḥ pratipakṣaiḥ bādhaḥ na bhavet
translated: For even if a cognition has a real object, its contradiction by real counter-arguments with the same bias would not occur.

analyzed: abhūta arthā tu iyam sātmībhāva mā āpannā api ātma ātmīya dṛṣṭiḥ iva saṃbhavat bādhā
translated: But this [cognition] with an unreal object, even though it has become familiar, like the view of self and what belongs to self, is possible to be contradicted.

analyzed: tasmāt pratipakṣa vibṛddhi mātram  na tu ātyantikī vivṛddhiḥ saṃbhavati
translated: Therefore, it is merely the increase of the counter-arguments.🔽But the absolute increase is not possible.

original: yayā samūlakāṣaṃ kaṣitā doṣā na punarudbhaviṣyanti /
analyzed: yayā sa mūla kāṣam kaṣitāḥ doṣāḥ na punar udbhaviṣyanti
translated: By which the faults, having been uprooted to the very root, will not arise again.

original: ataevāsthirāśrayatve 'pi apunaryatnāpekṣatve 'pi asya nātyantikī niṣṭhā saṃbhavati /
analyzed: ataeva asthira āśraya tve pi apunar yatna apekṣa tve pi asya nā ātyantikī niṣṭhā saṃbhavati
translated: Therefore, even though it has an unstable basis and does not require renewed effort, it cannot have ultimate stability.

analyzed: ātma ātmīya dṛśaḥ iva virodhi pratyaya saṃbhavāt
translated: Like the views of self and what belongs to self, it can be opposed by other conditions.

analyzed: tad saṃbhavaḥ ca abhūta artha tvāt
translated: And that is possible because it has unreal objects.

analyzed: śruta anumita viṣayam tu pratyakṣam na saṃbhavati eva
translated: But perception that has as its object what is heard or inferred is not possible at all.

analyzed: tayoḥ parokṣa rūpa avagāhi tvāt
translated: Because those two penetrate imperceptible forms,

analyzed: pratyakṣasya ca tad viparīta tvāt
translated: and perception is the opposite of that.

analyzed: tad gata bhūta abhūta artha anuvidhāyi tvena sva viṣaye śruta anumāna jñāna apekṣayā prāmāṇya anupapatteḥ vai
translated: And because it is not logically possible for it to be a valid means of knowledge with regard to its own object in relation to knowledge derived from hearing and inference, following unreal objects that are included in that.

analyzed: tat siddham etat bhūta artha bhāvanā prakarṣa paryanta ja vijñānam apratyakṣam arthe prāmāṇyāt
translated: Therefore this is established: The consciousness produced at the end of the culmination of meditation on a real object is not perception, because it is not a valid means of knowledge with regard to the object.

analyzed: yat apramāṇam tat apratyakṣam arthe
translated: What is not a valid means of knowledge is not perception with regard to the object.

analyzed: yathā kāma āturasya kāminī vijñānam
translated: Like the consciousness of a lustful person with regard to a beautiful woman.

analyzed: a pramāṇam ca tat
translated: And that is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: nitānta viśada ābha tve sati bhāvanā
translated: Because it is produced by the culmination of meditation, while being extremely clear and vivid.

analyzed: yat nitānta viśada ābha tve sati bhāvanā prakarṣa jam vijñānam tat apramāṇam
translated: That consciousness which is produced by the culmination of meditation, while being extremely clear and vivid, is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: yathā anumita bhāvita vahni viśada vijñānam iti
translated: Like the clear cognition of fire that arises from the inference of fire.

analyzed: samāna hetu ja tvam samāna rūpatayā vyāptam
translated: Having the same cause is pervaded by having the same form.

analyzed: yat āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: tad a tad rūpiṇaḥ bhāvāḥ tad a tad rūpa hetu jāḥ
translated: Things that have the form of that and not that arise from causes that have the form of that and not that.

original: iti / tadasya prāmāṇyaṃ nivartamānaṃ tulyahetujatvamapi nivartayati /
analyzed: iti tat asya prāmāṇyam nivartamānam tulya hetu ja tvam api nivartayati
translated: Thus, when its validity ceases, the fact of having the same cause also ceases.

original: na caiṣa bhūtārthabhāvanāprakarṣaparyantajo 'nindriyasannikṛṣṭānumitabhāvitavahnivaiśadye ca nirātmakasamastavastuvaiśadye ca viśiṣyate /
analyzed: na ca eṣa bhūta artha bhāvanā prakarṣa paryanta jaḥ n indriya sannikṛṣṭa anumita bhāvita vahni vaiśadye ca nirātmaka samasta vastu vaiśadye ca viśiṣyate
translated: And this [cognition] does not arise from the culmination of the intensification of the conception of real objects, nor is it distinguished in the clarity of fire inferred but not in contact with the senses, or in the clarity of all things devoid of self.

analyzed: na ca rāga ādi āvaraṇa virahaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: And the absence of obscurations such as attachment is not a distinction.

original: na khalvete kambalādibadāvarakā vijñānasya /🔽kiṃ tu tadākṣiptamanā vividhaviṣayabhedatṛṣṇādiparipluto na śaknoti bbāvayitumiti bhāvanādaramātra eva tadvirahopayogaḥ /
analyzed: na khalu ete kambala ādi badāvarakāḥ vijñānasya  kim tu tad ākṣipta manāḥ vividha viṣaya bheda tṛṣṇā ādi pariplutaḥ na śaknoti bbāvayitum iti bhāvanā ādara mātraḥ eva tad viraha upayogaḥ
translated: For these [obscurations] do not cover the cognition like a blanket, etc.🔽But the mind distracted by various desires for different objects, being drawn by them, is unable to conceive [the object]. Thus, the absence of those [obscurations] is useful only in the mere respect for meditation.

original: asti cehāpi śiśirabharasaṃbhṛta jaḍimamantharatarakāyakāṇḍasyānumitavahnibhāvanābhiyoga iti na hetu bhedataḥ pratibandhasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: asti ca iha api śiśira bhara saṃbhṛta jaḍima mantharatara kāya kāṇḍasya anumita vahni bhāvanā abhiyogaḥ iti na hetu bhedataḥ pratibandha siddhiḥ
translated: And here too, there is the application of meditation on inferred fire for one whose body and limbs are very slow and dull due to the accumulation of cold. Thus, there is no establishment of the restriction by difference of cause.

analyzed: na ca eka pārthiva aṇu samavāyi kāraṇa janmabhiḥ abhinna auṣṇya apekṣa eka vahni saṃyoga asamavāyi kāraṇaiḥ gandha rasa rūpa sparśaiḥ nānā svabhāvaiḥ vyabhicāraḥ  sāmarthya vaicitryāt eka tve pi pārthivasya paramāṇoḥ
translated: And there is no inconstancy with the smell, taste, form, and touch, which are produced by the inherent cause consisting of the aggregation of one earth atom, and which have as their inherent cause the contact with one fire, which is not different in heat, and which have different natures.🔽Even in the case of the earth atom, which is one, the variety is due to the variety of potencies.

analyzed: tad vaicitryam ca kārya vaicitrya upalambhāt
translated: And that variety is inferred from the observation of the variety of effects.

analyzed: tat ca nitya samavetam nityam
translated: And that is eternal and always present, and is eternal.

original: kāraṇasāmarthyaprakrameṇa ca pārthivāvayavini kārye jāyata iti avadātam /
analyzed: kāraṇa sāmarthya prakrameṇa ca pārthiva avayavini kārye jāyate iti avadātam
translated: And it is produced in the earth aggregate, which is the effect, in the order of the potency of the cause. Thus it is clear.

analyzed: pariśiṣṭam tu grantha vyākhyāna samaye vyākhyāsyāmaḥ
translated: But the rest we will explain at the time of explaining the text.

analyzed: tat āstām tāvat
translated: Let that be so for the present.

analyzed: trilocanaḥ tu nyāya prakīrṇake prāha
translated: But Trilocana says in the Nyāyaprakarana:

analyzed: iha kila duḥkha samudaya nirodha mārga ākhyāni āryāṇām satyāni catvāri
translated: Here, indeed, the four noble truths are the truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and path.

analyzed: teṣām satyānām svarūpa sākṣātkāri jñānam yogi pratyakṣam
translated: The yogi's perception is the knowledge that directly perceives the nature of those truths.

analyzed: tatra duḥkham phala bhūtāḥ pañca upādāna skandhāḥ
translated: Among them, suffering is the five aggregates that are subject to clinging, which are the fruits.

analyzed: tat ca svarūpataḥ jñātavyam
translated: And that should be known in its own nature.

analyzed: te eva hetu bhūtāḥ samudayaḥ
translated: Those same aggregates that are the causes are the origin.

analyzed: sa ca prahātavyaḥ
translated: And that should be abandoned.

analyzed: niḥkleśa avasthā cittasya nirodhaḥ
translated: The cessation of the mind is the state free from afflictions.

analyzed: sa ca sākṣātkartavyaḥ
translated: And that must be directly realized.

analyzed: tad avasthā prāpti hetuḥ nairātmya kṣaṇika tva ādi ākāraḥ citta viśeṣaḥ mārgaḥ
translated: The path is a special mind with aspects such as selflessness and momentariness that is the cause for attaining that state.

analyzed: sa ca bhāvayitavyaḥ iti saugata matam
translated: And that must be cultivated - this is the Buddhist view.

original: atrocyate / mārgastāvat pramāṇapariśuddho na bhavatītyuktaṃ prāk /
analyzed: atrā ucyate mārgaḥ tāvat pramāṇa pariśuddhaḥ na bhavati iti uktam prāk
translated: Here it is said: First of all, it has been said that the path is not purified by valid cognition.

analyzed: atas bhūta viṣayasya vikalpasya abhyāsāt asatya artha vijñānam syāt na saṃvādi
translated: Therefore, from the practice of conceptualization with unreal objects, there would be cognition of unreal objects, not in agreement [with reality].

original: api ca pramāṇapariśuddhamārgavādo śākyaḥ pramāṇaṃ pṛṣṭaḥ san satvākhyaliṅgajaṃ vikalpaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: api ca śākyaḥ pramāṇam pṛṣṭaḥ san satva ākhya liṅga jam vikalpam brūyāt
translated: Moreover, when asked about valid cognition, the Buddhist who advocates the path purified by valid cognition would say that conceptualization arises from the inferential sign called existence.

analyzed: tatas yāvat vikalpena darśita rūpam tat sarvam asat
translated: Therefore, whatever is shown by conceptualization, all that is unreal.

analyzed: śabda saṃsṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it is mixed with words.

original: tasmiṃśca bhāvyamāne sattve bhāvakasya vikalpakasya bhāvanopahite viśadābhatve śabdasaṃsṛṣṭagrāhyanimittaṃ vikalpakatvaṃ nivartate /
analyzed: tasmin ca bhāvyamāne sattve bhāvakasya vikalpakasya bhāvanā upahite viśada ābha tve śabda saṃsṛṣṭa grāhya nimittam vikalpaka tvam nivartate
translated: And when that existent is being cultivated, in the clear appearance infused with cultivation of the cultivator, the conceptualizer, the conceptualizing of the object-sign mixed with words ceases.

analyzed: tad vyāvṛttau grāhyam api śabda saṃsṛṣṭam nivartate
translated: When that ceases, the object-sign mixed with words also ceases.

analyzed: atas nirvikalpakam api yogi jñānam nirviṣayam prasaktam
translated: Therefore, even non-conceptual knowledge of a yogin is implicated as being without an object.

analyzed: yat tu pāramārthikam vastu ātmakam na
translated: But that which is the ultimate reality, which is not dependent on anything else,
is purified by valid cognition.

analyzed: śuddhau vā kim bhāvanayā
translated: If it is purified, what is the use of meditation?

analyzed: bhāvyasya sākṣāt vijñāta tvāt
translated: Because what is to be meditated upon is directly known.

original: na cānyasmin śabdasaṃsṛṣṭe bhāvyamāne sphuṭamanyadrūpaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na ca anyasmin śabda saṃsṛṣṭe bhāvyamāne sphuṭam anyat rūpam bhavati
translated: And when something else is being meditated upon in connection with words, another form does not become clear.

analyzed: śoka āturasya api niruddha indriya vyāpārasya tanaya bhāvanāyām mitra ādi pratibhāsa prasaṅgāt
translated: Even for one afflicted with grief, when the functioning of the senses is restrained, there would be the appearance of friends and so on when meditating on one's son.

original: kṣaṇikatve bhāvye samāropite vāstavaṃ kṣaṇikatvameva yogivijñānapratibhāsīti cet / na /
analyzed: kṣaṇika tve bhāvye samāropite vāstavam kṣaṇika tvam eva yogi vijñāna pratibhāsi iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that when momentariness is being meditated upon, the real momentariness itself appears in the cognition of the yogi, that is not so.

analyzed: satya asatyayoḥ eka tva abhāva ātmake hi bhede satya bhāvane yadi satya pratibhāsaḥ
translated: For in the case of identity and non-identity, if there is the appearance of the real when meditating on the unreal,

analyzed: tarhi satya tanaya abhyāse pi śabda sāmyāt abhedinaḥ tanaya saṃjñakasya kasyacid aparasya svarūpa pratibhāsa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then even in the practice of meditating on the real son, there would be the appearance of the form of someone else who is not different and who is designated as the son, due to the similarity of words.

original: tasmādabhūtaviṣayābhyāsaṃ nirvikalpakamapi saṃvādānna pramāṇamiti na sarvajñasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt abhūta viṣaya abhyāsam nirvikalpakam api saṃvādāt na pramāṇam iti na sarvajña siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, even non-conceptual meditation on a non-existent object is not valid knowledge because it is in agreement with non-existent objects. Thus there is no establishment of omniscience.

original: api ca bhāvyasya vastunaḥ punaḥ punaścetasi niveśanamabhyāsaḥ /
analyzed: api ca bhāvyasya vastunaḥ punar punar cetasi niveśanam abhyāsaḥ
translated: Moreover, meditation is the repeated placing of the object to be meditated upon in the mind.

original: sa ca brahmacaryeṇa tapasā sādaraṃ dīrghakālaṃ nirantaramāsevito dṛḍhabhūmirasphuṭākārasya vikalpasya sphuṭābhatvajanana iṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca brahmacaryeṇa tapasā sādaram dīrgha kālam nirantaram āsevitaḥ dṛḍha bhūmiḥ asphuṭa ākārasya vikalpasya sphuṭa ābha tva jananaḥ iṣṭaḥ
translated: And that [concentration] is accepted as producing clear appearance for a conceptual cognition with an unclear image, when practiced with celibacy, austerity, respect, for a long time, continuously, and with firmness.

analyzed: sa kṣaṇika tva nairātmya vādinā draḍhayitum aśakyaḥ
translated: That [concentration] cannot be strengthened by one who asserts momentariness and selflessness.

original: tathā hi bhāvyagrāhī yādṛśo vikalpa utpannastādṛśa eva niranvayaṃ nirudhyate /
analyzed: tathā hi bhāvya grāhī yādṛśaḥ vikalpaḥ utpannaḥ tādṛśaḥ eva niranvayam nirudhyate
translated: For thus, the conceptual cognition that apprehends the object to be cultivated ceases without remainder in exactly the same way that it arose.

original: tasmiṃśca niruddhe punaḥ punarutpadyamānaḥ pratyayastādṛśa evāpūrva utpadyate /
analyzed: tasmin ca niruddhe punar punar utpadyamānaḥ pratyayaḥ tādṛśaḥ eva apūrvaḥ utpadyate
translated: And when that [conceptual cognition] has ceased, the condition that arises again and again produces exactly the same new [conceptual cognition].

original: tadanena paryāyeṇa kalpasahasre 'pi apūrvotpatteraviśeṣānna tajjanyaḥ saṃskāro 'bhyāsa utpadyate /
analyzed: tat anena paryāyeṇa kalpa sahasre pi apūrva utpatteḥ aviśeṣāt na tad janyaḥ saṃskāraḥ bhyāsaḥ utpadyate
translated: By this method, even in a thousand eons, there is no difference in the production of the new [conceptual cognition], so the impression produced by that [concentration] does not arise as cultivation.

analyzed: etena viśiṣṭa vijñāna utpādaḥ bhyāsaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this [method], cultivation that produces a special cognition is explained.

original: niranvayaniruddhaṃ hi pūrvapūrvavijñānaṃ kathamuttarottarāvasthāntaraṃ viśiṣṭaṃ janayet /
analyzed: niranvaya niruddham hi pūrva pūrva vijñānam katham uttara uttara avasthā antaram viśiṣṭam janayet
translated: For how could the previous cognition, which has ceased without remainder, produce a special subsequent state?

original: sarvathā kramabhāvibhiḥ pratyayairavasthitameva rūpaṃ śakyaṃ saṃskartum /
analyzed: sarvathā krama bhāvibhiḥ pratyayaiḥ avasthitam eva rūpam śakyam saṃskartum
translated: In every way, only a stable form can be modified by conditions that occur in sequence.

analyzed: anavasthitam tu sva utpāda vyaya yogi mātram iti aviśiṣṭam syāt
translated: But what is unstable, which is merely subject to its own production and destruction, would be non-distinct.

original: tasmāt pratyāvṛttibhāvyavastupratyayajaḥ saṃskāro vyutthānapratyayasaṃskāravirodhī yasyāsti tasyaivātmanaḥ prakṛṣṭo 'pi bhāvyasākṣātkāripratyayaheturitiyuktaṃ
analyzed: tasmāt pratyāvṛtti bhāvya vastu pratyaya jaḥ saṃskāraḥ vyutthāna pratyaya saṃskāra virodhī yasya asti tasya eva ātmanaḥ prakṛṣṭaḥ pi bhāvya sākṣātkāri pratyaya hetuḥ iti yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that only for that self which has a latent impression born from the object of the thing to be realized by return, which is opposed to the latent impression of the condition of distraction, is the cause of the condition of realization of the thing to be realized, even though it is excellent.

analyzed: paśyāmaḥ
translated: We see this.

analyzed: kim ca cittam ekāgram vyavasthāpayitum vikṣepa tyāga artham abhyāsaḥ nuṣṭhīyate
translated: Moreover, practice is undertaken in order to establish the mind in concentration and to abandon distraction.

analyzed: na ca kṣaṇika vādinām vikṣiptam cittam asti
translated: But for those who assert momentariness, there is no distracted mind.

analyzed: prati artha niyata tayā sarvasya citta ekāgra tvāt
translated: Because everything is concentrated on one object, being restricted to each object.

original: tathā hi yadi sākāraṃ vikalpavijñānaṃ svapratibhāsaniyatatvāt ekāgrameva tat kathaṃ vikṣipyate /
analyzed: tathā hi yadi sa ākāram vikalpa vijñānam sva pratibhāsa niyata tvāt ekāgram eva tat katham vikṣipyate
translated: Thus, if the conceptual consciousness with form is concentrated on its own appearance, how can it be distracted?

original: atha nirākāraṃ tathāpi vikalpakaṃ prati vikalpyaṃ bhinnameva /
analyzed: atha nirākāram tathā api vikalpakam prati vikalpyam bhinnam eva
translated: Even if it is formless, in that way also the object of conceptualization is different from the conceptualizer.

analyzed: na tu sarva vikalpānām ekam vikalpyam asti
translated: But there is no single object of conceptualization for all conceptualizations.

analyzed: tatas nirākāram api vijñānam niyata ālambana tvāt ekāgram eva
translated: Therefore, even formless consciousness is concentrated on a restricted object and is therefore concentrated,

analyzed: na vikṣiptam
translated: not distracted.

original: sarvathā nāsti kṣaṇikavādināmekamanekārthamavasthitaṃ cittaṃ yadekāgraṃ kartumiṣyate /
analyzed: sarvathā nā asti kṣaṇika vādinām ekam aneka artham avasthitam cittam yat ekāgram kartum iṣyate
translated: In every way, there is no single mind of the proponents of momentariness that is many-purposed and enduring, which is intended to be made concentrated.

original: tadevamabhyāsānupapatterasarvajñavatyāṃ cittasantatau na ca vijñānaviśeṣaḥ sarvajñaḥ sidhyatīti //
analyzed: tat evam abhyāsa anupapatteḥ asarvajñavatyām citta santatau na ca vijñāna viśeṣaḥ sarvajñaḥ sidhyati iti
translated: Thus, because practice is impossible, and because the continuum of consciousness does not possess omniscience, the special consciousness of the yogin is not established as omniscient.

analyzed: nyāyabhūṣaṇa kāraḥ tu āha
translated: However, the author of the Nyāyabhūṣaṇa says:

original: sarvajñānānāṃ nirālambanatve saṃvedanamātratve ca yogītarapratyayayoḥ ko viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: sarva jñānānām nirālambana tve saṃvedana mātra tve ca yogi itara pratyayayoḥ kaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: If all cognitions are without an object and are mere consciousness, what is the difference between the cognition of the yogin and that of others?

analyzed: śuddha aśuddha tvam iti ced
translated: If it is said to be purity and impurity,

analyzed: bhavatu nāma evam
translated: let it be so.

analyzed: tathā api catur ārya satya ādi viṣaya tvam ayuktam
translated: Even so, it is not proper for it to have as its object the four noble truths and so on.

original: na hi svātmamātravedanena caturāryasatyādikaṃ sākṣātkṛtamiti yuktamatiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: na hi sva ātma mātra vedanena catur ārya satya ādikam sākṣātkṛtam iti yuktam atiprasaṅgāt
translated: For it is not proper to say that the four noble truths and so on are directly realized by the knowledge of one's own self alone, because that would lead to an absurd consequence.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: tad ākāra tvena tad viṣaya tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it has those as its object by having their form,

analyzed: tat kim idānīm sautrāntika matam abhyupagatam satyam
translated: then is the Sautrāntika doctrine now accepted as true?

analyzed: katham
translated: Even so, how can it have the future as its object?

analyzed: na hi asataḥ kaścid ākāraḥ sti
translated: For the non-existent has no form.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa śruta anumita ākāraḥ ca yadi bhāvanā balataḥ spaṣṭaḥ evā avabhāti
translated: And if the form of what is seen, heard, or inferred appears clearly by the power of meditation,

analyzed: tathā ca sati bhrāntam eva yogi pratyakṣam syāt
translated: and if it is so, then the yogic perception would be mistaken.

analyzed: a vidyamānasya vidyamāna ākāra tayā pratibhāsanāt svapna vat
translated: Because what does not exist appears in the form of what exists, like in a dream.

original: tathā' visaṃvāditvānna bhrāntam / na /🔽anumānajñānasya bhrāntatve 'pi avisaṃvāditvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: tathā visaṃvādi tvāt na bhrāntam na  anumāna jñānasya bhrānta tve pi avisaṃvādi tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Thus, it is not erroneous because it is not contradicted. No.🔽Because even though inferential knowledge is erroneous, it is accepted to be non-contradictory.

analyzed: atha bhrāntasya api saṃvādi tvena prāmāṇyam
translated: If even an erroneous cognition is valid because it is non-contradictory,

analyzed: tathā api pratyakṣa lakṣaṇasya abhrānta tva viśeṣaṇam virudhyate
translated: then the definition of perception as non-erroneous is contradicted.

original: na cāvisaṃvāditvamapi tvanmate yuktam /🔽yataḥ prāpyārthadarśakatvaṃ vā /
analyzed: na ca avisaṃvādi tvam api tvad mate yuktam  yatas prāpya artha darśaka tvam vā
translated: And non-contradiction is not appropriate according to your view.🔽Because it is either the state of showing an attainable object,

analyzed: pravṛtti viṣaya upadarśaka tvam vā
translated: or the state of showing the object of engagement,

analyzed: avabhātāt artha kriyā niṣpattiḥ vā bhavatām avisaṃvādi tvam abhipretam  na ca etat atīta ādi artha jñāne saṃbhavati
translated: or the accomplishment of the operation of an object after it has appeared. This is what you intend by non-contradiction.🔽And this is not possible in the case of knowledge of past and future objects.

analyzed: vartamāna artha jñānasya api kṣaṇika tva pakṣe nā upapadyate eva
translated: And it does not hold even in the case of knowledge of present objects, in the view that they are momentary.

analyzed: tasmāt saugatānām yogi pratyakṣa upavarṇanam ayuktam eva iti
translated: Therefore, the Sautrāntikas' description of yogic perception is indeed inappropriate.

analyzed: kim ca idam api vaktum ucitam
translated: Moreover, this should also be said:

analyzed: yadi anumāna pūrvakam artheṣu bhāvanā bala ja jñānam āśvāsa bhājanam
translated: If knowledge arising from the power of meditation on objects preceded by inference is a source of confidence,

analyzed: tat āstām tāvat anumāna pauruṣa pratyāśā
translated: Let alone the hope of [validating] inference by human effort.

original: pratyakṣeṇāpi cakṣurdahanādikaṃ gṛhītvā bhāvanāprakarṣaparyante jātaṃ sthirataraṃ tadākāravijñānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa api cakṣuḥ dahana ādikam gṛhītvā bhāvanā prakarṣa paryante jātam sthirataram tad ākāra vijñānam syāt
translated: Even by perception, having grasped the eye, fire, etc., a very stable cognition with that form would arise at the culmination of the perfection of meditation.

analyzed: yāvat na bhāvanā abhiyoga paryantaḥ
translated: As long as there is no culmination of intense practice of contrary meditation.

original: astaṃ gataśca tadviṣayo 'vasthāntaraprāpto veti kathaṃ pramāṇopanītavastugocaratve 'pi saṃvādāśvāsaḥ /
analyzed: astam gataḥ ca tad viṣayaḥ vasthā antara prāptaḥ vā iti katham pramāṇa upanīta vastu gocara tve saṃvāda āśvāsaḥ
translated: And the object has set, or has attained another state - so how can there be assurance of agreement even when the object is presented by a means of valid knowledge?

original: api ca yadā hālika eva havyāśanamanumāya bhāvanayā sphuṭayet /
analyzed: api ca yadā hālikaḥ eva havya aśanam anumāya bhāvanayā sphuṭayet
translated: Moreover, when the farmer himself infers the eater of oblations and clarifies it through meditation,

analyzed: tadā na tat yogi jñānam paramārtha viṣaya abhāvāt iti pratyakṣa antara prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then that yogic cognition is not ultimately about an object, so it would be another kind of perception.

analyzed: kim ca tat yogi jñānam indriya jñānāt bhinnam abhinnam vā
translated: Furthermore, is that yogic cognition different from sense cognition or not different?

original: abhedapakṣe na yogijñānaṃ nāma pratyakṣeṇa bhinnamindriyajñānenaiva saṃgrahāt /
analyzed: abheda pakṣe na yogi jñānam nāma pratyakṣeṇa bhinnam indriya jñānena eva saṃgrahāt
translated: If it is non-different, then there is no such thing as yogic cognition that is different from perception, because it is included in sense cognition itself.

analyzed: na ca bhāvanā upaskṛta santānasya tathā udayāt bheda vyavasthā
translated: And it cannot be established as different just because it arises thus from a continuum refined by meditation.

analyzed: rasāyana ādi saṃskāra apekṣayā api pratyakṣa antara vyavasthā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurd consequence of another kind of perception even in dependence on refinement by elixirs, etc.

analyzed: bheda pakṣe ca bhāvanā saṃbhavam jñānam kṣaṇika sākṣātkāri
translated: And in the case of difference, the knowledge born of meditation would directly perceive the momentary,

analyzed: indriya jñānam ca syairya grāhi iti sādhvī siddhiḥ
translated: and the sense cognition would grasp the impermanent. Thus, the conclusion is sound.

analyzed: indriya jñānasya api tad avasthāyām asthairya grahaṇe kṛtam yogi jñānena
translated: If the sense cognition also grasps the impermanence in that state, what is the use of the knowledge of the yogin?

analyzed: na ca tasya ākasmikaḥ kṣaṇika tva avabodhaḥ
translated: And its sudden understanding of momentariness is not possible.

analyzed: bhāvanā udbhūta vaiśadyasya hi tad bodhaḥ
translated: For its understanding is born of the clarity produced by meditation.

analyzed: na ca indriya jñānasya bhāvanā
translated: And there is no meditation for sense cognition.

analyzed: api tu manaḥ vijñāne
translated: But for mental consciousness.

original: tāmantareṇāpi sākṣāt kriyālābhe ca bhāvanāvaiyarthyamiti kāraṇābhāvādeva sarvajñapratihatiḥ //
analyzed: tām antareṇa api sākṣāt kriyā lābhe ca bhāvanā vaiyarthyam iti kāraṇa abhāvāt eva sarvajña pratihatiḥ
translated: And if it directly obtains its object even without that, then meditation is useless. Thus, the obstruction to omniscience is due to the absence of a cause itself.

analyzed: atra abhidhīyate
translated: To this we reply:

original: yattāvat sarvapadārthasaṃvedanasya kāraṇaṃ kimindriyajñānamityādi valgitaṃ tatra bhāvanābalajaṃ manovijñānameva sarvapadārthagrāhīti pañcama 🔽evāsmākaṃ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: yat tāvat sarva padārtha saṃvedanasya kāraṇam kim indriya jñānam ityādi valgitam tatra bhāvanā bala jam manaḥ vijñānam eva sarva padārtha grāhi iti  eva asmākam pakṣaḥ
translated: As for the boasting that the cause of the knowledge of all things is sense cognition, etc., there, the mental consciousness born of the power of meditation itself grasps all things. Our position is only the fifth.

analyzed: atas pakṣa antara bhāvinaḥ doṣāḥ anabhyupagama pratihatāḥ
translated: Therefore, the faults arising from other positions are obstructed by non-acceptance.

analyzed: yat ca asmad abhyupagate pañcame pakṣe dūṣaṇam uktam
translated: And the fault stated in our accepted fifth position,

analyzed: anartha tvāt pratyakṣa śabdasya
translated: Because the word pratyaksa is meaningless.

analyzed: tasya ca nakṣaja tvāt na artha sākṣātkāri tvam asti iti
translated: And even though it depends on the power of bhāvanā, it does not have the nature of directly perceiving objects because it is produced by the mind.

analyzed: tat asaṅgatam
translated: That is not correct.

original: tathā hi pratyakṣaśabdasya tāvadakṣāśritatvaṃ vyutpattinimittamarthasākṣātkāritvaṃ tu pravṛttinimittamiti pratipāditam /
analyzed: tathā hi pratyakṣa śabdasya tāvat akṣa āśrita tvam vyutpatti nimittam artha sākṣātkāri tvam tu pravṛtti nimittam iti pratipāditam
translated: For this has been explained: the etymological basis for the word pratyaksa is being based on the sense faculties, but the basis for its usage is the nature of directly perceiving objects.

original: Nibandh na ca bhāvanābalāvalambino manovijñānasyānakṣāśritatve 'pyarthasākṣātkaraṇe kaścidasti śaktipratighātaḥ /
analyzed: na ca bhāvanā bala avalambinaḥ manaḥ vijñānasya an akṣa āśrita tve pi artha sākṣātkaraṇe kaścid asti śakti pratighātaḥ
translated: And even though the mental consciousness that depends on the power of bhāvanā is not based on the sense faculties, there is no obstruction to its ability to directly perceive objects.

original: yathā hi cakṣrurindriyaṃ svasāmarthyānatikrameṇa yogyadeśasthamarthamapekṣya svavijñānajanane pravartate /
analyzed: yathā hi cakṣruḥ indriyam sva sāmarthya anatikrameṇa yogya deśa stham artham apekṣya sva vijñāna janane pravartate
translated: Just as the eye sense faculty, without exceeding its own power, operates in generating its own consciousness in dependence on an object located in a suitable place,

original: tathā sarvāvidyāparipanthibhūtārthabhāvanāsahitaṃ mana indriyamapi yogyadeśasthamarthaṃ prāpya svavijñānajanane pravartiṣyate /
analyzed: tathā sarva avidyā paripanthi bhūta artha bhāvanā sahitam manaḥ indriyam api yogya deśa stham artham prāpya sva vijñāna janane pravartiṣyate
translated: in the same way, the mental sense faculty, accompanied by the bhāvanā of the object that is the antidote to all ignorance, will operate in generating its own consciousness upon reaching an object located in a suitable place.

analyzed: aprāpyakāritāyāḥ ubhayoḥ sādhāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because the ability to operate without contact is common to both [the eye sense faculty and the mental sense faculty].

analyzed: arthavat tāyāḥ ca manasaḥ u pi tadānīm iṣṭa tvāt
translated: And because the usefulness of the mental [sense faculty] is accepted at that time [when it directly perceives objects].

analyzed: pṛthagjanasya tu na tādṛśī śaktiḥ
translated: But an ordinary person does not have such power.

analyzed: yatas netra śrotra vat manaḥ pi tādṛś maryādayā yogya deśa stham artha sahakāriṇam āsādya vedanam utpādayet
translated: Because, like the eye and ear, the mind also, being in a suitable place within that limit, would produce cognition by encountering an object as a cooperating factor.

analyzed: sarva avidyā unmūlakasya bhāvanā viśeṣasya sahakāriṇaḥ bhāvāt iti na atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: But there is no overextension, because there is an absence of cooperating factors for a particular meditation that uproots all ignorance.

original: tadavasthāyāṃ tu śrutinayanayoriva manaso 'pi kiyaddūreṇa viṣayasannidhivyavasthitika eva pramātuṃ kṣamaḥ /
analyzed: tad avasthāyām tu śruti nayanayoḥ iva kiyat dūreṇa viṣaya sannidhi vyavasthitikaḥ eva pramātum kṣamaḥ
translated: But in that state, like the ear and eye, the mind also, even if established at a certain distance from the object, is capable of cognizing it.

analyzed: kevalam etāvat ucyate
translated: Only this much is said.

original: yāvattena śakyamadhigantuṃ svākārārpaṇasamartha sahakāri vastu tāvaditarajanāsādhāraṇaṃ truṭyadrūpatayā tasya gocarībhavatīti /
analyzed: yāvat tena śakyam adhigantum su ākāra arpaṇa samartha sahakāri vastu tāvat itara jana asādhāraṇam truṭyat rūpa tayā tasya gocarībhavati iti
translated: To that extent, the object capable of impressing its form is made the object of that [mind], and to that extent, it becomes the object of that [mind] as a momentary form, which is not common to other people.

original: ata evārthākāro vastuto na bhāvanāmātrajanita iti na visaṃvādaśaṅkāpi /
analyzed: atas eva arthākāraḥ vastutas na bhāvanā mātra janitaḥ iti na visaṃvāda śaṅkā api
translated: For this very reason, the form of the object is not actually produced by meditation alone, so there is no doubt of contradiction.

original: bhāvanayā punastadīyasantāne netra ivāñjanaviśeṣeṇa śaktiratiśayavatī kācidarpitā yatparajanāsādhāraṇadarśanamasya /
analyzed: bhāvanayā punar tadīya santāne netre iva añjana viśeṣeṇa śaktiḥ atiśayavatī kācid arpitā yat para jana asādhāraṇa darśanam asya
translated: But by meditation, some very powerful capacity is impressed in its continuum, like collyrium in the eye, by which it has a vision that is not common to other people.

analyzed: tasmāt an akṣa ja tve manaḥ vijñānasya artha sākṣātkāri tvam sambhavati
translated: Therefore, even though mental consciousness is not produced by the eye, it is possible for it to perceive objects.

analyzed: nanu manasaḥ bahis asvātantryam
translated: But the mind is not independent externally.

analyzed: anyathā andha badhira ādi abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, the existence of the blind, deaf, and so on would be impossible.

analyzed: uktam ca yoginām dharma adharmayoḥ aparokṣa pratibhāsam jñānam na asti
translated: And it is said that yogis do not have knowledge that directly appears as dharma and adharma,

analyzed: indriya sannikarṣa abhāvāt asmat ādi vat iti
translated: because they lack contact with the sense faculties, like us and others.

original: api ca / arthasya hi ālambanapratyayatvamindriyāpekṣatvena vyāptam /
analyzed: api ca arthasya hi ālambana pratyaya tvam indriya apekṣa tvena vyāptam
translated: Moreover, the object's being the object condition is pervaded by depending on the sense faculties.

analyzed: tat ca asmāt sva viruddha upalabdhyā vyāvartamānam ālambana pratyaya tām api tasya nivartayati
translated: And that, being excluded by the perception of its opposite, also excludes its being the object condition.

original: na khalvindhanaviśeṣo dhūmaheturiti vināpi dahanaṃ sahasreṇāpi saṃskārairdhūmamādhatte /
analyzed: na khalu indhana viśeṣaḥ dhūma hetuḥ iti vinā api dahanam sahasreṇa api saṃskāraiḥ dhūmam ādhatte
translated: For a particular fuel is not the cause of smoke. Even without burning, it produces smoke with a thousand modifications.

analyzed: tad ādhāne samasta kārya hetuka anumāna uccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If it did produce it, then the entire inference based on effects and causes would be destroyed.

original: na ca bhāvanābalena kasyacidatīndriyadarśitvaṃ sarvajñatvaṃ vā dṛṣṭamiti cet /
analyzed: na ca bhāvanā balena kasyacid atīndriya darśi tvam sarvajña tvam vā dṛṣṭam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that no one is seen to have the power to perceive the imperceptible or omniscience through the power of meditation,

analyzed: atra ucyate manaḥ śabdena tāvat asmākam anakṣajam vijñānam eva abhipretam
translated: it is said in response: As for the word mind, we intend by it only consciousness that is not produced by the eye.

analyzed: na ca asmin andha badhira ādi abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And in this case, there is no contingence of the absence of the blind, the deaf, etc.

analyzed: sarva avidyā pratipakṣa bhūta artha bhāvanā lakṣaṇasya sahakāri viśeṣasya andha ādīnām abhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of the special cooperating factor in the form of the cultivation of the object which is the counteragent to all ignorance, in the case of the blind, etc.

analyzed: indriya sannikarṣa abhāvāt iti tu artha sākṣātkāri tva mātra apekṣayā sandigdha vyatireki tve anaikāntikī kāraṇa anupalabdhiḥ
