translated: But if the non-apprehension of the cause is considered in relation to the mere capacity for the direct perception of the object, then it is inconclusive, as the absence of the object is doubtful.

original: asmadvidhārthasākṣātkāritvāpekṣayā punaḥ siddhasādhanam //🔽asmadādiviśeṣaṇaśūnyasyārthasākṣātkāritvamātrasyaivendriyādhīnatvadarśanādanaikāntikatvamasaṃbhavīti cet /🔽yadyevamarthasākṣātkāritvamātrasyendriyavadālokādhīnatvamupalabdhamiti na santamase paśyeyurulūkādayaḥ /
analyzed: asmadvidha artha sākṣātkāri tva apekṣayā punar siddha sādhanam  asmat ādi viśeṣaṇa śūnyasya artha sākṣātkāri tva mātrasya eva indriya adhīna tva darśanāt anaikāntika tvam asaṃbhavi iti ced  yadi evam artha sākṣātkāri tva mātrasya indriya vat āloka adhīna tvam upalabdham iti na santamase paśyeyuḥ ulūka ādayaḥ
translated: If it is considered in relation to the capacity for direct perception of an object like us, then it is a futile rejoinder.🔽If it is argued that the inconclusiveness is impossible, because the mere capacity for direct perception of an object devoid of the qualification of us is seen to be dependent on the sense organ,🔽then if it is so, it is observed that the mere capacity for direct perception of an object is dependent on light like the sense organ, so owls, etc. would not see in the dark.

analyzed: atha vyabhicāra darśanāt ālokasya avyāpaka tvam
translated: If it is argued that the inconclusiveness is due to the observation of deviation, and light is not all-pervading,

analyzed: vyabhicāra śaṅkayā tarhi indriyasya api avyāpaka tvam
translated: then due to the suspicion of deviation, the sense organ is also not all-pervading.

analyzed: vyāptyā śaṅkā khaṇḍyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the suspicion is contradicted by the pervasion,

analyzed: śaṅkā asaṃbhavāt vyāptiḥ eva asaṃbhavinī
translated: then due to the impossibility of suspicion, the pervasion itself is impossible.

analyzed: yadi hi prathamatas eva vyāptiḥ
translated: If the pervasion is established at the outset,

analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ pi na dṛśyeta
translated: Nor would there be any instance of deviation.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: binding

analyzed: tasmāt vyabhicāra darśanam vyāpti śaithilyāt eva
translated: Therefore, the observation of deviation is due to the looseness of the pervasion itself.

original: sati ca vyāptiśaithilye śaṅkāpi nyāyādāpatantī kena pratihanyate /
analyzed: sati ca vyāpti śaithilye śaṅkā api nyāyāt āpatantī kena pratihanyate
translated: And when there is looseness of pervasion, how can the doubt arising from reasoning be obstructed by anyone?

analyzed: ulūka ādīnām bhinna jātīya tvāt āloka abhāve pi artha sākṣātkāri tvam astu iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the owls and others have a different species, so they may have the ability to perceive objects even in the absence of light,

analyzed: tarhi bhagavataḥ pi bhūta artha bhāvanā prakarṣa paryanta mahāpralaya vāyunā nirasta anādya vidyā vipakṣasya
translated: then even for the Lord, who has dispelled the beginningless ignorance opposed to the ultimate reality by the wind of great dissolution at the culmination of the practice of the true object,

analyzed: saṃsāra kūpa patitebhyaḥ prāṇibhyaḥ sti eva adbhuta vaijātyam iti yuktam asya avidyā pratipakṣa bhāvanā atiśaya sahita ātmaka anantara pratyayāt ālambana pratyayāt ca
translated: it is proper that there is a wonderful difference for the living beings fallen into the well of worldly existence. Thus, from the immediately preceding condition consisting of the self along with the excess of the practice opposed to ignorance, and from the objective condition,

analyzed: sākṣāt utpannasya indriyam antareṇa artha sākṣātkāri tvam
translated: it is proper that there is the ability to perceive objects without the sense organ, which arises directly.

original: ataḥ kāraṇānupalabdhiḥ kāśikākārasya vyāpakaviruddhopalabdhiśca vācaspateḥ sandigdhavyatirekitvādanaikāntikī /
analyzed: atas kāraṇa anupalabdhiḥ kāśika ākārasya vyāpaka viruddha upalabdhiḥ ca vācaspateḥ sandigdha vyatireki tvāt anaikāntikī
translated: Therefore, the non-apprehension of the cause by the author of the Kāśikā and the apprehension of the contradictory of the pervader by the lord of speech are inconclusive because of the doubtful negative concomitance.

analyzed: sandigdha vyatireki tvam tu dūṣaṇam asmat īśvara dūṣaṇe prasādhitam
translated: And the doubtful negative concomitance is a fault that has been established in our refutation of God.

analyzed: tasmāt sādhāraṇa karma nirjātānām asmat ādīnām artha sākṣātkāri tvam indriya apekṣa tvena vyāptam iti siddhasādhanam
translated: Therefore, it is an established fact that the capacity for perceiving objects belongs to us and others who are born of common actions, because it is pervaded by the dependence on sense organs.

original: prasiddhānumānasya ca na kṣatirdṛśyatvopādherdhūmādeḥ pratyakṣānupalambhato vyāptigrahaṇāvirodhāt /🔽sāṃsārikāgocarārthasākṣātkāritvamātrāpekṣayā tu sandigdhavyatirekitvam /
analyzed: prasiddha anumānasya ca na kṣatiḥ dṛśya tva upādheḥ dhūma ādeḥ pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ vyāpti grahaṇa avirodhāt  sāṃsārika agocara artha sākṣātkāri tva mātra apekṣayā tu sandigdha vyatireki tvam
translated: And there is no harm to the well-known inference, because the perception of the pervasion by smoke etc. which are the limiting conditions of visibility is not contradicted by the perception and non-apprehension.🔽But there is doubt about the negative pervasion in relation to the mere capacity for perceiving objects that are not in the domain of worldly experience.

analyzed: adṛśyasya pratyakṣa anupalambhābhyām kenacid vyāpti grahaṇa ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for anyone to apprehend the pervasion of the invisible by perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: viparyaye bādhaka pramāṇasya ca asaṃbhavāt iti
translated: And because there is no valid means of knowledge that contradicts the contrary.

original: na catīndriyadarśitvaṃ sarvajñatvaṃ vādarśane 'pi niṣeddhuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca atīndriya darśi tvam sarvajña tvam vā adarśane niṣeddhum śakyate
translated: And the omniscience of one who sees the imperceptible cannot be denied even in the absence of a doctrine.

analyzed: adṛśya anupalambhataḥ niṣedha ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible to deny it on the basis of the non-apprehension of the imperceptible.

analyzed: kāraṇa anupalambhataḥ tad niṣedhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it can be denied on the basis of the non-apprehension of the cause,

original: kāraṇābhāvo 'pi adarśanamātrato na sidhyatīti tadavasthaḥ paribhavaḥ //
analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvaḥ pi adarśana mātrataḥ na sidhyati iti tad avasthaḥ paribhavaḥ
translated: then the same difficulty remains, because the absence of the cause is not established merely on the basis of non-apprehension.

analyzed: yat api kāśikā ākāreṇa abhihitam  atha pramāṇa antara avagatam bhāvyate
translated: What was also stated by the author of the Kāśikā:🔽If what is apprehended by another means of knowledge is to be established,

analyzed: ki bhāvanayā
translated: is it to be established by that [means of knowledge]?

analyzed: tatas eva tad siddheḥ iti
translated: Because it is established by that [means of knowledge] itself.

analyzed: tat api asaṃgatam
translated: That also is irrelevant.

analyzed: pramāṇa antaram hi anumānam
translated: Inference is a different means of knowledge.

original: na ca caturāryasatyasvarūpe vastutattve niścite sākṣātkāramantareṇa kleśajñeyāvaraṇakṣatiriti svārthamapi tāvad bhāvanā yuktimatī /
analyzed: na ca catur ārya satya svarūpe vastu tattve niścite sākṣātkāram antareṇa kleśa jñeya āvaraṇa kṣatiḥ iti svārtham api tāvat bhāvanā yuktimatī
translated: And when the nature of the four noble truths, the reality of things, is ascertained, without direct perception there is no damage to the afflictions and the obscurations to knowledge. Thus, even for one's own sake, meditation is reasonable.

original: tattvasākṣātkāriṇi ca cittasantāne sati śakyasākṣātkriyamidamityanye 'pi niścayānantaraṃ sākṣātkriyāyai pravartyante /
analyzed: tattva sākṣātkāriṇi ca citta santāne sati śakya sākṣātkriyam idam iti anye niścaya anantaram sākṣātkriyāyai pravartyante
translated: And when the mind-stream has the direct realization of reality, others are also able to directly realize what is capable of being directly realized, and after ascertaining it, they engage in direct realization.

original: tadupadiṣṭa svargasādhanaṃ cārthabhāvanayānusarantīti svargāpavargalakṣaṇaparārthasiddhaye ca bhāvanā saphaleti /
analyzed: tad upadiṣṭa svarga sādhanam ca artha bhāvanayā anusaranti iti svarga apavarga lakṣaṇa para artha siddhaye ca bhāvanā saphalā iti
translated: And they follow the means of attaining heaven taught by him through the contemplation of the object. Thus, meditation is fruitful for the accomplishment of the ultimate goal characterized by heaven and liberation.

original: anyathā tattvāsākṣātkāriṇo lokānatikrāntasya vacanamanādeyameva syāditi kva parārthavārtāpi /
analyzed: anyathā tattva asākṣātkāriṇaḥ loka anatikrāntasya vacanam anādeyam eva syāt iti kva parārtha vārtā api
translated: Otherwise, the words of one who has not transcended the world and does not have the direct realization of reality would not be accepted at all. So where is the talk of the ultimate goal?

original: yacca kiṃ ca tatpramāṇamityādyārabhya tasmād bhūtamabhūtaṃ veti etatparyantena dharmādharmayoranumānāpravartanamuktam /
analyzed: yat ca kim ca tat pramāṇam ityādi ārabhya tasmāt bhūtam abhūtam vā iti etad paryantena dharma adharmayoḥ anumāna apravartanam uktam
translated: And what was said beginning with What is that means of knowledge? up to Therefore, it is either real or unreal, about the non-operation of inference regarding dharma and adharma,

analyzed: tatra dharma adharma śabdena kim abhipretam
translated: What is meant by the terms dharma and adharma there?

analyzed: yadi kṣaṇika nirātmaka vastu tattvam
translated: If it is the reality of momentary and selfless entities,

original: tadā tasya pratyakṣeṇāniścaye 'pi yathā viparyaye bādhakapramāṇabalena vyāptisaṃvedanaṃ tathā kṣaṇabhaṅgasādhanāvasare vyavasthāpitam /
analyzed: tadā tasya pratyakṣeṇa aniścaye yathā viparyaye bādhaka pramāṇa balena vyāpti saṃvedanam tathā kṣaṇa bhaṅga sādhana avasare vyavasthāpitam
translated: Then, even though there is no ascertainment by direct perception, just as the cognition of the pervasion by the power of the contradictory valid cognition in the case of the opposite, so it has been established in the context of proving momentariness.

analyzed: atha vastūnām svarga ādi sādhana tvam abhipretam
translated: Or if the means of attaining heaven and so on are intended for things,

analyzed: tadā tad viṣaya parijñāna a prasādhane na asmākam kācid kṣatiḥ
translated: then even if the knowledge of that is not established, there is no harm to us at all.

analyzed: sa parikara saṃsāra nirvāṇa parijñānena eva upayukta sarvajña prasādhanāt yat āhuḥ
translated: Because the omniscience of the one who is useful is established by the knowledge of the world with its retinue and nirvana. As they say:

analyzed: heya upādeya tattvasya ityādi
translated: Of the reality that is to be abandoned and accepted... and so on.

analyzed: yat api api ca bhāvanā bala jam gṛhīta grahaṇāt apramāṇam iti uktam
translated: And what is said: It is not a valid means of knowledge because it grasps what has already been grasped, which arises from the power of meditation.

analyzed: tatra gṛhītam nāma pratyakṣeṇa anumānena vā
translated: There, what has been grasped is either by perception or by inference.

analyzed: pramāṇa antarasya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no other valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: na tāvat pratyakṣam kṣaṇika tva ādau arvācīnasya
translated: To begin with, there is no perception of momentariness, etc. for one who is a beginner.

analyzed: nibandh kasyacid asti
translated: There is no connection with anything.

original: anumānena caikavyāvṛttiviśiṣṭe vastutattve 'vasite 'pi sarvātmanā spaṣṭavastutattvasākṣātkāri pratyakṣaṃ na gṛhītagrāhi /
analyzed: anumānena ca eka vyāvṛtti viśiṣṭe vastu tattve vasite sarva ātmanā spaṣṭa vastu tattva sākṣātkāri pratyakṣam na gṛhīta grāhi
translated: And even if the reality of things distinguished by the exclusion of one [thing] is ascertained by inference, perception which clearly and completely cognizes the reality of things is not a grasper of what has already been grasped.

analyzed: anumānena vastu tattva asparśanāt
translated: Because inference does not touch the reality of things.

original: na ca taduttarakālamityādi tu kāraṇānupalabdhidūṣaṇaprastāve prativyūḍhamiti /
analyzed: na ca tad uttara kālam ityādi tu kāraṇa anupalabdhi dūṣaṇa prastāve prativyūḍham iti
translated: And the statement beginning with And not after that has been refuted in the context of refuting the non-apprehension of a cause.

original: yadapi vācaspatinā satyamityādinā punaḥ punaruttarottaramāśaṅkaya tat kimanumānena vahni vyavasthāpyetyādinā bhāvanābalajasyānumānapūrvakatve
analyzed: yat api vācaspatinā satyam ityādinā punar punar uttarottaram āśaṅkaya tat kim anumānena vahni vyavasthāpya ityādinā bhāvanā bala jasya anumāna pūrvaka tve
translated: And what has been repeatedly suspected by Vācaspati with the words True, etc. and then with So what is the use of inference to establish fire, etc. in the case of the cognition arising from the power of meditation being preceded by inference,

analyzed: tat na bhāvanāyāḥ bhūta artha tvam tad ja viśada vijñāna prāmāṇya hetuḥ
translated: that is not the case. The reality of the object is not the cause of the validity of the clear cognition born from it.

analyzed: vyabhicārāt iti
translated: Because of deviation.

analyzed: tat asaṅgatam
translated: That is irrelevant.

original: tathā hyayaṃ vahniviṣayenumānapūrvakabhāvanābalataḥ spaṣṭavahnipratyayaḥ kiṃ vahnerapyutpannaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi ayam vahni viṣaya inumāna pūrvaka bhāvanā balataḥ spaṣṭa vahni pratyayaḥ kim vahneḥ api utpannaḥ
translated: For, in this case, is the clear cognition of fire born from the power of meditation preceded by inference with regard to fire, or is it born from the mere meditation of that kind?

analyzed: tathābhūta bhāvanā mātrāt eva vā
translated: Or is it born from the object itself?

original: prathamapakṣe visaṃvādaśca bahulamupalabhyate iti yaduktaṃ taddurbhāṣitam /
analyzed: prathama pakṣe visaṃvādaḥ ca bahulam upalabhyate iti yat uktam tat durbhāṣitam
translated: If it is the first hypothesis, then what has been said - that contradiction is often observed - is ill-spoken.

analyzed: sākṣāt arthāt utpannasya api visaṃvāda saṃbhave nyasya api pratyakṣasya hastaka tyāga prasaṅgāt
translated: Because even if it is born directly from the object, contradiction is possible, and it would lead to the abandonment of the hand of any other perception.

analyzed: dvitīya pakṣe tu bhāvanā prakarṣa mātra jasya arthāt anutpannasya bahulam visaṃvāda upalambhe
translated: But if it is the second hypothesis, then in the case of the cognition born from the mere intensity of meditation, which is not born from the object, the observation of contradiction is often.

original: 'pi bhāvanārthābhyāṃ sākṣādutpannasya yogipratyakṣasyāpi visaṃvādasaṃbhava iti sthavīyasī bhrāntiḥ /
analyzed: pi bhāvanā arthābhyām sākṣāt utpannasya yogi pratyakṣasya api visaṃvāda saṃbhavaḥ iti sthavīyasī bhrāntiḥ
translated: Even for the yogic perception that arises directly from the means of knowing existence and purpose, there is a possibility of contradiction, so the error is grave.

analyzed: nanu yadi indriyam vinā api bhāvanā arthābhyām yogi jñānam utpadyate
translated: If, indeed, the knowledge of a yogi arises from existence and purpose without the senses,

analyzed: tarhi parvate bhāvanā vahnibhyām vahni jñānam utpadyatām avisaṃvādi
translated: then let the knowledge of fire arise from existence and fire on a mountain, without contradiction.

analyzed: visaṃvādaḥ ca bahulam upalabhyate iti ced na
translated: And if it is said that contradiction is often observed, no.

analyzed: sākṣāt vahneḥ utpāde sati visaṃvāda abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction when fire is produced directly.

analyzed: kevalamutpādaḥ eva durāpaḥ
translated: It is only the production that is difficult to attain.

original: na hi vayaṃ pramāṇadṛṣṭavastubhāvanāsahitaṃ manaindriyamarthasvarūpagrāhijñānaṃ janayatīti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: na hi vayam pramāṇa dṛṣṭa vastu bhāvanā sahitam manā indriyam artha svarūpa grāhi jñānam janayati iti brūmaḥ
translated: For we do not say that the mental sense organ, accompanied by the meditation on a thing seen by a means of valid knowledge, produces a cognition that grasps the form of the object.

analyzed: api tu asat dṛṣṭi lakṣaṇa avidyā paripanthi kṣaṇika nairātmya lakṣaṇa sarva vastu tattva bhāvanā sahitam
translated: But rather, it is accompanied by the meditation on the truth of all things, which has the characteristic of momentariness and non-self, and which is the antidote to the ignorance characterized by the perception of what is not.

analyzed: na ca vahni tvam sarva vastu tattvam
translated: And fireness is not the truth of all things.

analyzed: kim tu kṣaṇika nairātmyam eva iti kṣaṇa bhaṅga prasādhanataḥ pratipāditam iti
translated: But rather, it is momentariness and non-self alone. Thus it has been taught through the proof of momentariness.

analyzed: kim ca sva manīṣā parikalpitaḥ khalu ayam anuimita bhāvita vahni viṣaya viśadaḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: Moreover, this clear cognition of fire, which is the object of repeated meditation, is indeed imagined by one's own intellect.

analyzed: na punar asya loke saṃbhavaḥ
translated: It does not exist in the world.

analyzed: tathā hi niṣprayojanam anunmattaḥ na kaścid bhāvayati
translated: For thus, no sane person would meditate on it without a purpose.

analyzed: prayojanam ca śiśira bhara manthara kāya kāṇḍasya api dāha ādi mātram eva
translated: And the purpose is merely the removal of cold, etc. for one whose body and limbs are sluggish with cold.

analyzed: tat ca anumitena eva vahninā tad deśa upasarpaṇāt sidhyati
translated: And that is accomplished by the inferred fire itself through approaching that place.

original: anupasarpaṇe bhāvanāvaiyarthyam /🔽purastāttu bhāvite parisphurati tadarthāpekṣayā bhrāntiḥ prāsarpakasyevetyādyupahāsyamapyasya kṣatātmano durnītipūtigavībhakṣaṇādhmātajaradgomāyorudgāra
analyzed: an upasarpaṇe bhāvanā vaiyarthyam  purastāt tu bhāvite parisphurati tad artha apekṣayā bhrāntiḥ prāsarpakasya iva ityādi upahāsyam api asya kṣata ātmanaḥ durnīti pūti gavī bhakṣaṇa ādhmāta jarat gomāyoḥ udgāra
translated: If it does not approach, the meditation is useless.

analyzed: iva satām asahyaḥ
translated: But when it is meditated upon before, it appears due to the dependence on that object. The error is like that of one who crawls. Thus, even this contemptible one, with a wounded self, is unbearable to the good, like the belch of an old jackal inflated by eating rotten cow meat due to bad conduct.

analyzed: yat api tatas nantaram āśaṅkayā arthasya ālambana pratyaya tvam indriya apekṣi tvena vyāptam iti prasādhitam
translated: What was also suspected after that and established as the pervasion of the object being the objective condition by depending on the sense faculty,

analyzed: tat pūrvam eva pratyuktam
translated: that was already refuted earlier.

analyzed: tathā bhāvanāyāḥ ca ityādi āśaṅkayā arthasya ālambana pratyaya tvam aśakya avagamam iti yat uktam tat api asambaddham
translated: Similarly, the doubt that has been raised regarding the object being the causal condition of mental perception, and the statement that it is not possible to understand the object as the causal condition of mental perception, is also irrelevant.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ indriyasya api artham antareṇa dvi candra keśoṇḍuka ādau viśada bhrānta jñāna janana sāmarthyam upalabdham iti artha sahitam api kevalam eva samartham
translated: The eye sense faculty is also observed to have the ability to generate clear erroneous knowledge in the absence of an object, such as in the perception of two moons or floaters. Therefore, even when accompanied by an object, it is only capable by itself.

original: ato ghaṭāderapyālambanapratyayatvamaśakyāvagamamiti indriyapratyakṣamapi pratihataṃ syāditi / tathā / api
analyzed: atas ghaṭa ādeḥ api ālambana pratyaya tvam aśakya avagamam iti indriya pratyakṣam api pratihatam syāt iti tathā api
translated: Therefore, it would be impossible to understand even a pot as the causal condition of mental perception, and sense perception would also be obstructed. Similarly,

original: Nibandh cālambanapratyayā api ta eva yujyanta ityādirna punarvikalpanirmāṇapratibandhateti paryanto vyarthaḥ /
analyzed: ca ālambana pratyayāḥ api te eva yujyante ityādiḥ na punar vikalpa nirmāṇa pratibandha tā iti paryantaḥ vyarthaḥ
translated: the statement beginning with And it is reasonable that those very [sense faculties] are the causal conditions of mental perception and ending with but not the obstruction of the construction of conceptualization is pointless.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ evaṃvidhasya prastute na abhyupagata tvāt
translated: Because we do not accept such a kind of [mental perception] in the present [discussion].

analyzed: atas eva tasmāt bhāvanā prakarṣa mātra ja tvāt
translated: For this very reason, because it arises merely from the culmination of meditation,

analyzed: artha avyabhicāra niyama abhāvāt  viśada ābham api saṃśaya ākrānta tvāt
translated: there is no restriction on the non-deviation of the object.🔽Even the clear appearance is not a valid cognition because it is overridden by doubt.

analyzed: apramāṇam apratyakṣam ca iti dhikkāraḥ
translated: The conclusion that it is not a valid cognition and is not perception is also a condemnation.

analyzed: sarveṣām eva hetūnām asiddha tvāt
translated: Because all the reasons are unestablished.

analyzed: bhāvanā bala jasya arthāt api utpatteḥ indriya pratyakṣa vat
translated: Because it arises from the power of cultivation, like sense perception.

analyzed: sat artha prakāśanam buddheḥ svabhāvaḥ ityādi asmākam api manoharam
translated: The manifestation of a real object is the nature of cognition, this is pleasing to us also.

analyzed: bhāvanāyāḥ ca sāmānyena sphuṭa ābha jñāna hetu tvam sādhyate
translated: And the cause of the clear manifestation of knowledge is generally established as the cause of cultivation.

analyzed: pramāṇa upapanna catur ārya satya viṣaya niṣṭhāyām tu sāmarthyāt pratyakṣa pramāṇa hetu tā api sādhyate
translated: But in the case of the four noble truths, which are the object of valid cognition, the cause of valid cognition is established by implication.

original: ata eva kāminīpratibhāsasyāpramāṇatve 'pyapratyakṣatve 'pi sphuṭābhatvasya sādhyadharmasāmānyasya saṃbhavāt na viruddho hetuḥ /
analyzed: atas eva kāminī pratibhāsasya apramāṇa tve pi apratyakṣa tve pi sphuṭa ābha tvasya sādhya dharma sāmānyasya saṃbhavāt na viruddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: For this very reason, even though the appearance of a lover is not a valid cognition, and is not sense perception, the general property of clear manifestation to be proved is possible, so the reason is not contradictory.

analyzed: nā api dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya śūnya tā iti
translated: And the example is not devoid of the property to be proved.

analyzed: na ca nairātmya dṛṣṭiḥ saṃbhavat bādhā
translated: And the view of selflessness is not possible when there is an obstruction.

analyzed: arthāt utpatteḥ abhūta artha tva abhāvāt
translated: Because it arises from the object, it is not unreal.

analyzed: śruta anumita viṣayam pratyakṣam na saṃbhavatā iti api ayuktam
translated: It is also incorrect to say that sense perception is not possible with regard to the object of inference and scripture.

analyzed: āgama anumānayoḥ dvividhaḥ viṣayaḥ grāhyaḥ dhyavaseyaḥ ca
translated: The object of scripture and inference is twofold: to be grasped and to be determined.

analyzed: tatra grāhyaḥ su ākāraḥ
translated: There, the object to be grasped is one's own form.

analyzed: adhyavaseyaḥ tu pāramārthika vastu sva lakṣaṇa ātmā  asya ca parokṣa tve numāna sāmagrī saṃbhave numāna viṣaya tvam
translated: But the object to be ascertained is of the nature of the particular characteristic of the ultimately real entity.🔽And when it is imperceptible and the conditions for inference are present, it becomes the object of inference.

analyzed: pratyakṣa sāmagrī saṃbhave ca krameṇa pratyakṣa viṣaya tvam dṛṣṭam eva
translated: And when the conditions for perception are present, it is seen to be the object of perception in due order.

analyzed: tat siddham ityādi upasaṃhāraḥ pi paryākulaḥ eva
translated: The conclusion beginning with that is established is also confused.

analyzed: apramāṇa tvāt iti hetuḥ ca siddhaḥ  bhāvanā bala jasya arthāt api utpatteḥ
translated: And the reason because it is not a means of valid knowledge is the first one, which is unestablished.🔽Because it arises from the object produced by the power of meditation.

analyzed: pramāṇa śakti saṃbhavāt
translated: Because the power of a means of valid knowledge is possible.

analyzed: indriya pratyakṣa vat
translated: Like sense perception.

analyzed: bhāvanā bala ja tvāt iti dvitīyaḥ tu sandigdha vyatireki tvāt anaikāntikaḥ
translated: But the second one, because it is produced by the power of meditation, is inconclusive because of doubtful exclusion.

analyzed: tathā yathā anumita bhāvita vahni viṣaya viśada jñānam iti dṛṣṭāntaḥ u pi asaṃbhavi iti pratipāditam
translated: It has also been shown that the example, like the clear knowledge of fire which is meditated upon in accordance with inference, is impossible.

original: bhavatu vā / tathāpi yogijñānasya tena saha tulyahetutvamasiddham /
analyzed: bhavatu vā tathā api yogi jñānasya tena saha tulya hetu tvam asiddham
translated: Let it be so. Even then, it is not established that the knowledge of a yogi has the same cause as that.

analyzed: tat hi pramāṇa dṛṣṭa vastu bhāvanā mātra jam
translated: For that arises merely from the meditation on the object seen by a means of valid knowledge.

original: yogijñānaṃ tu avidyāpratipakṣasarvavastutattvabhāvanāviṣayābhyāmutpannamiti mahāntamapi viśeṣamasau durmatiprapātapatito nāvagāhata ityupekṣaṇīyaḥ
analyzed: yogi jñānam tu avidyā pratipakṣa sarva vastu tattva bhāvanā viṣayābhyām utpannam iti mahāntam api viśeṣam asau durmati prapāta patitaḥ na avagāhate iti upekṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: But the knowledge of the yogin arises from the cultivation of the truth of all things, which is the antidote to ignorance. Therefore, that [knowledge of the yogin] does not penetrate even a great difference. He who has fallen into the abyss of bad thoughts should be disregarded.

original: nyāyaprakīrṇe tu mārgastāvat pramāṇapariśuddho na bhavatītyuktaṃ yat /
analyzed: nyāya prakīrṇe tu mārgaḥ tāvat pramāṇa pariśuddhaḥ na bhavati iti uktam yat
translated: But in the Nyāyaprakiṛṇa, it is said that the path is not purified by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tat tad prasādhaka pramāṇena eva pratyuktam
translated: That [argument] has been refuted by the very valid means of knowledge that establishes [the path].

original: yaccāpi cetyādyārabhya yogijñānaṃ nirviṣayaṃ prasaktamityuktam tatra keyaṃ nirviṣayatā nāma /🔽kiṃ vikalpākāranivṛttau nirākāratā /
analyzed: yat ca api ca ityādi ārabhya yogi jñānam nirviṣayam prasaktam iti uktam tatra kā iyam nirviṣaya tā nāma  kim vikalpa ākāra nivṛttau nirākāra tā
translated: And what is begun with And what is... and so on, it is said that the knowledge of the yogin is devoid of an object. What is this so-called absence of an object?🔽Is it the absence of a form when the conceptual form ceases?

analyzed: artha ākārāt visadṛśa ākāra tā
translated: Is it a form that is different from the form of the object?

analyzed: atha tad ākāra tve tad vastu saṃsparśi tā
translated: Or, even if it has that form, is it not in contact with that thing?

analyzed: na tāvat prathamaḥ pakṣaḥ kṣamaḥ
translated: First, that position is not acceptable.

analyzed: jñānasya nirākāra tā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for knowledge to be without form.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor is the second [position].

analyzed: kāminī ādi bhāvanāyāḥ tad ākārasya eva viśadasya darśanāt
translated: Because the vivid form of the meditation on the beloved woman and so on is seen to have that form.

analyzed: na ca tṛtīyaḥ
translated: And not the third [position].

analyzed: artha samarpita ākāra saṃsparśam apāsya anyasya artha saṃsparśasya ayogāt
translated: Because apart from the contact with the form conveyed by the object, another contact with the object is not possible.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And thus it is said:

analyzed: arthena ghaṭayati enām ityādi
translated: As stated by he connects it with the object and so on.

analyzed: tayoḥ ca eka tvena adhyavasāyāt bāhye eva pravṛtti nivṛttī
translated: And because of the ascertainment of those two as one, engagement and disengagement occur only externally.

original: vyāvahārikasya sphuṭībhāvo 'pi bahirabhimatasya paryante vikalpopādeyakṣaṇasyaiva sphuṭasyodayaḥ /
analyzed: vyāvahārikasya bahis abhimatasya paryante vikalpa upādeya kṣaṇasya eva sphuṭasya udayaḥ
translated: The manifestation of the conventional is also the arising of the clear momentary object to be accepted by the conceptual cognition at the end of what is externally intended.

analyzed: tāvatā eva sa
translated: To that extent,

original: Nibandh viṣayastena sākṣātkṛta iti vyavahāraḥ kevalamarthādapyutpattau /
translated: the convention is that the object is directly realized by him only if it arises even from the object.

original: anyathā vyabhicārādaprāmāṇyam /🔽na ca vikalpopadarśitamapiḥ rūpamavastu jñānātmakatvāt /
analyzed: anyathā vyabhicārāt aprāmāṇyam  na ca vikalpa upadarśitam apiḥ rūpam avastu jñāna ātmaka tvāt
translated: Otherwise, due to deviation, it would be invalid.🔽And the form shown by conceptual cognition is not a non-entity, because it is of the nature of cognition.

analyzed: anātmaka tve prakāśa ayogāt

analyzed: yasya hi avikala kāraṇasya bhavataḥ yad sannidhānāt abhāvaḥ tayoḥ eva saha anavasthāna lakṣaṇaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: For two things are said to be mutually exclusive when the presence of one is invariably absent in the presence of the other.

original: na ca sarvajñatvaṃ prāk pravṛttamavikalakāraṇaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yena paścājjñeyatvādisadbhāve nivartata iti syāt /
analyzed: na ca sarvajñatvam prāk pravṛttam avikala kāraṇam dṛṣṭam yena paścāt jñeya tva ādi sadbhāve nivartate iti syāt
translated: But omniscience, whose cause is not deficient, is not seen to occur before, which would later cease upon the presence of knowability, etc.

original: tathātve sati deśādiniṣedya eva bhavenna tu sarvathoccheda iti /
analyzed: tathātve sati deśa ādi niṣedyaḥ eva bhavet na tu sarvathā ucchedaḥ iti
translated: If it were so, it would be negated only in certain places, etc., but not completely annihilated.

analyzed: na ca paramparayā virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no indirect contradiction.

original: sa hi bhavan niṣedhyasya sarvajñatvasya vyāpakaviruddhatvāt /🔽kāraṇaviruddhatvāt /
analyzed: sa hi bhavat niṣedhyasya sarvajña tvasya vyāpaka viruddha tvāt  kāraṇa viruddha tvāt
translated: Because that [non-existence] is contradictory to the pervader of what is to be negated, omniscience.🔽Because it is contradictory to the cause.

analyzed: kārya viruddha tvāt  svabhāva viruddha kārya tvāt
translated: Because it is contradictory to the effect.🔽Because it has an effect that is contradictory to its nature.

analyzed: kāraṇa viruddha kārya tvāt
translated: Because it has an effect that is contradictory to the pervader.🔽Because it has an effect that is contradictory to the cause.

analyzed: kārya viruddha kārya tvāt  svabhāva viruddha vyāpta tvāt
translated: Because it has an effect that is contradictory to the effect.🔽Because it is pervaded by what is contradictory to its nature.

analyzed: vyāpaka viruddha vyāpta tvāt  kāraṇa viruddha vyāpta tvāt
translated: Because it is pervaded by what is contradictory to the pervader.🔽Because it is pervaded by what is contradictory to the cause.

analyzed: kārya viruddha vyāpta tvāt vā bhavet
translated: Or because it is pervaded by what is contradictory to the effect.

analyzed: tatra sarvajña tvasya asattvāt
translated: There, because omniscience does not exist,

analyzed: vyāpaka kāraṇa kāryāṇām asiddheḥ tad viruddha kārya vyāpya abhāvāt na prameya tva ādayaḥ sarvajña tvena paramparayā api viruddhāḥ
translated: and because the pervader, cause, and effect are not established, the absence of the effect and pervaded that are contradictory to them does not make knowability, etc. contradictory to omniscience even indirectly.

analyzed: nanu vaktṛ tvam virudhyate eva sarva viṣaya nirvikalpa jñāna viruddha vikalpa kārya tvāt vaktṛ tvasya
translated: But isn't speech itself contradictory, because speech is the effect of conceptualization, which is contradictory to non-conceptual knowledge of all objects?

analyzed: na etat yuktam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: sa vikalpa avikalpayoḥ yugapad avṛtteḥ vikalpaka tvena sarvajñasya avirodhāt
translated: Because conceptual and non-conceptual do not occur simultaneously, there is no contradiction to the omniscient one being conceptual.

analyzed: kaḥ tarhi pṛthagjanāt asya bhedaḥ iti ced
translated: Then what is the difference between this [omniscient one] and an ordinary person?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: yathā māyākāro nirmitāśvādiviṣayaṃ vijñānaṃ nirviṣayatvena niścinvannabhrāntaḥ /
analyzed: yathā māyākāraḥ nirmita aśva ādi viṣayam vijñānam nirviṣaya tvena niścinvan abhrāntaḥ
translated: Just as a magician, while ascertaining the consciousness of a horse etc. created by himself as devoid of an object, is not deluded.

analyzed: tad anyasmāt ca śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: And he is superior to others.

original: tathā bhagavānapi śuddhalaukikavikalpasammukhībhāve 'pi na bhrānto nāpi pṛthagjanasamāna iti /
analyzed: tathā bhagavān api śuddha laukika vikalpa sammukhībhāve pi na bhrāntaḥ na api pṛthagjana samānaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, the Blessed One, even when manifesting pure worldly conceptualization, is not deluded, nor is he the same as ordinary people.

analyzed: tatas ca nirvikalpaka sarvajña jñāna vikalpayoḥ virodha abhāvāt vaktṛ tvam sarvajña tvena saha aviruddham eva
translated: And therefore, because there is no contradiction between the non-conceptual omniscient knowledge and conceptualization, the state of being a speaker is not contradictory with omniscience.

analyzed: nirastam yat āha kāśikākāraḥ
translated: By this, this is also refuted, which the author of the Kāśikā said:

analyzed: samādheḥ vyutthāya upadekṣyate iti ced na
translated: If it is said that he will teach after rising from concentration, no.

analyzed: vyutthitasya hi abhilāpinī pratīti bhrānta bhāṣitam apramāṇam bhavet iti
translated: For the one who has risen would have a deluded speech, a conceptual cognition, which would not be a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: yat api uktam bṛhaṭṭīkāyām  yadā ca upadiśet ekam kiñcid sāmānya vaktṛ vat
translated: And what was also said in the Bṛhatī commentary:🔽And when he would teach one thing, like an ordinary speaker,

analyzed: eka deśa jña gītam tat na syāt sarvajña bhāṣitam
translated: That which is sung by one who knows only a part would not be the speech of the Omniscient One.

analyzed: tat api nirastam
translated: That too is refuted.

original: vikalpenaikasya kasyacidāmukhīkṛtvopadeśe 'pi nirvikalpena sarvamavabudhyamānasya vacanānāṃ sarvajñabhāṣitatvādeva //
analyzed: vikalpena ekasya kasyacid ā mukhīkṛtvā upadeśe nirvikalpena sarvam avabudhyamānasya vacanānām sarvajña bhāṣita tvāt eva
translated: Even when teaching by manifesting one thing through conceptualization, since he who understands everything through non-conceptualization is speaking, the words are indeed the speech of the Omniscient One.

analyzed: yat punar kārikāyām uktam
translated: What is said again in the Kārikā:

analyzed: sānnidhya mātrataḥ tasya puṃsaḥ cintāmaṇeḥ iva
translated: By the mere presence of that person, like a wish-fulfilling gem,

analyzed: niścaranti yathākāmam deśanāḥ
translated: Instructions emerge as desired, even from walls and so on.

analyzed: evamādi ucyamānam hi śraddadhānasya śobhate
translated: When this and other such statements are made, they are indeed beautiful for the faithful.

analyzed: kuḍya ādi niḥsṛta tvāt tu na āśvāsaḥ deśanāsu naḥ
translated: But because they emerge from walls and so on, we have no confidence in those instructions.

analyzed: kinnu buddha praṇotāḥ syuḥ kiṃvā kaiścid durātmabhiḥ
translated: Are they perhaps inspired by the Buddha, or are they proclaimed by some evil beings,

analyzed: adṛśyaiḥ vipralambha artha piśāca ādibhiḥ īritāḥ
translated: Invisible demons and others, for the purpose of deception?

analyzed: bṛhaṭṭīkāyām api
translated: In the Brhattika it is also said:

analyzed: tasmin dhyāna samādhi sthe cintā ratna vat āsthite
translated: When he abides in meditation and concentration, like a wish-fulfilling gem,

analyzed: niścaranti yathākāmam deśanāḥ
translated: Instructions emerge as desired, even from walls and so on.

analyzed: tābhiḥ jijñāsita anarthān sarvān jānanti mānavāḥ
translated: By those, people know all the desired objects of inquiry,

analyzed: hitāni ca yathāyogam kṣipram āsādayanti te
translated: And they quickly obtain the benefits as appropriate.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Nibandha

analyzed: ityādi kīrtamānam tu śraddadhānasya śobhate
translated: When this and other such statements are made, they are indeed beautiful for the faithful.

analyzed: vayam aśraddadhānāḥ tu ye yuktīḥ arthayāmahe
translated: But we are the unbelievers who seek logical reasons.

analyzed: kuḍya ādi niḥsṛtānām ca na syāt āpta upadiṣṭa tā
translated: And the instructions emerging from walls and so on would not be taught by a reliable person,

original: viśvāsaśca na tāsu syātkenaitāḥ kīrtitā iti //
analyzed: viśvāsaḥ ca na tāsu syāt kena etāḥ kīrtitāḥ iti
translated: And there would be no confidence in them, wondering by whom they were proclaimed.

original: kinnu buddhapraṇītāḥ syuḥ kiṃ vā brāhyaṇavañcakaiḥ /🔽krīḍadbhirupadiṣṭāḥ syurdūrasthapratiśabdakaiḥ //
analyzed: kinnu buddha praṇītāḥ syuḥ kim vā brāhyaṇa vañcakaiḥ  krīḍadbhiḥ upadiṣṭāḥ syuḥ dūra stha pratiśabdakaiḥ
translated: Are they taught by the Buddha, or by deceivers of the Brahmins,🔽or are they taught by those who play with echoes at a distance?

analyzed: kim vā kṣudra piśāca ādyaiḥ adṛṣṭaiḥ parikalpitāḥ
translated: Or are they imagined by unseen small demons and the like?

analyzed: tasmāt na tāsu viśvāsaḥ kartavyaḥ prājña mānibhiḥ
translated: Therefore, they should not be trusted by those who think themselves wise.

analyzed: etat api anabhyupagamena eva nirastam
translated: This is also refuted by simply not accepting it.

analyzed: śuddha laukika vikalpa saṃmukhībhāvena eva tasya deśaka tva abhyupagamāt iti
translated: Because it is accepted that it is taught by the mere appearance of pure worldly thoughts.

original: atha vā yathā cakrasyoparate 'pi daṇḍapreraṇāvyāpāre pūrvāvegavaśād bhramaṇam /
analyzed: atha vā yathā cakrasya uparate daṇḍa preraṇā vyāpāre pūrva āvega vaśāt bhramaṇam
translated: Or, just as a wheel continues to spin even after the operation of the stick that propelled it has ceased, due to its previous momentum,

original: evaṃ bhagavati pratyastamitasamastavikalpajāle 'pi sthite yadi pūrvapraṇidhānāhitasatatānābhogavāhinī deśanā syāttadā ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: evam bhagavati pratyasta mita samasta vikalpa jāle sthite yadi pūrva praṇidhāna āhita satata anābhoga vāhinī deśanā syāt tadā kaḥ virodhaḥ

analyzed: vacana mātrasya vivakṣayā vyāpteḥ abhāvāt

translated: Therefore, just as for one who is suddenly awakened by the enemy striking him etc. due to previous practice, the proper procedure of drawing out the weapon etc. is appropriate,

analyzed: tathā sarva vedinaḥ api sakalāḥ kalāḥ iti an ākulam
translated: in the same way, for one who knows everything, all the arts are not confused.

analyzed: yat āha alaṅkāraḥ  śatru sānnidhya mātreṇa pravartante vikalpataḥ
translated: As Alaṅkāra says:🔽Without any doubt, they proceed merely by the presence of the enemy.

analyzed: prāk eva tad nirākāri prakramāḥ kopa nirmitāḥ

original: yatpunaruktam piśācādikṛtaśaṅkayā nātrāśvāsaḥ satāṃ yukta iti /

translated: As for what was said - that out of fear of ghosts etc., it is not proper for the good to have confidence here -

analyzed: tat asaṅgatam yatas
translated: that is irrelevant. Because

analyzed: saṃbhinna ālāpa hiṃsā ādi kutsita artha upadarśanam
translated: The display of despicable meanings such as mixed speech and harm,

analyzed: krīḍā śīla piśāca ādeḥ kāryam tāsu na vidyate
translated: is not the function of playful ghosts etc. in those [texts].

analyzed: pramāṇa dvaya saṃvādi matam tad viṣaye khile
translated: The entire subject matter is accepted as consistent with the two means of valid knowledge,

analyzed: yasya bādhā pramāṇābhyām aṇīyasī api na īkṣate

analyzed: yathā atyanta parokṣe na pūrva apara bādhitam
translated: Just as in what is extremely hidden, the prior and posterior are not contradicted,🔽it is the instigator of all men due to the arising of compassion and other virtues.

analyzed: sarva anuśaya saṃdoha pratipakṣa abhidhāyakam
translated: It proclaims the antidote to the entire mass of latent tendencies,

analyzed: nirvāṇa nagara dṣvāra kapāṭa puṭa bhedanam
translated: it breaks open the sealed door of the city of nirvana.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

original: taccet krīḍanaśīlānāṃ rakṣasāṃ vā vaco bhavet /
analyzed: tat ced krīḍana śīlānām rakṣasām vā vacaḥ bhavet

analyzed: na ca nāmni vivādaḥ

analyzed: na ca nāma nivṛttau vastu nivartate

analyzed: pratyuta vedasya eva krīḍana śīla piśāca ādi praṇīta tvam yuktam saṃbhāvayitum
translated: Rather, it is appropriate to consider that the Veda itself was composed by playful demons and so on.

analyzed: yena go śava ādiṣu yogeṣu agamyā gamana ādayaḥ satya samudācārāḥ saṃprakāśitāḥ
translated: By whom, in the rituals such as the Gośava, the intercourse with a forbidden woman and so on, which are not in accordance with reality, are revealed.

analyzed: loka prasiddhiḥ ca
translated: And the popular belief

analyzed: trayaḥ vedasya kartāraḥ muni bhaṇḍa niśācarāḥ
translated: There are three authors of the Veda: sages, demons, and goblins.

analyzed: iti alam ati nirbandhena
translated: Enough of this excessive insistence.

analyzed: nanu sarvajña tvam vīta rāga di tvena vyāptam iṣyate
translated: But omniscience is accepted as pervaded by being free from passion and so on,

analyzed: tad viruddham ca rāga ādi yogitvam
translated: and that is contradicted by being associated with passion and so on,

analyzed: tad kāryam ca vacanam
translated: and speech is its effect.

original: tadetad vyāpakaviruddhakāryabhūtaṃ vacanaṃ sarvajñābhāvaṃ sādhayati paramparayā viruddhatvāditi cet / na /
analyzed: tat etat vyāpaka viruddha kārya bhūtam vacanam sarvajña abhāvam sādhayati paramparayā viruddha tvāt iti ced na
translated: That speech, which is the effect of the contradictory of the pervader, establishes the absence of omniscience of the opponent, by way of being contradictory in turn, if this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: rāga ādīnām vacasaḥ ca kārya kāraṇa bhāva asiddheḥ
translated: Because the relation of cause and effect between speech and passion and so on is not established.

analyzed: tathā hi vacana viśeṣaḥ rāga ādi kāryam
translated: For thus, a particular speech is the effect of passion and so on.

analyzed: yaḥ rāgeṇa eva janitaḥ

analyzed: vacana mātram vā
translated: Or it is mere speech.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat prathamaḥ pakṣaḥ

analyzed: tādṛśasya vacanasya niścaya upāya asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because there is no means of ascertaining such speech.

analyzed: asabhya maithuna ācāra prakāśakam vacanam tat kāryam iti ced na

analyzed: abhiprāyasya durlakṣya tvāt

analyzed: viraktaḥ rakta vat ceṣṭate

analyzed: virakta vat iti abhiprāyaḥ durbodhaḥ
translated: Even one who is attached acts like one who is detached. Such an intention is difficult to understand.

original: tataśca viśiṣṭavyavahārasya sāṃkaryeṇa na tatraikāntena rāgānumānaṃ yujyate /
analyzed: tatas ca viśiṣṭa vyavahārasya sāṃkaryeṇa na tatra ekāntena rāga anumānam yujyate
translated: And therefore, because the usage of the distinguished [person] is mixed up, it is not proper to infer attachment there with absolute certainty based on mere speech.

analyzed: na api vacana mātram rāga ādi kāryam
translated: Nor is mere speech the effect of attachment and so on.

original: asaṃmukhībhūtarāgādayo 'pi hi svābhimatadevatāstutividhāne mātrādigurujanasaṃbhāṣaṇādau ca vacanamātramuccārayantaḥ samupalabhyante /
analyzed: asaṃmukhībhūta rāga ādayaḥ api hi sva abhimata devatā stuti vidhāne mātra ādi guru jana saṃbhāṣaṇa ādau ca vacana mātram uccārayantaḥ samupalabhyante
translated: For even those who are not presently attached and so on are seen to utter mere speech when praising their own desired deity, when conversing with elders such as their father and so on, and so forth.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt  rāga ādi yogya tā tarhi vacasaḥ kāraṇam

analyzed: tayā vinā upala khaṇḍala ādau vacanasya adarśanāt iti ced na
translated: because speech is not seen in a piece of wood and so on without that, it is not so.

analyzed: karaṇa guṇa vaktu kāma te hi vacanasya hetuḥ

analyzed: tad abhāvāt eva upala khaṇḍala ādau nivartate

analyzed: na rāga ādi yogyatāyāḥ abhāvāt

original: yadi kāraṇaguṇādisakalatadanyakāraṇabhāve 'pi rāgādi yogyatābhāvānnotpadyate vacanamiti sidhyettasyāḥ kāraṇatvam /
analyzed: yadi kāraṇa guṇa ādi sakala tad anya kāraṇa bhāve pi rāga ādi yogyatā bhāvāt nā utpadyate vacanam iti sidhyet tasyāḥ kāraṇa tvam
translated: If it were established that speech does not arise due to the absence of the capacity for passion, etc. even when all other causes such as the qualities of the cause are present, then its causality would be established.

analyzed: upala khaṇḍala ādau tu vaktu kāma tā na asti
translated: But in a lump of clay, etc. there is no desire to express.

analyzed: tat katham tad kāraṇa tvam vacasām iti

analyzed: evam tarhi vaktu kāma tā eva rāgaḥ stu

analyzed: iṣṭa tvāt na kiñcid bādhitam syāt

analyzed: nāmni vivāda abhāvāt

translated: But in reality, they say passion is the mental clinging to a contaminated object, prompted by the view of permanent, blissful, self, and what belongs to the self.

analyzed: niṣpanna sarva sampatteḥ vivakṣā api na yujyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even for one who has attained all perfections, the desire to express is not appropriate,

analyzed: adoṣaḥ yam para artha tvāt vivakṣāyāḥ
translated: this is not a fault, because the desire to express is for the sake of others.

original: vītarāge 'rthāsaṅgābhāvāt kathaṃ parārthāpi pravṛttiriti cet / na /
analyzed: vīta rāge ṛtha āsaṅga abhāvāt katham parārthā api pravṛttiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how activity for the sake of others is possible when there is no attachment to objects for one free from passion, no [it is not possible].

analyzed: āsaṅgam antareṇa karuṇayā api pravṛtteḥ
translated: Because activity occurs even without attachment, through compassion.

analyzed: saḥ eva rāgaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that compassion itself is passion,

analyzed: iṣṭa tvāt adoṣaḥ
translated: The answer is that there is no fault, because it is desired.

analyzed: rāgasya tu svarūpam uktam
translated: But the nature of passion has been stated.

original: kāruṇikasyāpi niṣphalārambho na yukta iti cet / na /
analyzed: kāruṇikasya api niṣphala ārambhaḥ na yuktaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not proper for the compassionate one to undertake fruitless activity, it is not so.

analyzed: parārthasya eva phala tvāt
translated: Because the benefit of others itself is the fruit.

analyzed: iṣṭa lakṣaṇa tvāt phalasya iti yat kiñcid etat
translated: This is because the fruit has the characteristic of being desired. This is mere verbiage.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

translated: But how can compassion arise in that state of the Lord who is free from conceptualization?

analyzed: duḥkha vikalpa prabhavā hi karuṇā iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām anya tvena niścitam
translated: For compassion arises from the conceptualization of suffering. This is ascertained by positive and negative concomitance as being different.

original: tataśca kāraṇābhāvāt kathaṃ kāryasaṃbhava iti cet / na /🔽yathā kumbhakāranivṛttāvapi svasantānamātrabhāvinī ghaṭādisthitistathotthāpakavikalpābhāve 'pi samana
analyzed: tatas ca kāraṇa abhāvāt katham kārya saṃbhavaḥ iti ced na  yathā kumbhakāra nivṛttau api sva santāna mātra bhāvinī ghaṭa ādi sthitiḥ tathā utthāpaka vikalpa abhāve pi
translated: And then, how can the effect arise due to the absence of the cause? If it is argued thus, it is not so.

analyzed: ntara pratyaya balāt anālambana karuṇā pravṝtteḥ avārya tvāt
translated: Just as the existence of a pot, etc. arises from the mere continuum of one's own [mind] even when the potter has ceased, in the same way, even in the absence of the conceptualization that arouses [compassion], compassion arises without an object due to the power of the immediately preceding condition, because it is unobstructed.

analyzed: yat āhuḥ guravaḥ
translated: As the teachers say:

analyzed: sattā āropakṛtaḥ u pi bhāvana vaśāt kāṭhinyam āpat tathā
translated: Even though it is created by the superimposition of existence, by the power of cultivation it attains hardness,

analyzed: śaithilye yathā asya duḥkha hataye sāndraḥ tathā eva śramaḥ
translated: and even in laxity, the effort for the destruction of suffering is dense in the same way.

original: utpāde tu phalasya hetuniyamo no tu prabandhasthitau
analyzed: utpāde tu phalasya hetu niyamaḥ no tu prabandha sthitau
translated: But in the continuity of the effect, there is no restriction of the cause.

analyzed: tasmāt duḥkha dṛśaḥ kṣaye vilasat maitrī ādaye smai namaḥ
translated: Therefore, to him who shines with love etc. even in the destruction of the view of suffering, salutations.

analyzed: etena etat api nirastam yat āha kārikāyām

analyzed: rāga ādi rahite ca asmin nirvyāpāre vyavasthite
translated: And in him who is free from passion etc., who abides without activity,

analyzed: deśanā anya praṇītā eva syāt ṛte pratyavekṣaṇāt
translated: The teaching would be composed by another, except through investigation.

original: nanu yadi nāmaivaṃ vaktṛtvaṃ sarvajñatvena sahāviruddhaṃ dehendriyabuddhyādiyogitvaṃ tu viruddhameva /
analyzed: nanu yadi nāma evam vaktṛ tvam sarvajña tvena saha aviruddham deha indriya buddhi ādi yogitvam tu viruddham eva
translated: But if speaking is not contradictory with omniscience, the possession of body, senses, intellect etc. is indeed contradictory.

analyzed: sarvajña tā vyāpaka vīta rāga tva viruddha rāga ādi kāraṇa tvāt deha ādīnām
translated: Because the body etc. are the cause of passion etc., which is contradictory with being free from passion, which is the pervasion of omniscience.

analyzed: tatas ca pratiṣedhya vyāpaka viruddha kāraṇa upalambhāt sarvajña abhāvaḥ iti ced
translated: And then, due to the perception of the cause which is contradictory with the pervasion of the negated, there is the absence of omniscience. If this is argued,

analyzed: ucyate
translated: it is said:

original: dehādīnāṃ hetutve 'pi naiṣāṃ kevalānāṃ sahakārimātrāṇāmātmābhiniveśalakṣaṇopādānakāraṇavikalānāṃ rāgādijanakatvamityagamakā eva dehādayaḥ sarvajñābhāvasya
analyzed: deha ādīnām hetu tve pi na eṣām kevalānām sahakāri mātrāṇām ātma abhiniveśa lakṣaṇa upādānakāraṇa vikalānām rāga ādi janaka tvam iti agamakāḥ eva deha ādayaḥ sarvajña abhāvasya
translated: Even if the body etc. are the cause, these alone, which are only auxiliaries, lacking the material cause characterized by attachment to the self, do not generate passion etc. Therefore, the body etc. are indeed non-indicators of the absence of omniscience.

analyzed: tasmāt jñeya tva ādīnām api asāmarthyāt na sarvajña abhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, because of the ineffectiveness of being known and so on, the non-existence of the Omniscient One is not established even by inference imagined by others.

analyzed: nā api sva vikalpitam śābda ādikam bhagavataḥ bādhakam
translated: Nor is the Lord contradicted by the verbal and other [means of knowledge] imagined by ourselves.

original: tathā hi yadyapi teṣāṃ sati prāmāṇye 'numāna evāntarbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi yadi api teṣām sati prāmāṇye numāne eva antarbhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, although if they are valid, they are included only in inference,

original: anantarbhāve cāprāmāṇyameveti sthūlaṃ dūṣaṇamasti /🔽tathāpi tatprāmāṇyamabhyupagamyāpi brūmaḥ /
analyzed: anantarbhāve ca aprāmāṇyam evā iti sthūlam dūṣaṇam asti  tathā api tad prāmāṇyam abhyupagamya api brūmaḥ
translated: and if they are not included, they are invalid, there is a gross fault.🔽Nevertheless, even accepting their validity, we say:

analyzed: yat tāvat pauruṣeya vacanam tat apramāṇam eva bhavatām
translated: As for the human statement, it is not a means of knowledge for you.

original: na ca vaidikaṃ kiñcidvacanaṃ sarvanarāsarvajñatvapratipādaka mupalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca vaidikam kiñcid vacanam sarva nara asarvajña tva pratipādaka m upalabhyate
translated: And no Vedic statement is found that teaches that all men are not omniscient.

original: pratyuta nimittanāmni śākhāntare sphuṭatarameva sarvajñaḥ pratipāditaḥ / tathā hi
analyzed: pratyuta nimitta nāmni śākhā antare sphuṭataram eva sarvajñaḥ pratipāditaḥ tathā hi
translated: On the contrary, in the Nimiṣa branch, the Omniscient One is taught even more clearly. Thus:

original: sa vetti viśvaṃ na ca tasya vettā
analyzed: sa vetti viśvam na ca tasya vettā
translated: He knows the universe, and there is no knower of Him.

analyzed: ityādinā ca sarvajñaḥ vede pratipāditaḥ
translated: And so on, the Omniscient One is taught in the Veda.

analyzed: na api upamānāt tad abhāvaḥ sidhyati
translated: Nor is His non-existence established by analogy.

original: tathā hi smaryamāṇameva gavādivastu purovartigavayādisādṛśyopādhi gavādyupādhi vā sādṛśyamupamānena pratīyata iti sthitiḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi smaryamāṇam eva gavādi vastu purovarti gavaya ādi sādṛśya upādhi gavādi upādhi vā sādṛśyam upamānena pratīyate iti sthitiḥ
translated: For it is well known that the object remembered, such as a cow, is cognized by analogy as similar to the cow in front, or as similar to the cow as the qualifier, or as qualified by the cow.

original: na ca sarvajñasantānavartīni cetāṃsi kenacit sarvajñenānubhūtāni yataḥ smaraṇena viṣayīkriyeran /
analyzed: na ca sarvajña santāna vartīni cetāṃsi kenacid sarvajñena anubhūtāni yatas smaraṇena viṣayīkriyeran
translated: And the minds occurring in the continuum of the omniscient one have not been experienced by anyone omniscient, from which they could be made the object of recollection.

analyzed: para citta vitteḥ ayogāt
translated: Because it is impossible to know the mind of another.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: yat punar uktam kumārilena
translated: Moreover, what Kumārila has said:

analyzed: narān dṛṣṭvā tu asarvajñān sarvān eva adhunātanān
translated: Having seen men who are not omniscient, all the present ones,

analyzed: tad sādṛśya upamānena śeṣa a sarvajña niścayaḥ
translated: The ascertainment of the rest as non-omniscient is by analogy with their similarity.

analyzed: tat api ayuktam
translated: That also is not correct.

analyzed: adhunātana sarva nara asarvajña tva aniścayāt
translated: Because the non-ascertainment of the non-omniscience of all present men.

analyzed: niścaye ca ātmani eva sarvajña tva abhyupagama prasaṅgāt
translated: And if there were ascertainment, it would follow that one would accept omniscience in oneself alone.

analyzed: nā api arthāpattiḥ bādhikā
translated: Nor is presumption a refutation.

original: yato dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho 'nyathā nopapadyata iti adṛṣṭārthaṃparikalpanamarthāpattirucyate /
analyzed: yatas dṛṣṭaḥ śrutaḥ vā arthaḥ nyathā nā upapadyate iti adṛṣṭa artham parikalpanam arthāpattiḥ ucyate
translated: Presumption is said to be the postulation of an unseen object because it is not otherwise possible, when an object seen or heard is otherwise not possible.

original: na cāsarvajñatvamantareṇa sarvanareṣu kaścidartho dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vā nopapadyate yatastadarthāpattyā parikalpyeta /
analyzed: na ca asarvajñatvam antareṇa sarva nareṣu kaścid arthaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ śrutaḥ vā nā upapadyate yatas tad arthāpattyā parikalpyeta
translated: And without omniscience, no purpose is seen or heard with regard to all men, from which it could be imagined by presumption.

analyzed: nanu saṃsārasya tāvat anādi tvam pramāṇena pratītam
translated: But the beginninglessness of the world has been established by means of a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tat ca na sarvajñena jñāyate
translated: And that cannot be known by an omniscient being.
Because if it were non-existent beyond the limit of his knowledge, the beginninglessness would be destroyed.

analyzed: tat anyathā anupapadyamānam sarva bhāvānām anādi tvam sarvajña abhāvam sādhayati iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the beginninglessness of all things, which is not otherwise possible, proves the non-existence of an omniscient being,

analyzed: ucyate upayukta sarvajña apekṣayā tāvat idam adūṣaṇam
translated: it is said: This is not a fault from the point of view of an omniscient being who is needed.

analyzed: tasya anādi tva ajñāne pi upayukta sarvajña tva avyāhateḥ
translated: Because even if he does not know the beginninglessness, the omniscience that is needed is not contradicted.

analyzed: sarva sarvajñasya api abhāve sādhye samarthā iyam arthāpattiḥ
translated: If the non-existence of an omniscient being who knows everything is to be proved, this presumption is not valid.

original: tathā hi yathā saṃsārasyānāditve pūrvapūrvavastusattāyā anavadhitvaṃ tathā sarvajñajñānasyāpi pūrvapūrvavastusattāvyāpakatvenānavadhiprasaratā 🔽iti /
analyzed: tathā hi yathā saṃsārasya anādi tve pūrva pūrva vastu sattāyāḥ anavadhi tvam tathā sarvajña jñānasya api pūrva pūrva vastu sattā vyāpaka tvena anavadhi prasara tā  iti
translated: Because just as the existence of the previous things has no limit in the beginninglessness of the world, so also the omniscient knowledge, being all-pervading, has an unlimited spread.

analyzed: ajñātasya ekasya api vastunaḥ nava sthiteḥ
translated: Thus, even if a single unknown thing is not established.

analyzed: sati api sarvajñe nādi tvam upapadyamānam na sarvajña abhāvam ākṣipati
translated: Even if there is an omniscient being, the fact that [the world] is beginningless, being possible, does not negate the existence of an omniscient being.

analyzed: tatas ca arthāpattiḥ api na sarvajñasya bādhikā
translated: Therefore, presumption also does not contradict an omniscient being.

analyzed: na ca abhāva pramāṇa bādhyaḥ sarvajñaḥ  pramāṇa pañcaka nivṛttiḥ abhāva pramāṇam iṣyate
translated: And an omniscient being is not contradicted by the means of knowledge of non-existence.🔽The absence of the five means of knowledge is accepted as the means of knowledge of non-existence.

analyzed: tatra nivṛttiḥ iti prasajya vṛttyā pramāṇa anutpatti mātram abhipretam
translated: There, absence is intended in the sense of non-existence, as the mere non-arising of the means of knowledge.

analyzed: atha vā paryudāsa vṛttyā vastu antaram
translated: Or, in the sense of exclusion, it is a different entity.

analyzed: vastu antaram api jaḍa rūpam jñāna rūpam vā
translated: And that different entity is either of the nature of inert matter or of the nature of knowledge.

analyzed: jñānam api jñāna mātram
translated: And knowledge is either mere knowledge

analyzed: eka jñāna saṃsargi vastu jñānam vā iti vikalpāḥ
translated: or the knowledge of an entity that is in association with a single cognition. These are the alternatives.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat nivṛtti mātra bhāva pramāṇam upapadyate
translated: Among them, first, the means of knowledge that exists as mere absence is not possible.

analyzed: tat khalu nikhila śakti vikala tayā na kiñcid
translated: For that, being devoid of all power, is nothing.

original: yacca na kiñcit tatkathaṃ prameyaṃ paricchindyāt /
analyzed: yat ca na kiñcid tat katham prameyam paricchindyāt
translated: And how can that which is nothing determine an object of knowledge?

analyzed: tad viṣayam vā vijñānam janayet
translated: Or generate a cognition having that as its object?

analyzed: pratītam vā tat katham iti sarvam andhakāra nartanam yathā uktam
translated: Or how can that which is well-known be so? All this is like dancing in the dark. As it has been said:

analyzed: na hi abhāvaḥ kasyacid pratipattiḥ pratipatti hetuḥ vā
translated: For non-existence is neither the apprehension of anything nor the cause of apprehension.

analyzed: tasya api vā katham pratipattiḥ iti
translated: Or how is there understanding of that [non-existence]?

analyzed: nā api vastu antara tā pakṣe jaḍa rūpaḥ pramāṇa abhāvaḥ saṃgacchate
translated: Nor is it proper for the theory of non-existence being a different entity from the object to be a dull form, due to the absence of a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tasya prameya pariccheda ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for that [non-existence] to define the object of knowledge.

analyzed: paricchedasya jñāna dharma tvāt
translated: Because definition is a property of knowledge.

analyzed: nā api jñāna mātra svabhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: Nor is non-existence the nature of mere knowledge.

analyzed: deśa kāla svabhāva viprakṛṣṭasya api tatas bhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that even what is distant in space, time, and nature would be non-existent.

analyzed: tad apekṣayā api vijñāna mātra tvāt tasya
translated: Because that [knowledge] is merely consciousness in relation to that [distant object].

analyzed: atha eka jñāna saṃsargi svabhāvaḥ
translated: If it is accepted that [non-existence] has the nature of being associated with a single cognition,

analyzed: tadā kṣatam abhāva pramāṇa pratyāśayā
translated: then the hope for a means of valid knowledge of non-existence is ruined.

analyzed: adhyakṣa viśeṣasya eva abhāva pramāṇa nāma karaṇāt  tasya ca asmābhiḥ dṛśya anupalambha ākhya sādhana tvena svīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because a particular perception is given the name 'means of valid knowledge of non-existence'.🔽And because we accept that [perception] as a means of valid knowledge called 'non-apprehension of the perceptible', in order to prove the non-existence of the Lord.

analyzed: dṛśya anupalambhaḥ ca bhagavat abhāva sādhane samarthaḥ iti pūrvam eva āveditam
translated: And it has been explained before that non-apprehension of the perceptible is not capable of proving the non-existence of the Lord.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

original: kiṃ ca / kaḥ punarayaṃ pramāṇābhāvo 'bhimato bhavatām /
analyzed: kim ca kaḥ punar ayam pramāṇa abhāvaḥ bhimataḥ bhavatām
translated: Moreover, what exactly is this non-existence of a means of valid knowledge that you accept?

analyzed: sva pramāṇa gaṇa nivṛttiḥ atha sarva prāṇi gaṇa pramāṇa nivṛttiḥ
translated: Is it the cessation of your own means of counting, or the cessation of the means of counting of all living beings?

analyzed: tatra sva pramāṇa gaṇa nivṛttiḥ vyabhicāriṇī
translated: Among those, the cessation of your own means of counting is inconclusive.

analyzed: tasyām satyām api vyavahitasya arthasya an apahnava tvāt
translated: Even when that [non-apprehension] exists, the distant object is not denied.

analyzed: para pramāṇa nivṛttiḥ tu asarvavidaḥ siddhā
translated: But the cessation of other means of knowledge is not established for one who does not know everything.

analyzed: yat āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: sarva adṛṣṭiḥ ca sandigdhā sva adṛṣṭiḥ vyabhicāriṇī
translated: And the non-perception of all is doubtful, and one's own non-perception is inconclusive,

analyzed: vindhya adri randhra dūrvā ādeḥ adṛṣṭau api sattvataḥ iti
translated: Because even when the Vindhya mountain, the interior of the earth, and durva grass, etc. are not perceived, they exist.

analyzed: tat evam sarvajña niṣedhaḥ iti sthitam
translated: Thus, it is established that the non-existence of an omniscient being cannot be negated even by the means of knowledge of non-existence.

original: nanu tathāpi sadvyavahārārthaṃ sādhakamapyasya na vidyate /
analyzed: nanu tathā api sat vyavahāra artham sādhakam api asya na vidyate
translated: But even so, there is no means of establishing his existence for the purpose of worldly conventions.

original: tathā hi sarvavido 'tīndriyatvāt na tāvadasmadādipratyakṣamasya sādhakam /
analyzed: tathā hi atīndriya tvāt na tāvat asmat ādi pratyakṣam asya sādhakam
translated: To explain: Since the omniscient one is beyond the senses, perception of him by us and others is not a means of establishing his existence.

analyzed: yathā ca asmābhiḥ asau na upalabhyate tathā asmad jātīyaiḥ api apratyakṣa svabhāva niyamāt
translated: Just as we do not perceive him, he is also imperceptible to those of our kind, because of the restriction of the nature of not being perceptible.

original: na cāyaṃ kālāntare 'bhūditi ca kalpanā yujyate /
analyzed: na ca ayam kāla antare bhūt iti ca kalpanā yujyate
translated: And it is not proper to imagine that he existed at another time.

original: yathā hi kālatvādidānīntanakālavaditi anenānumānena nirākartuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yathā hi kāla tvāt idānīntana kāla vat iti anena anumānena nirākartum śakyate
translated: Just as it can be refuted by inference that he is like the present time because of being time, etc.,

analyzed: na tathā sādhayitum
translated: it cannot be established in that way.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: kārikā

analyzed: sarvajña kalpanā tu anyaiḥ vede vā apauruṣeya tā
translated: But others imagine an omniscient being, or the Vedas to be without a personal author,

analyzed: tulya vat kalpyate yena tena idam saṃpradhāryate
translated: By which [the two] are considered equal, by that this is being examined.

analyzed: sarvajñaḥ dṛśyate tavat an na idānīm asmat ādibhiḥ
translated: The omniscient one is not seen by us now,

analyzed: nirākaraṇa vat śakyā na ca āsīt iti kalpanā iti
translated: and it is not possible to refute him, nor was there such a conception.

analyzed: nā api anumānataḥ sarvajña siddhiḥ
translated: Nor is the establishment of omniscience by inference.

analyzed: tad pratibaddha liṅga aniścayāt
translated: Because the inferential mark that is bound to that is uncertain.

original: kiṃ ca sarvajñasattāsādhane sarvo hetuḥ trayīṃ doṣajātiṃ nātivartate asiddhatvaṃ viruddhatvamanaikāntikatvaṃ ceti /
analyzed: kim ca sarvajña sattā sādhane sarvaḥ hetuḥ trayīm doṣa jātim na ativartate asiddha tvam viruddha tvam anaikāntika tvam ca iti
translated: Moreover, in establishing the existence of the omniscient one, every reason does not go beyond the triad of faults: non-establishment, contradiction, and inconclusiveness.

original: tathā hi sarvajñe dharmiṇi kriyamāṇe na taddharmo hetuḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi sarvajñe dharmiṇi kriyamāṇe na tad dharmaḥ hetuḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Thus, when the omniscient one is being made the subject, its property is not an established reason.

analyzed: tasya eva dharmiṇaḥ sādhya tvena asiddha tvāt
translated: Because that very subject is not established as what is to be proven.

analyzed: siddhau vā vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: Or if it is established, there is the consequence of futility.

analyzed: asarvajñe dharmiṇi na sarvajña siddhiḥ
translated: In the case of the omniscient one being the subject, the establishment of the omniscient one is not possible.

analyzed: hetoḥ sarvajña viparīta sādhana tvena viruddha tvāt
translated: Because the reason contradicts the establishment of the opposite of the omniscient one.

analyzed: na api sarvajña asarvajña dharmaḥ hetuḥ
translated: Nor is the property of the omniscient one or the non-omniscient one a reason.

analyzed: tasya anaikāntika tvāt
translated: Because that is inconclusive.

analyzed: tasmāt na anumānataḥ sarvajña siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, the establishment of the omniscient one is not even by inference.

analyzed: kārikā
translated: kārikā

original: dṛṣṭo na caikadeśo 'sti liṅgaṃ yo vānumāpayet / iti //
analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ na ca eka deśaḥ sti liṅgam yaḥ vā anumāpayet iti
translated: And no part is seen, nor is there a mark that could be inferred.

analyzed: na api āgama gamyaḥ
translated: Nor is he known by scripture.

analyzed: āgamaḥ hi dvividhaḥ pauruṣeyaḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: For scripture is of two kinds: human and eternal.

original: tatra pauruṣeyopyāgamaḥ tadīyo vā tatra pramāṇam /
analyzed: tatra pauruṣeya upi āgamaḥ tadīyaḥ vā tatra pramāṇam
translated: And among them, human scripture or that of him (the omniscient one) is the authority there.

analyzed: nara antara praṇītaḥ vā
translated: Or it is composed by another person.

analyzed: na tāvat tadīyaḥ
translated: First, it is not that of him.

analyzed: anyaḥ nya saṃśraya āpatteḥ  tathā hi āgamasya sarvajña ukta tve prāmāṇyam
translated: Because of the fallacy of mutual dependence.🔽For thus, the scripture is authoritative because it is spoken by the omniscient one.

analyzed: asya ca prāmāṇye sati asmāt sarvajña siddhiḥ iti
translated: And if it is authoritative, then the omniscient one is established from it.

analyzed: nara antara praṇītaḥ tu pramāṇa tvena anabhimataḥ evā iti atas na sarvajña siddhiḥ  nibandh
translated: But that composed by another person is not accepted as authoritative. Therefore, the omniscient one is not established from that either.

original: kiṃ ca sarvajñapraṇītādvacanāt sarvajñasiddhau kimaparāddhaṃ svavacanena yenāto 'pyasau na gamyeta /
analyzed: kim ca sarvajña praṇītāt vacanāt sarvajña siddhau kim aparāddham sva vacanena yena atas pi asau na gamyeta
translated: Moreover, if the omniscient one is established from the statement composed by the omniscient one, what has been done wrong by one's own statement, by which he is not known even from that?

analyzed: na api nitya āgama gamyaḥ sarvajñaḥ
translated: Nor is the omniscient one known by eternal scripture.
