analyzed: tad avyavacchede tad svarūpa aparicchedāt sva pracyuti vyavacchedya svabhāva tvāt padmarāga bhāvasya
translated: Because without excluding that, its nature cannot be determined, since the existence of the ruby has the nature of being excluded by its own destruction.

analyzed: tad anavacchede tad pariccheda anupapatteḥ
translated: Because without excluding that, its determination is not possible.

analyzed: kasmāt punar tad anye puṣparāga ādayaḥ vyavacchidyante
translated: But why are the others, such as the ruby, excluded?

analyzed: tad abhāva avinābhāvāt iti ced
translated: If it is said it is because of the invariable concomitance with its absence,

analyzed: saḥ eva kutas
translated: why is that so?

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa kadācid api puṣparāga padmarāgayoḥ tādātmya anupalambhāt iti ced
translated: If it be said that the identity of ruby and padmarāga is never perceived by perception,

analyzed: yatra tarhi tatas tādātmya pratītiḥ
translated: then where there is the cognition of identity of those two,

analyzed: na tatra tad avinābhāvaḥ
translated: there is not the invariable concomitance of that [identity].

original: samasti ca so 'yaṃ padmarāga iti deśakālāvasthānugatamekaṃ padmarāgamavabhāsayantī sākṣātkāravatī pratītiḥ /
analyzed: samasti ca saḥ yam padmarāgaḥ iti deśa kāla avasthā anugatam ekam padmarāgam avabhāsayantī sākṣātkāravatī pratītiḥ
translated: And this cognition which manifests the padmarāga as one thing persisting through space, time and condition, is a cognition of direct perception.

analyzed: na vikalpa rūpa tayā asyāḥ aprāmāṇyam
translated: It is not invalid because of being in the form of a conceptual construction.

analyzed: abhilāpa saṃsarga pratibhāsa tva prāmāṇyayoḥ avirodhāt
translated: Because validity and the appearance of connection with verbal expression are not contradictory.

analyzed: na ca idam smārtam
translated: And this [cognition] is not a recollection.

analyzed: a deśa kāla avasthāvataḥ yam deśa kāla avasthā anugata tvena ādhikyāt iti
translated: Because this [padmarāga] which is not persisting through space, time and condition appears as persisting through space, time and condition, it is superior [to the recollection].

original: atha keśakuśakadalīstambādau satyapi bhede pratyabhijñānamutpannamiti cet /
analyzed: atha keśa kuśa kadalī stamba ādau sati api bhede pratyabhijñānam utpannam iti ced
translated: If it be said that recognition arises even in the case of hair, kuśa grass, plantain tree, etc., although there is difference,

analyzed: utpadyatām kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: let it arise. What is the fault?

analyzed: kim anena pratipāditam bhavati
translated: What is established by this?

analyzed: kim pratyabhijñāyāḥ sādhāraṇa anaikāntika tvam  atha śabda sāmyāt ubhayoḥ api aprāmāṇyam
translated: Is it the inconclusive nature of recognition in general?🔽Or is the invalidity of both [recognition and verbal testimony] due to the similarity of words?

analyzed: uta saṃśaya āpādana mātram
translated: Or is it merely the production of doubt?

analyzed: prathamaḥ pakṣaḥ na abhyupagamāt eva nirastaḥ
translated: The first hypothesis is refuted by the very fact that it is not accepted.

analyzed: na hi iyam anumāna tvena upanyastā
translated: For this [cognition] is not presented as an inference.

original: anumānatve 'pyabādhitatvāditi viśeṣaṇe na doṣa iti pratipādayiṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: anumāna tve pi abādhita tvāt iti viśeṣaṇe na doṣaḥ iti pratipādayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will show that there is no fault in the qualification not contradicted even if it is an inference.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is the second alternative [correct].

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta mātrataḥ sādhya siddheḥ ayogāt
translated: Because it is impossible to establish the probandum merely from an example.

analyzed: keśoṇḍuka ādi viṣayasya cakṣuḥ vijñānasya api aprāmāṇye ghaṭa ādi pratyakṣasya aprāmāṇya prasaṅgāt
translated: And because if the visual cognition of a hair-tuft and so on is also not valid, it would follow that the perception of a pot and so on is not valid.

original: saṃśayamātraṃ tu vyavahārocchedakatvānnāśrayaṇīyamevati pratipāditamiti na tṛtīyo 'pio pakṣaḥ //
analyzed: saṃśaya mātram tu vyavahāra ucchedaka tvāt na āśrayaṇīyam eva iti pratipāditam iti na tṛtīyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: And it has been shown that mere doubt, because it cuts off worldly activity, should not be relied upon at all, so the third alternative is also not [correct].

original: kiṃ ca keśādau yadi pratyabhijñā vyabhicāriṇo /🔽kāryakāraṇapratītiḥ kiṃ na vyabhicāriṇī /
analyzed: kim ca keśa ādau yadi pratyabhijñā vyabhicāriṇaḥ  kārya kāraṇa pratītiḥ kim na vyabhicāriṇī
translated: Moreover, if recognition in regard to hair and so on is fallacious,🔽how is the cognition of cause and effect not fallacious?

original: yā vyabhicāriṇo sā kāryakāraṇapratītireva na bhavatīti cet /🔽yadyevaṃ yā visaṃvādinī sā pratyabhijñaiva na bhavati tadābhāsatvāditi samānam /
analyzed: sā kārya kāraṇa pratītiḥ eva na bhavati iti ced  yadi evam yā visaṃvādinī sā pratyabhijñā eva na bhavati tad ābhāsa tvāt iti samānam
translated: If it is said that what is fallacious is not a cognition of cause and effect at all,🔽if so, then what is deceptive is not a recognition at all, because it is a semblance, so it is the same.

analyzed: pratyabhijñānasya ca sati prāmāṇye numāna ādiṣu anantarbhāve pratyakṣa tā eva
translated: And if recognition is valid, and is not included in inference and so on, then it is perception itself.

analyzed: saṃskāra sahāya indriya anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tvāt ca
translated: And because it conforms to the presence and absence of the sense organs aided by impressions.

analyzed: sat saṃprayoge sati indriyāṇām bhāvāt ca
translated: And because the senses exist when there is contact with the real.

original: tadiyaṃ pratyabhijñā anekadeśakālāvasthāsaṃbaddhamekaṃ sphaṭikādikaṃ gocarayantī sthairyaṃ vyavasthāpayati //
analyzed: tat iyam pratyabhijñā aneka deśa kāla avasthā saṃbaddham ekam sphaṭika ādikam gocarayantī sthairyam vyavasthāpayati
translated: Thus this recognition, perceiving a single crystal etc. connected with many places, times and states, establishes its permanence.

analyzed: tathā anumānataḥ pi sthira tā siddhiḥ
translated: In the same way, permanence is established by inference also.

original: prayogaḥ vivādādhyāsitaḥ sa evāyaṃ sphaṭikaṃ ityādipratyabhijñāpratyayo yathārthaḥ /
analyzed: prayogaḥ vivāda adhyāsitaḥ saḥ eva ayam sphaṭikam ityādi pratyabhijñā pratyayaḥ yathārthaḥ
translated: The argument is: The cognition of recognition, such as This is the same crystal, which is the subject of dispute, is true.

analyzed: a bādhita pratyaya tvāt
translated: Because it is an unobstructed cognition.

analyzed: yāvān abādhita pratyayaḥ sa sarvaḥ yathā arthaḥ upalabdhaḥ
translated: Whatever is an unobstructed cognition is all apprehended as true.

analyzed: yathā sva saṃvedana pratyayaḥ
translated: Like a cognition of one's own experience.

analyzed: a bādhitaḥ ca ayam
translated: And this is unobstructed.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā iti
translated: Therefore, it is so.

analyzed: abādhita tvam ca para udbhāvita kṣaṇikatva sādhana bādhaka uddhārāt niśceyam
translated: And unobstructedness should be ascertained by refuting the objections raised by others to the proof of momentariness.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: atha aparaḥ prayogaḥ
translated: Now another argument:

analyzed: vivāda adhyāsitāḥ bhāvāḥ pūrva apara kālayoḥ eka svabhāvāḥ
translated: Things subject to dispute have the same nature in the earlier and later times.

analyzed: a bādhita pratyabhijñayā pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt
translated: Because they are recognized by unobstructed recognition.

analyzed: yat yat abādhita pratyabhijñayā pratyabhijñāyate tat sarvam abhinnam
translated: Whatever is recognized by unobstructed recognition, all that is non-different.

original: yathā yastvayā dṛṣṭo nīlo 'rthaḥ sa eva mayā dṛṣṭa iti nīlo 'rthaḥ pratyabhijñāyate /
analyzed: yathā yaḥ tvayā dṛṣṭaḥ nīlaḥ rthaḥ saḥ eva mayā dṛṣṭaḥ iti nīlaḥ rthaḥ pratyabhijñāyate
translated: Just as when one says The blue object that was seen by you was seen by me too, the blue object is recognized.

analyzed: tathā ca ete bhāvāḥ
translated: And so are these entities.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā iti
translated: Therefore, it is like that.

analyzed: pūrvam pratyayasya dharmi tā  adhunā bhāvānām iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Previously, the dharma-ness of the condition was stated.🔽Now, the difference is that it is stated for the entities.

analyzed: kim ca sa hetuka tvāt vināśasya siddham
translated: Moreover, the permanence of entities is established because destruction has a cause.

original: prayogaḥ vivādāspadībhūtā bhāvā yathāsvaṃ vināśahetusannidheḥ prāṅ na vināśinaḥ /
analyzed: prayogaḥ vivāda āspadībhūtāḥ bhāvāḥ yathāsvam vināśa hetu sannidheḥ prāk na vināśinaḥ
translated: The argument is: The entities that are the subject of the dispute do not perish prior to the presence of their respective causes of destruction,

analyzed: sa hetuka vināśa tvāt
translated: because their destruction has a cause.

analyzed: yat yad hetukam tat tat asannidhau na bhavati
translated: Whatever has a cause does not exist in the absence of that cause.

analyzed: yathā vahni ādi abhāve dhūma ādiḥ
translated: For example, smoke does not exist in the absence of fire and so on.

analyzed: sa hetuka vināśāḥ ca amī bhāvāḥ
translated: And these entities have destruction with a cause.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā iti
translated: Therefore, it is like that.

original: sahetukavināśatvaṃ ca ghaṭasyāgnidhūmayoriva pratyakṣānupalambhato mudgaravināśayorapi kāryakāraṇabhāvasiddhau siddham /
analyzed: sa hetuka vināśa tvam ca ghaṭasya agni dhūmayoḥ iva pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ mudgara vināśayoḥ api kārya kāraṇa bhāva siddhau siddham
translated: And the fact that destruction has a cause is established by the establishment of the relation of cause and effect between a hammer and destruction, just as between a pot and fire and smoke, through perception and non-perception.

analyzed: na ca vināśa hetoḥ asāmarthya vaiyarthya abhidhānam ucitam
translated: And it is not proper to say that the cause of destruction is either incapable or useless.

analyzed: aṅkura ādi hetoḥ api tathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to the consequence that the cause of a sprout and so on would also be like that.

analyzed: śakyam hi vaktum arthasya abhaviṣṇu tāyām asamarthaḥ janma hetuḥ
translated: For it can be said that when the object is non-existent, the cause of birth is ineffective.

analyzed: bhaviṣṇu tāyām vyarthaḥ iti
translated: When it is existent, it is useless.

analyzed: api ca akṣaṇikāḥ santaḥ
translated: Moreover, they are non-momentary,

analyzed: kāraṇavat tvāt
translated: because they have a cause.

analyzed: yat kāraṇavat tat akṣaṇikam
translated: What has a cause is non-momentary.

analyzed: yathā bhāva vināśaḥ
translated: Like the destruction of an existent thing.

analyzed: kāraṇavantaḥ ca ime santaḥ
translated: And these existents have a cause.

analyzed: tasmāt akṣaṇikāḥ iti
translated: Therefore they are non-momentary.

original: kāraṇavattvasya sādhyaviparyaye vṛttiśaṅkā vināśasya sahetukatvameva nivartayatīti prasiddhavyāptikāt kāraṇavattvādakṣaṇikatvasiddhiriti //
analyzed: kāraṇavat tvasya sādhya viparyaye vṛtti śaṅkā vināśasya sa hetuka tvam eva nivartayati iti prasiddha vyāptikāt kāraṇavat tvāt akṣaṇika tva siddhiḥ iti
translated: The suspicion of the occurrence of the property of having a cause in the opposite of the probandum only excludes the fact that destruction has a cause. Thus momentariness is established from having a cause, whose pervasion is well-known.

analyzed: tathā śaṅkaraḥ sthira siddhau prāha
translated: Similarly, Śaṅkara says in the Sthirasiddhi:

analyzed: na utpatti anantara vināśī bhāvaḥ
translated: An existent thing is not destroyed immediately after arising,

analyzed: prameya tvāt
translated: because it is an object of knowledge.

analyzed: vastu vyāvṛtti vat iti
translated: Like the exclusion of an entity.

analyzed: a vidyamāna vipakṣa tvāt anvayī eva hetuḥ
translated: The reason is inconclusive because the counter-example does not exist.

analyzed: prameya tvasya kṣaṇika tvena virodha abhāvāt sandigdha vyatireki tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is of doubtful exclusion because the property of being an object of knowledge is not contradictory with momentariness,

original: na khalu kṣaṇikatve kasyacitprameyatvaṃ sidhyati /🔽kṣaṇasthitidharmaṇaḥ pramāṇakāle 'pātāt /
analyzed: na khalu kṣaṇika tve kasyacid prameya tvam sidhyati 🔽kṣaṇa sthiti dharmaṇaḥ pramāṇa kāle pātāt
translated: indeed, the property of being an object of knowledge is not established for anything that is momentary.🔽Because it would not exist at the time of the means of knowledge, being subject to momentary existence.

analyzed: atītasya ca prameya tve tiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: And if the past were an object of knowledge, there would be an absurd consequence.

analyzed: evam eva prayogam upastuvan trilocanaḥ pi āha
translated: In the same way, Trilocana, praising this method of proof, says:

analyzed: akṣaṇikāḥ sarva bhāvāḥ  prameya tvāt
translated: All things are momentary.🔽Because they are objects of knowledge.

analyzed: yat pramīyate tat akṣaṇikam
translated: What is known is momentary.

analyzed: yathā bhāva vināśaḥ
translated: Like the destruction of an entity.

analyzed: prameyāḥ ca sarva bhāvāḥ
translated: And all things are objects of knowledge.

analyzed: tasmāt akṣaṇikāḥ iti
translated: Therefore they are momentary.

analyzed: asiddhaḥ dṛṣṭānta dharmī iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the example property is unestablished, it is not so.

analyzed: sva kāraṇa kalāpāt utpannavataḥ bhāvasya antareṇa nivṛtti prasavam sarvadā avasthāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Because for an entity that has arisen from its own assemblage of causes, without the occurrence of cessation, there would be the consequence of remaining forever.

original: tadaiva bhāvo 'sti na pūrvaṃ na praścādityapi śabdaḥ kṣaṇikaparyāyatveneṣyamāṇaḥ kṣaṇādūrdhvaṃ sattvāvicchedopajananamantareṇa nārthavān devairapi 🔽śakyaḥ parikalpayitum /
analyzed: tadā eva bhāvaḥ sti na pūrvam na praścāt iti api śabdaḥ kṣaṇika paryāya tvena iṣyamāṇaḥ kṣaṇāt ūrdhvam sattva aviccheda upajananam antareṇa na arthavān devaiḥ api  śakyaḥ parikalpayitum
translated: Even the word at that time the entity exists, not before nor after, if intended as a synonym for momentary, is not meaningful without generating the uninterrupted arising of existence after the moment, even if it could be imagined by the gods.

analyzed: vināśa kāla apekṣayā hi kṣaṇaḥ lpīyān kālaḥ
translated: For a moment is a shorter period of time in relation to the time of destruction.

analyzed: tena saḥ sya asti iti kṣaṇikaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: Therefore it should be said that it is momentary because it has that.

analyzed: itarathā janma vināśayoḥ ekasmin kāle bhavatoḥ tulya hetuka tvena ekatva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, if arising and destruction occur at the same time, they would be of the same cause, and there would be the consequence of oneness.

analyzed: eka tve tu dvayoḥ ekataraḥ prahātavyaḥ
translated: But if they were one, one of the two would have to be abandoned.

analyzed: tatra janma prahāṇe bhāvāḥ niḥsvabhāvāḥ prasajyeran
translated: If it were so, then things would be without self-nature in the abandonment of birth.

original: nivṛttiparityāge ca janmino bhāvā nityā iti durnivāraḥ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: nivṛtti parityāge ca janminaḥ bhāvāḥ nityāḥ iti durnivāraḥ prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if the cessation were abandoned, then things that are born would be eternal, and the consequence is unavoidable.

analyzed: tat siddhaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: Therefore, the example is established.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: nanu prameya tva kṣaṇika tvayoḥ virodha asiddheḥ sandigdha vipakṣa vyāvṛttikam prameya tvam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the subject, being an object of knowledge, is inconclusive in excluding the counter-example because the contradiction between being an object of knowledge and being momentary is not established,

original: naitadasti /🔽yasmādarthaṃ kañcit prāpayat pratyakṣaṃ tena pratyāsannatvātprāpayati /
analyzed: na etat asti  yasmāt artham kañcid prāpayat pratyakṣam tena pratyāsanna tvāt prāpayati
translated: that is not so.🔽Because when something produces a certain object, it produces it through that proximity.

analyzed: pratyāsattiḥ ca tad utpatiḥ evā avakalpate
translated: And proximity is only possible as arising from that.

analyzed: na tādātmyam
translated: Not as identity.

analyzed: sa ākāra nirākāra vādayoḥ aprakṛta tvāt
translated: Because the theories of representation and non-representation are not under consideration.

analyzed: anyatra nirākṛta tvāt ca
translated: And because they have been refuted elsewhere.

original: sā ca niyatavastupratibhāsākṣiptā kāryakāraṇabhāvalakṣaṇā pratyāsattistulyakālaṃ pramāṇaprameyayoranupapannā /
analyzed: sā ca niyata vastu pratibhāsa ākṣiptā kārya kāraṇa bhāva lakṣaṇā pratyāsattiḥ tulya kālam pramāṇa prameyayoḥ anupapannā
translated: And that proximity characterized by the relation of cause and effect, which is projected by the appearance of a definite object, is not possible at the same time for the means of knowledge and the object of knowledge,

analyzed: savyetara viṣāṇayoḥ iva
translated: like the right and left horns of a cow.

analyzed: tatas pramāṇam artha sattām bodhayat tad adhīna utpāda tayā bodhayati
translated: Therefore, the means of knowledge, while revealing the existence of the object, reveals it as produced in dependence on that.

analyzed: kāraṇa bhāva mātra anubandhi tvāt ca tasya pūrva kāla sattayā bhavitavyam
translated: And because it is related merely to the state of being a cause, it must exist in the prior moment.

analyzed: atas pūrva kāla sattvena vyāptam prameya tvam
translated: Therefore, the property of being an object is pervaded by prior existence.

original: pūrvakālasattvaṃ ca kṣaṇikatve 'nupapannamiti vyāpakānupalabdhyā vipakṣāt kṣaṇikatvād vyāvartamānaṃ prameyatvamakṣaṇikatvena vyāpyata iti asandigdho 🔽vyatirekaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva kāla sattvam ca kṣaṇika tve nupapannam iti vyāpaka anupalabdhyā vipakṣāt kṣaṇika tvāt vyāvartamānam prameya tvam akṣaṇika tvena vyāpyate iti asandigdhaḥ  vyatirekaḥ
translated: And prior existence is not possible in the case of momentariness. Thus, by the non-apprehension of the pervader, the property of being an object, which is excluded from momentariness, the contrary, is pervaded by non-momentariness. Thus the negative concomitance is undoubted.

analyzed: tat evam anumāna pramāṇa siddhaḥ kṣaṇikaḥ iti
translated: Thus, it is established that the non-momentary is proved by the means of knowledge of inference.

analyzed: evam arthāpattiḥ api asya sādhikā
translated: In the same way, presumption also proves it.

original: tathā hi kāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇaṃ kramayaugapadyagrahaṇasmaraṇam abhilāṣaḥ svayaṃnihitapratyanumārgaṇaṃ
analyzed: tathā hi kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇam krama yaugapadya grahaṇa smaraṇam abhilāṣaḥ svayaṃnihita pratyanumārgaṇam
translated: Thus, the apprehension of the relation of cause and effect, the apprehension and recollection of sequence and simultaneity, desire, the recollection of one's own hidden path,

analyzed: duṣṭa artha kutūhala viramaṇam karma phala saṃbandhaḥ saṃśaya pūrvaka nirṇayaḥ bandha mokṣaḥ
translated: the cessation of curiosity about faulty objects, the relation between action and its result, the ascertainment preceded by doubt, bondage and liberation,

original: mokṣaprayatnaḥ śubhodarke karmaṇi pravṛttiḥ pratyabhijñā kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ upādānopādeyabhāvaprabhṛtayaḥ
analyzed: mokṣa prayatnaḥ śubha udarke karmaṇi pravṛttiḥ pratyabhijñā kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ upādāna upādeya bhāva prabhṛtayaḥ
translated: the effort for liberation, engagement in virtuous action, recognition, the relation of cause and effect, the relation of material cause and effect, etc.,

analyzed: sthira sattām antareṇa anupapadyamānāḥ sthairya sādhayanti
translated: which are not possible without a permanent existence, prove permanence.

original: pratikṣaṇaṃ bhede satyanubhaviturvinaṣṭatve 'nyasya kāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇādyanupapatteriti kathaṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgaśaṅkāpi //
analyzed: pratikṣaṇam bhede sati anubhavituḥ vinaṣṭa tve nyasya kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇa ādi anupapatteḥ iti katham kṣaṇa bhaṅga śaṅkā api
translated: If there were difference at every moment, the experiencer would be destroyed, and the relation of cause and effect, etc. would be impossible for another. So how can there be even a suspicion of momentariness?

analyzed: atra abhidhīyate
translated: To this we reply:

original: apramāṇamevāyaṃ pratyabhijñākhyo vikalpo mithyātvaṃ ca sadviṣayatvabādhakapratyayāt /
analyzed: apramāṇam eva ayam pratyabhijñā ākhyaḥ vikalpaḥ mithyātvam ca sat viṣaya tva bādhaka pratyayāt
translated: This conception called recognition is indeed not a means of valid knowledge. And its falsity is due to the cognition that contradicts its being about a real object.

analyzed: nanu asya bādhakam pratyakṣam asambhavi
translated: But isn't the contradicting [means of valid knowledge] in this case impossible to be perception?

analyzed: anumānam ca asamartham āveditam iti ced
translated: And isn't inference powerless, as explained?

analyzed: nanu asya pratyabhijñānasya sva artha avinābhāva dārḍhye pratyakṣa sahasreṇa api kim
translated: But if this recognition is firm due to the invariable concomitance with its object, what is the use of even a thousand perceptions?

analyzed: saṃvāda śaithilye tu bādhaka pratyakṣa vat anumānam api prāpta avakāśam
translated: But if there is looseness in agreement, then inference also gets an opportunity, like a contradicting perception.

analyzed: pramāṇasya eva siddhi bādhayoḥ adhikārāt
translated: Because success and failure belong only to a means of valid knowledge.

original: tathā hi māyākāraḥ śirasi nimajjitaṃ golakamāsyena niḥsārayatīti pratyabhijñā śirasi cchidraprasaṅgasaṅgatenānumānena bādhyamānā pratītaiva
analyzed: tathā hi māyākāraḥ śirasi nimajjitam golakam āsyena niḥsārayati iti pratyabhijñā śirasi chidra prasaṅga saṅga tena anumānena bādhyamānā pratītā eva
translated: For example, when a magician takes out a ball that has been submerged in his head through his mouth, the recognition is indeed perceived, but is contradicted by an inference connected with the implication of a hole in the head.

analyzed: bādhyamānā na pratyabhijñā iti prastute pi astu
translated: Let it be that what is contradicted is not recognition, even in the present case.

original: yathāvanatākāśapratibhāsaḥ sarvasaṃpratipattāvapi bādhya eva tadvadekatāgrahaḥ sarvasaṃpratipattāvapi bādhyo 'stu /
analyzed: yathā avanata ākāśa pratibhāsaḥ sarva saṃpratipattau api bādhyaḥ eva tadvat ekatā grahaḥ sarva saṃpratipattau api bādhyaḥ stu
translated: Just as the reflection of the sky bent by a lens, though appearing to all who are present, is still to be refuted, so let the apprehension of oneness be refuted even though all are in agreement.

analyzed: tasmāt asyāḥ pratyakṣa tā kīrtanam yācitaka maṇḍana mātram atrāṇam
translated: Therefore, the claim that this [apprehension of oneness] is perception is merely a vain ornament, not a defense.

analyzed: katham atas sthairya sthitiḥ astu
translated: How then can it be established as stable?

analyzed: tatas ca anumāna tvam api asyāḥ dhvastam
translated: And from that, its status as inference is also destroyed.

analyzed: ukta krameṇa abādhita tva viśeṣaṇa viruddha bādhyamāna tāyāḥ prasādhanāt iti viśeṣaṇa asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: Because the reason for its refutation, being contradicted while not being contradicted in the stated order, is established, the reason is unestablished with respect to the qualifier.

analyzed: yadā api kṣaṇa bhaṅga sādhakam bādhakam nā ucyate asyāḥ tadā api iyam apramāṇam eva
translated: Even when a refutation establishing momentariness is not stated, this [apprehension of oneness] is still not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: lūna punar jāta keśa pāśa ādau vyabhicāra upalambhāt
translated: Because deviation is observed in the case of hair that is cut and grows back, etc.

original: nanūktaṃ yā vyabhicāriṇī sā na pratyabhijñetyādi /
analyzed: nanu uktam yā vyabhicāriṇī sā na pratyabhijñā ityādi
translated: But hasn't it been said that what is deviant is not recognized, etc.?

analyzed: yuktam etat
translated: This is correct.

analyzed: yadi kārya kāraṇa bhāva pratīti vat lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ pratipādayitum śakyeta
translated: If the difference in characteristics, like the cognition of the relation of cause and effect, could be demonstrated.

analyzed: yathā hi anvaya vyatireka grahaṇa pravaṇa pratyakṣa anupalambhāt upapannaḥ niścayaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva pratīteḥ anyaḥ tad ābhāsa pratītiḥ iti anayoḥ lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ
translated: For instance, the ascertainment that is brought about by Perception and Non-apprehension, which are capable of indicating positive and negative concomitance, is quite different from the cognition of the relation of Cause and Effect; and the difference between these two is quite clear.

original: tathā yadi pratyabhijñāne 'pi lakṣaṇabhedo darśitaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā yadi pratyabhijñāne lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ darśitaḥ syāt
translated: For just as the ascertainment of the relation of cause and effect is established by perception and non-apprehension inclined to the apprehension of concomitance and non-concomitance, and the apprehension of their semblance is different from that, so if the difference of the characteristics of recognition and its semblance is shown,

analyzed: darśayitum
translated: if it is possible to demonstrate
or to compose a treatise on the difference of characteristics in recognition also,

analyzed: tadā bhavatu pratyabhijñā tad ābhāsayoḥ vivekaḥ
translated: then let there be discrimination between recognition and its semblance.

analyzed: na tu evam asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: sarvatra atyanta sadṛśe vastuni pṛthagjana pratyabhijñāyāḥ ekarasa tvāt
translated: Because in every case, due to the oneness of the recognition of an ordinary person in a very similar object,

analyzed: saṃvādi tva asaṃvādi tve lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the difference of characteristics lies in being in agreement and not being in agreement, that is not so.

original: aliṅgasya hi vikalpasya saṃvādo nāma pramāṇāntarasaṅgatirarthakriyāprāptirvā /
analyzed: aliṅgasya hi vikalpasya saṃvādaḥ nāma pramāṇa antara saṅgatiḥ arthakriyā prāptiḥ vā
translated: For a non-inferential cognition, what is called agreement is either the connection with another means of knowledge or the attainment of practical efficiency.

analyzed: tatra na tāvat ādyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Among those, the first view is not tenable.

analyzed: paścāt api saḥ eva ayam iti svatantra eka adhyavasāya mātrāt aparasya pramāṇa gandhasya api abhāvāt
translated: Because even later, there is only the independent single determination this is the same, and there is no trace of another means of knowledge.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ saṃgacchate
translated: Nor is the second view tenable.

analyzed: na hi pūrva apara kālayoḥ eka vastu pratibaddhā siddhā kācid arthakriyāḥ
translated: For no single object is found to be related to the two times, past and future.

analyzed: bhinnena api tad samāna śaktinā tādṛś arthakriyāyāḥ karaṇa avirodhāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in an object of similar capacity, even if different, performing such an action.

original: tathā hi yathaiko ghaṭo vāri dhārayatīti tatkālabhāvino 'pyanyasya deśāntaravartino na vāridhāraṇavāraṇam tathā dvitīyādikṣaṇopyanyo yadi vāri
analyzed: tathā hi yathā ekaḥ ghaṭaḥ vāri dhārayati iti tad kāla bhāvinaḥ u pi anyasya deśa antara vartinaḥ na vāri dhāraṇa vāraṇam tathā dvitīya ādi kṣaṇaḥ upi anyaḥ yadi vāri
translated: For example, just as one pot is said to hold water, the other existing at that time and located in a different place is not prevented from holding water, similarly, if the second moment and other moments also hold water,

analyzed: kīdṛśaḥ doṣaḥ syāt
translated: what kind of fault would there be?

analyzed: visadṛśa kriyāyām tu cintā eva na asti
translated: But when the action is dissimilar, there is no doubt at all.

analyzed: tat katham pratyabhijñānasya saṃvāda saṃbhavaḥ
translated: So how is it possible for recognition to be in agreement?

original: nanu yadyekaṃ pratyabhijñānaṃ bisaṃvādi dṛṣṭamiti sarvameva pratyabhijñānaṃ visaṃvādi śaṅkyate /
analyzed: nanu yadi ekam pratyabhijñānam bisaṃvādi dṛṣṭam iti sarvam eva pratyabhijñānam visaṃvādi śaṅkyate
translated: If it is argued that if one instance of recognition is seen to be in disagreement, then all recognition is suspected of being in disagreement,

original: tadaikamindriyajñānaṃ keśoṇḍukadvicandrādau visaṃvādyupalabdhamiti ghaṭādiṣvapi sarvameva pratyakṣaṃ visaṃvādi saṃbhāvyatām /
analyzed: tadā ekam indriya jñānam keśoṇḍuka dvi candra ādau visaṃvādi upalabdham iti ghaṭa ādiṣu api sarvam eva pratyakṣam visaṃvādi saṃbhāvyatām
translated: then just as one sense perception is seen to be in disagreement regarding hair-tufts, circles, two moons, etc., in the same way, all perception regarding pots etc. should also be suspected of being in disagreement.

analyzed: indriya janya tvasya eka lakṣaṇasya sarvatra saṃbhavāt iti ced na
translated: Because the single defining characteristic of being produced by a sense organ is present in all cases. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: tatra api lakṣaṇa bhedasya sadbhāvāt
translated: Because even there, the difference in defining characteristics is present.

original: tathā hi bahirarthasthitāvindriyārthakāryatayā sākṣādarthākārānukāritvaṃ pratyakṣatvam /🔽taccābhyāsaviśeṣāsāditapaṭimnā pratyakṣeṇa niścīyate /
analyzed: tathā hi bahis artha sthitau indriya artha kārya tayā sākṣāt artha ākāra anukāri tvam pratyakṣa tvam  tat ca abhyāsa viśeṣa āsādita paṭimnā pratyakṣeṇa niścīyate
translated: For instance, the directness of perception consists in its being the effect of the sense-object-contact, and hence in its being a copy of the form of the object.🔽And this is ascertained by perception itself, which has been brought about by the excellence of practice.

analyzed: kvacid tu arthakriyā prāpti jñānāt iti pratyakṣa tvam anavadyam eva
translated: In some cases, it is ascertained from the knowledge of the attainment of the effect of the object. Thus, directness is not at all faulty.

original: dvicandrādau tvarthavinākṛtena timirādiviplutacakṣuirmātreṇa tajjñānaṃ janitamiti pratyakṣābhāsameva /
analyzed: dvi candra ādau tu artha vinākṛtena timira ādi vipluta cakṣuḥ mātreṇa tat jñānam janitam iti pratyakṣa ābhāsam eva
translated: But in the case of the perception of two moons, that knowledge is produced merely by the eyes affected by timira, without any external object. Hence, it is only an apparent perception.

original: dvicandrādyarthābhāvastu deśakālanarāntarairdvicandrāderarthasya bādhitatvādavyāhata iti pratyakṣābhāsaparihāre 'pi pratyakṣeṣu ka āścāsavirodhaḥ
analyzed: dvi candra ādi artha abhāvaḥ tu deśa kāla nara antaraiḥ dvi candra ādeḥ arthasya bādhita tvāt avyāhataḥ iti pratyakṣa ābhāsa parihāre pi pratyakṣeṣu kaḥ āścāsa virodhaḥ
translated: But the non-existence of the object of the perception of two moons is not contradicted by other persons at other places and times, because the object of the perception of two moons is contradicted. Thus, even when apparent perceptions are excluded, there is no contradiction in perceptions.

analyzed: pratyabhijñāne sarvam idam asti iti na yuktam
translated: And all this is not proper in the case of recognition.

original: yathā hi pūrvaṃ pāvakādau pākādikriyā pratibaddhā siddhā paścādanubhūyamānā dahanajñānasya saṃvādamāvedayati /
analyzed: yathā hi pūrvam pāvaka ādau pāka ādi kriyā pratibaddhā siddhā paścāt anubhūyamānā dahana jñānasya saṃvādam āvedayati
translated: For instance, when the action of cooking, etc. is first established as connected with fire, etc., and is then experienced, it indicates the agreement of the knowledge of burning.

analyzed: anyathā bāhya artha ucchedāt nirīham jagat jāyate
translated: Otherwise, the world would be born without any activity, due to the annihilation of external objects.

original: na tathā prathamacaramakālayorekīmāvapratibaddhā kācidarthakriyā upalabdhigocarā pūrvāparakālayorekatvamantareṇa vā pravṛttyādikṣatiryenaikatāvagraho 🔽'pi saṃvādī syāt /
analyzed: na tathā prathama carama kālayoḥ ekī īmāva pratibaddhā kācid arthakriyā upalabdhi gocarā pūrva apara kālayoḥ ekatvam antareṇa vā pravṛtti ādi kṣatiḥ yena ekatā avagrahaḥ  pi saṃvādī syāt
translated: Nor is any such useful action observed in the sphere of perception, which is connected with the unity of the object at the first and last moments, or without the unity of the object at the earlier and later moments, by which the apprehension of unity would also be in conformity with reality.

original: tadiyamanumānabādhitatvād vyabhicāraśaṅkākalaṅkitatvāccana pratyakṣamanumānaṃ veti kathamataḥ sthairyasiddhiranumānapratihatirvā //
analyzed: tat iyam anumāna bādhita tvāt vyabhicāra śaṅkā kalaṅkita tvāt cana pratyakṣam anumānam vā iti katham atas sthairya siddhiḥ anumāna pratihatiḥ vā
translated: Therefore, this [apprehension of unity] is neither perception nor inference, because it is contradicted by inference and because it is tainted by the suspicion of error. How then can there be establishment of permanence or contradiction of inference from this [apprehension of unity]?

original: yat punarvācaspatirūvāca saṃskārendriyayormilitayoreva pratyabhijñānaṃ prati kāraṇatvamiti /
analyzed: yat punar vācaspatiḥ ūvāca saṃskāra indriyayoḥ militayoḥ eva pratyabhijñānam prati kāraṇa tvam iti
translated: As for what Vācaspati said, that the impression and the sense organ together are the cause for recognition,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is incorrect.

analyzed: bhinna sāmagrī prasūta tvāt anayoḥ jñānayoḥ
translated: Because these two cognitions are produced by different collections of causes.

original: tathā hi nimīlite cakṣuṣi sa ityatrendriyavinākṛtasyaiva saṃskārasya sāmarthyamupalabdham /
analyzed: tathā hi nimīlite cakṣuṣi saḥ iti atra indriya vinākṛtasya eva saṃskārasya sāmarthyam upalabdham
translated: For thus, when the eyes are closed, in that, the capacity of the impression alone, without the sense organ, is observed.

original: prathamadarśane tvayamityatra saṃskārarahitasyaivendriyasya sāmarthyaṃ dṛṣṭam /🔽tasmāt sāmagrīdvayapratibaddhaṃ
analyzed: prathama darśane tu ayam iti atra saṃskāra rahitasya eva indriyasya sāmarthyam dṛṣṭam  tasmāt sāmagrī dvaya pratibaddham
translated: But in the first perception, this, the capacity of the sense organ alone, without the impression, is seen.
Therefore, this pair of cognitions is determined to be dependent on two collections of causes.

analyzed: katham ubhābhyām militvā ekam eva pratyabhijñānam utpāditam iti udghuṣyate
translated: How is it proclaimed that by the two combined, only one recognition is produced?

original: bījakṣityādyostu pṛthak sāmarthyaṃ na dṛṣṭamityekaiva sāmagrītyaṅkuro 'pyeka evāstu /
analyzed: bīja kṣiti ādyoḥ tu pṛthak sāmarthyam na dṛṣṭam iti ekā eva sāmagrī iti aṅkuraḥ pi ekaḥ evā astu
translated: But the power of the seed, earth, etc. is not seen to be separate, so let the collection be one and the sprout also be one.

analyzed: tathā pūrva deśa kāla apara deśa kālābhyām tad saṃbaddhābhyām anya tvāt padyarāgasya abhedaḥ iti api asaṅgatam
translated: Similarly, it is also incoherent to say that the ruby is non-different because it is different from what is connected with a previous place and time and a different place and time.

original: viruddhayordharmayoḥ padmarāgādanyatve 'pi viruddhadharmayogāt padmarāgasya bhedaḥ kathamapahnayate /
analyzed: viruddhayoḥ dharmayoḥ padmarāgāt anya tve pi viruddha dharma yogāt padmarāgasya bhedaḥ katham apahnayate
translated: Even if the ruby is different from the lotus and other things, how can the difference of the ruby be denied due to the connection with contradictory properties?

analyzed: trailokya ekatva prasaṅgasya durvāra tvāt
translated: Because the undesirable consequence of the oneness of the three worlds is unavoidable.

original: na hi dharmadharmiṇoranyatve 'pi brāhmaṇatvacāṇḍālatve ekādhāre bhavitumarhata iti padmarāgasya bhedo duratikramaḥ /
analyzed: na hi dharma dharmiṇoḥ anya tve pi brāhmaṇa tva cāṇḍāla tve eka ādhāre bhavitum arhataḥ iti padmarāgasya bhedaḥ duratikramaḥ
translated: For when the property and the possessor of the property are different, Brahminhood and Chandalahood cannot exist in the same substratum. Thus the difference of the ruby is inescapable.

analyzed: tathā ca na svabhāva virodhaḥ numānasya api aneka tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And thus there is no contradiction in nature, because there would be the undesirable consequence of inference also being many.

analyzed: tat api pratyakṣam apratyakṣam ca avikalpaḥ vikalpaḥ ca asamāropaḥ samāropaḥ ca iti api ayuktam
translated: It is also incorrect to say that it is both perception and non-perception, non-conceptual and conceptual, non-superimposition and superimposition.

analyzed: anumānasya hi paramārthataḥ sva saṃvedana pratyakṣa ātmanaḥ vikalpasya asamāropa svabhāvasya apratyakṣa tva vikalpa tva samāropa tva ādeḥ
translated: For inference, in reality, is of the nature of self-cognition and perception, is non-conceptual, and has the nature of non-superimposition. Its non-perception, conceptuality, superimposition, etc.

original: parāpekṣayā prajñaptatvād viruddhadharmādhyāsābhāvāt kathaṃ bhedasiddhiḥ /🔽sa e vāyamiti tu pratyabhijñānasya sa ityaspaṣṭākārayogitvam /
analyzed: para apekṣayā prajñapta tvāt viruddha dharma adhyāsa abhāvāt katham bheda siddhiḥ  saḥ e vā ayam iti tu pratyabhijñānasya saḥ iti aspaṣṭa ākāra yogi tvam
translated: are designated in relation to others. How can there be establishment of difference due to the absence of the superimposition of contradictory properties?

analyzed: ayam iti spaṣṭa ākāra yogi tvam iti viruddha dharma dvayam bhedakam
translated: But the recognition This is the same has the form of that which is not clear, and the form of this which is clear. Thus, the two contradictory properties are the basis for difference.

original: na caivaṃ vaktavyam tattedantāpekṣayā pratyabhijñānasyāpyekasyaiva pārokṣyāpārokṣyamaviruddhamiti /
analyzed: na ca evam vaktavyam tattedanta apekṣayā pratyabhijñānasya api ekasya eva pārokṣya apārokṣyam aviruddham iti
translated: And one should not say that even for recognition, which is the same, the obscurity and non-obscurity in relation to that and this are not contradictory.

analyzed: na ha udam eka ākāra tayā vyavasthitam
translated: For this is not established as having a single form.

analyzed: yena anumāna vat asya api pārokṣya apārokṣya vyavasthā mātram syāt
translated: By which, like inference, its obscurity and non-obscurity would be merely determined.

original: yāvadatītārthākārānukāro vartamānārthānukāraśca svadharmo na bhavati tāvattadarthagocarataiva nāsti /
analyzed: yāvat atīta artha ākāra anukāraḥ vartamāna artha anukāraḥ ca svadharmaḥ na bhavati tāvat tad artha gocara tā eva na asti
translated: As long as the imitation of the form of the past object and the imitation of the present object are not its own property, there is no engagement with that object at all.

analyzed: kutas pārokṣya apārokṣya vyavahāraḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: How then will there be the convention of obscurity and non-obscurity?

analyzed: tasmāt spaṣṭa aspaṣṭa ākāra dvaya viruddha dharma adhyāsāt pratyabhijñānam
translated: Therefore, because of the superimposition of contradictory properties in the form of clear and unclear, the recognition

analyzed: pratyaya dvayam etat iti sthitam
translated: is established as being two cognitions.

analyzed: tathā sa hetuka vināśa tvāt ayam api asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: Similarly, this reason is also unestablished because of the destruction with a cause.

original: yatpunaratroktam sahetukavināśatvaṃ ghaṭasyāgnidhūmayoriva pratyakṣānupalambhato mudgaraghaṭavināśayorapi kāryakāraṇabhāvasiddhau siddhamiti /
analyzed: yat punar atra uktam sa hetuka vināśa tvam ghaṭasya agni dhūmayoḥ iva pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ mudgara ghaṭa vināśayoḥ api kārya kāraṇa bhāva siddhau siddham iti
translated: What is said here is that the fact of the destruction of the pot having a cause is established by perception and non-apprehension, just as in the case of fire and smoke, when the relation of cause and effect between the hammer and the destruction of the pot is established.

analyzed: tat asaṅgatam
translated: That is irrelevant.

analyzed: agni dhūmayoḥ dvayoḥ api dṛśya tvāt
translated: Because both fire and smoke are visible.

analyzed: pratyakṣa anupalambhataḥ dhūmasya vahni kārya tā sidhyatu
translated: Let the causal nature of smoke be established by perception and non-apprehension.

analyzed: vināśa śabda vācyaḥ tu arthaḥ na kaścid idantayā dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: But no object denoted by the word 'destruction' is seen in this way.

analyzed: karparam eva ghaṭa mudgarābhyām utpadyamānam upalabdham
translated: Only the potsherd is seen arising from the pot and the hammer.

analyzed: yat āhuḥ guravaḥ
translated: As the teachers say:

original: dṛṣṭastāvadayaṃ ghaṭo 'tra ca patan dṛṣṭastathā mudgaro
analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ tāvat ayam ghaṭaḥ ca patan dṛṣṭaḥ tathā mudgaraḥ
translated: This pot is seen falling here and the hammer is seen thus,

original: dṛṣṭā karparasaṃhatiḥ paramato nāśo na dṛṣṭaḥ paraḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭā karpara saṃhatiḥ paramatas nāśaḥ na dṛṣṭaḥ paraḥ
translated: and the collection of potsherds is seen afterwards, but the other, destruction, is not seen at all.

original: tenābhāva iti śrutiḥ kva nihitā kiṃ vātra tatkāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tena abhāvaḥ iti śrutiḥ kva nihitā kim vā atra tad kāraṇam
translated: So where is the word 'non-existence' placed? Or what is the cause of it here?

analyzed: svādhīnā palighasya kevalam iyam dṛṣṭā kapāla āvaliḥ
translated: This mere series of potsherds is seen to be dependent on the pestle.

analyzed: tat ayam abhāvaḥ dṛśya anupalabdhi bādhitaḥ katham pratyakṣataḥ mudgara ādi kāryam avadhāryaḥ
translated: How then can this non-existence, contradicted by the non-apprehension of the visible, be ascertained by perception as the effect of the pestle, etc.?

original: yatpunarasminnadṛśyamāne 'pi dṛśyata iti vāgjālaṃ sā bhaṇḍavidyā /
analyzed: yat punar asmin adṛśyamāne dṛśyate iti vāc jālam sā bhaṇḍa vidyā
translated: But this web of words, that even when this [non-existence] is not seen, it is seen, is a fraud's knowledge.

analyzed: tad vacanāt gṛhṇān api paśuḥ eva tathā hi
translated: Even if one accepts it on his word, one is just an animal. Thus:

analyzed: kasyacid pratibhāsena sādhyate pratibhāsi yat
translated: What is not manifest is proved by the manifestation of something else.

analyzed: pratibhāsaḥ sya na asya iti na upapatteḥ tu gocaraḥ iti
translated: The manifestation is of that, not of this; therefore it is not the object of inference.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: atha evam vaktavyam kim anyena dhvaṃsena
translated: Now, if this is to be said: What is the use of another destruction?

analyzed: karparam eva ghaṭa dhvaṃsaḥ astu
translated: Let the potsherd itself be the destruction of the pot.

original: tathā ca sati mudgarādyabhāve karparābhāvāt ghaṭasthairyamavyāhatamiti /
analyzed: tathā ca sati mudgara ādi abhāve karpara abhāvāt ghaṭa sthairyam avyāhatam iti
translated: And if that is so, then in the absence of the pestle, etc., because of the absence of the potsherd, the stability of the pot is unobstructed.

analyzed: durāśā khalu eṣā
translated: This is indeed a vain hope.

original: tathā hi yathā nāśaśabdena karparamucyate tathā yadyabhāvaśabdenāpi karparamevocyate tadaikatra pradeśe ghaṭamekamapanīya ghaṭāntaranyāse tatrāpanītaghaṭasyābhāvavyavahāro
analyzed: tathā hi yathā nāśa śabdena karparam ucyate tathā yadi abhāva śabdena api karparam eva ucyate tadā ekatra pradeśe ghaṭam ekam apanīya ghaṭa antara nyāse tatra apanīta ghaṭasya abhāva vyavahāraḥ
translated: For thus, if the potsherd is called destruction by the word destruction, and if the potsherd is called non-existence by the word non-existence also, then in one place, having removed one pot, and placing another pot there, the convention of non-existence of the removed pot

analyzed: na syāt
translated: would not be.

analyzed: tad pradhvaṃsa kapālayoḥ tatra anutpādāt  tasmāt yathā apanīta ghaṭasya pracyuti mātra apekṣayā nyasta ghaṭe bhāva vyavahāraḥ tathā
translated: Because the destruction and the pot are not produced there.🔽Therefore, just as for a removed pot, the convention of non-existence is in relation to mere cessation,

analyzed: mudgara ādi kāraṇa abhāvāt pradhvaṃsa karparayoḥ anutpāde pi pracyuti mātra apekṣayā eva pratikṣaṇam anya anya tva vyavahāraḥ
translated: in the same way, even in the absence of causes like a hammer, due to the non-production of destruction and the pot, the convention of momentariness is established in relation to mere cessation itself.

analyzed: ghaṭasya sidhyati iti kutas sthairya siddhiḥ
translated: How then is permanence established?

analyzed: tasmāt pradhvaṃsa karpara abhāve pi pracyuti mātra ātmaka bhāva apekṣayā api asmad matam avyāhatam
translated: Therefore, even in the absence of destruction and the pot, our view is not contradicted even in relation to existence in the form of mere cessation.

analyzed: yat āhuḥ guravaḥ
translated: As the teachers have said:

original: āstāṃ karparapaṃktireva kalaśadhvaṃso na ceyaṃ purā
analyzed: āstām karpara paṃktiḥ eva kalaśa dhvaṃsaḥ na ca iyam purā
translated: Let alone the row of pots, this is not the destruction of the pot before.

original: tena sthairyamapi prasidhyatu tato bhinnena nāśena kim /
analyzed: tena sthairyam api prasidhyatu tatas bhinnena nāśena kim
translated: Therefore, let permanence also be established. What is the use of destruction by another?

analyzed: atra uttaram
translated: Here is the reply:

original: nāśaḥ saiva yathocyate yadi tathābhāvo 'pi kumbhāntar
analyzed: nāśaḥ sā eva yathā ucyate yadi kumbha antar
translated: If destruction is said to be just that, then existence is also like that inside the pot.

analyzed: anyāse bhāva vacaḥ katham matam atas sidhyati abhāvaḥ pi na
translated: How is the statement of non-existence in the case of superimposition? Therefore, non-existence is also established.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: nanu yadi sva hetu janitaḥ nāśaḥ na asti
translated: If destruction is not produced by its own cause,

original: kathaṃ kvacideva deśe kāle ghaṭo naṣṭa iti pratītiniyamaḥ /
analyzed: katham kvacid eva deśe kāle ghaṭaḥ naṣṭaḥ iti pratīti niyamaḥ
translated: How is it that there is the restriction of the cognition that a pot is destroyed only in a certain place and time?

analyzed: na ca mudgarāt anyaḥ nāśasya hetuḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: And the cause of destruction cannot be said to be anything other than the hammer.

original: prāgapi nāśasaṃbhave naṣṭaghaṭabuddhisaṃbhavaprasaṅgāt / yadāhuḥ🔽nāśo nāsti yadi svahetuniyataḥ kiṃ deśakāle kvacit
analyzed: prāk api nāśa saṃbhave naṣṭa ghaṭa buddhi saṃbhava prasaṅgāt yat āhuḥ  nāśaḥ nā asti yadi sva hetu niyataḥ kim deśa kāle kvacid
translated: Because if destruction were possible even before, there would be the contingence of the cognition of a destroyed pot. As it has been said:

original: kumbho naṣṭa iti pratītiniyamastenāsti kāryaśca saḥ /
analyzed: kumbhaḥ naṣṭaḥ iti pratīti niyamaḥ tena asti kāryaḥ ca saḥ
translated: If destruction does not exist, determined by its own cause, why is there the restriction of the cognition 'the pot is destroyed in a certain place and time'? That is its effect.

analyzed: nā api anyat kila kāraṇam rayavataḥ daṇḍāt purā api anyathā
translated: And it is said that there is no other cause than the hammer, otherwise it would be so even before.

original: nāśoktā na kṛtā vinaṣṭaghaṭadhīḥ kenoddhurā vāryate //🔽iti cet / tarhīdānīmarthāpattyā pradhvaṃsaṃ prasādhya mudgarādhīnatvamasya sādhayitumārabdham /
analyzed: nāśa uktā na kṛtā vinaṣṭa ghaṭa dhīḥ kena uddhurā vāryate  iti ced tarhi idānīm arthāpattyā pradhvaṃsam prasādhya mudgara adhīna tvam asya sādhayitum ārabdham
translated: Why is the cognition of a destroyed pot, said to be destroyed, not prevented?🔽If this is so, then having established destruction by presumption, it is begun to be proved that it is dependent on the hammer.

original: tathā ca sati dhūmāgnivat pratyakṣataḥ pradhvaṃsasya mudgarādikāryatvaṃ siddhamityutphullagallamullapitaṃ vyāluptam //
analyzed: tathā ca sati dhūma agni vat pratyakṣataḥ pradhvaṃsasya mudgara ādi kārya tvam siddham iti utphulla gallam ullapitam vyāluptam
translated: And if that is so, then the fact that destruction is the effect of the hammer etc. is established by perception, like smoke and fire. This is uprooted, the boastful talk of one with a swollen throat.

analyzed: na ca arthāpattitaḥ tad siddhiḥ
translated: And it is not established by presumption either.

analyzed: kumbhaḥ naṣṭaḥ iti pratīteḥ anyathā api upapadyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the cognition the pot is destroyed is possible in another way too.

original: vināśaṃ vināpi hi ghaṭadarśanavato mudgarakṛtakapālānubhava evanaṣṭaghaṭāvasāyasādhanaḥ /
analyzed: vināśam vinā api hi ghaṭa darśanavataḥ mudgara kṛta kapāla anubhavaḥ eva naṣṭa ghaṭa avasāya sādhanaḥ
translated: For one who has seen the pot without destruction, the experience of the potsherds produced by the hammer is the means of cognizing the destroyed pot.

analyzed: kim apareṇa nāśena kartavyam
translated: What else is to be done by destruction?

analyzed: ghaṭaḥ naṣṭaḥ iti buddheḥ ghaṭa niścaya pūrvaka mudgara kṛta kapāla anubhava mātra anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāna darśanāt
translated: Because the cognition the pot is destroyed is seen to be concomitant with and contravariant with the mere experience of the potsherds produced by the hammer, preceded by the ascertainment of the pot.

analyzed: na ca iyam sāmagrī pūrvam api asti
translated: And this assemblage does not exist even before.

original: mudgarābhāve karparapaṃkterevābhāvāt kathaṃ prāgapi naṣṭaghaṭabuddhiprasaṅgaḥ saṃgato nāma /
analyzed: mudgara abhāve karpara paṃkteḥ eva abhāvāt katham prāk api naṣṭa ghaṭa buddhi prasaṅgaḥ saṃgataḥ nāma
translated: How can the connection be proper, since the row of potsherds does not exist even before the absence of the hammer? How can the cognition of the destroyed pot be possible even before?

analyzed: yat āhuḥ guravaḥ
translated: As the teachers say:

analyzed: dṛṣṭe mbhobhṛti mudgara ādi janitā dṛṣṭā kapāla āvalī
translated: The row of potsherds is seen to be produced by the hammer etc. on the seen cloud.

analyzed: saṅketa anugamāt vinaṣṭa ghaṭa dhīḥ tāvat samutpādyate
translated: The cognition of the destroyed pot is produced to the extent of following the convention.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

original: sāmagryāmiha nāśanāma na kimapyaṅgaṃ na cāsyāmapi
analyzed: sāmagryām iha nāśa nāma na kim api aṅgam na ca asyām api
translated: In this assemblage, there is nothing at all called destruction, nor would it be in this assemblage.

original: syādeṣā na kadāpi nāpi ca purāpyeṣā samagrā sthitiḥ //
analyzed: syāt eṣā na kadāpi nā api ca purā api eṣā samagrā sthitiḥ
translated: This would never be, nor was this assemblage complete even before.

original: arthāpattirato gatā kṣayamiyaṃ na dhvaṃsasiddhau prabhuḥ // iti //
analyzed: arthāpattiḥ atas gatā kṣayam iyam na dhvaṃsa siddhau prabhuḥ iti
translated: Therefore, this presumption has gone to destruction. It is not the master in establishing destruction.

original: yadi nāśānubhavo nāsti kapālānubhavāt kapālakalpanaiva syāt /
analyzed: yadi nāśa anubhavaḥ nā asti kapāla anubhavāt kapāla kalpanā eva syāt
translated: If there is no experience of destruction, then from the experience of the potsherds, there would be only the imagination of potsherds.

analyzed: na naṣṭa ghaṭa buddhiḥ iti ced
translated: If it be said that there is no cognition of the destroyed pot,

analyzed: tat etat ati sāhasam
translated: this is a great rashness.

analyzed: ghaṭa niścaya pūrvaka kapāla valaya darśanāt eva naṣṭa ghaṭa buddheḥ sākṣāt eva anubhūyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the cognition of the destroyed pot is directly experienced only from the perception of the potsherds and the bracelet, which are preceded by the ascertainment of the pot.

analyzed: tad apalāpe dhūma ādīnām api dahana ādi pūrvakatva niścayaḥ na syāt iti atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: If that is denied, then there would be the over-extension that the ascertainment of the existence of fire, etc. preceded by smoke, etc. would not be possible.

analyzed: nanu ghaṭaḥ naṣṭaḥ iti buddhiḥ viśeṣya buddhiḥ
translated: If it be said that the cognition the pot is destroyed is a cognition of the qualified,

analyzed: sā ca vināśam viśeṣaṇam ākṣipati iti ced
translated: and that it implies destruction as a qualifier,

analyzed: tat asat yatas
translated: that is not correct. Because

analyzed: sva buddhyā rajyate yena viśeṣyam tat viśeṣaṇam
translated: that by which the qualified is delighted by its own cognition is its qualifier.

original: ucyate / na cāvidyamānamadṛśyaṃ vā svabuddhyā kiñcidrañjayati /
analyzed: ucyate na ca avidyamānam adṛśyam vā sva buddhyā kiñcid rañjayati
translated: It is said: and what does not exist or is not seen does not delight anything by its own cognition.

original: prayogo 'trayasya na svarūpanirbhāsastanna kasyacit svānurakta pratītinimittam /
analyzed: na sva rūpa nirbhāsaḥ tat na kasyacid pratīti nimittam
translated: The argument here is: that which does not appear in its own form is not the cause of anyone's cognition that is attracted to itself,

analyzed: yathā karikeśaraḥ
translated: like the hair of an elephant.

analyzed: na asti ca svarūpa nirbhāsaḥ dhvaṃsasya iti vyāpaka anupalabdhiḥ
translated: And the destruction is not perceived in its own form. Thus there is the non-apprehension of the pervader.

analyzed: na asyāḥ asiddhiḥ
translated: This is not unestablished for it.

analyzed: abhāvasya sva rūpeṇa eva idantayā nirbhāsa abhāvāt
translated: Because absence does not appear as itself at all.

analyzed: na ca viruddha tā
translated: And it is not contradictory.

analyzed: sapakṣe bhāvāt
translated: Because it exists in a similar instance.

analyzed: na api anaikāntika tvam
translated: Nor is it inconclusive.

original: pratibhāsābhāve 'pi svānuraktapratītihetutve śaśaviṣāṇāderapi tathātvaṃ syādityatiprasaṅgaḥ / nanu
analyzed: pratibhāsa abhāve pi sva anurakta pratīti hetu tve śaśaviṣāṇa ādeḥ api tathātvam syāt iti atiprasaṅgaḥ nanu
translated: Even in the absence of appearance, if it were the cause of cognition conforming to itself, then even a rabbit's horn would be like that, leading to over-extension. But

original: na dhvaṃsena vinā vinaśyati jagad bhāvena sārdhaṃ sacet
analyzed: na dhvaṃsena vinā vinaśyati jagat bhāvena sārdham saced
translated: If the world does not perish without destruction, but along with existence,

analyzed: sat ca asat ca kim astu vastu niyatam tatas
translated: then let it be existent and non-existent, determined as a thing, born after existence.

analyzed: bhāvāt tena tu bhinna kāraṇa tayā tad kāraṇa asaṃbhave
translated: From existence, therefore, by having a different cause, in the impossibility of its cause,

analyzed: bhāvāt tena kṛta anya tā api galitā bhaṅgaḥ kutas nu kṣaṇam
translated: by that, the difference made by non-existence is also lost. How is there moment-by-moment destruction?

analyzed: atra ucyate kāraṇa antarāt utpadyamānaḥ dhvaṃsaḥ bhinnaḥ bhinnaḥ vā
translated: To this it is said: Destruction arising from another cause is either non-different or different.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ pakṣaḥ  bhinna kāraṇa tvāt
translated: The first position is not so.🔽Because it has a different cause.

analyzed: taiḥ an abhyupagata tvāt ca
translated: And because that is not accepted by them.

analyzed: atha dvitīyaḥ pakṣa
translated: Now, if the second position is accepted,

original: tadā kaḥ punarbhāvasya pradveṣo yena pradhvaṃsākhye vastuni svahetorutpanne nivartate nāma //
analyzed: tadā kaḥ punarbhāvasya pradveṣaḥ yena pradhvaṃsa ākhye vastuni sva hetoḥ utpanne nivartate nāma
translated: then what is the hatred of existence, by which, when a thing called destruction arises from its own cause, it ceases to be?

original: yatpunaretaducyate nābhāvasyotpāde bhāvasyāparā nivṛttiḥ /🔽kiṃ tvabhāvotpattireva tannivṛttiriti /
analyzed: yat punar etat ucyate na abhāvasya utpāde bhāvasya aparā nivṛttiḥ  kim tu abhāva utpattiḥ eva tad nivṛttiḥ iti
translated: As for what is said here, In the arising of non-existence, there is no other cessation of existence.🔽But the cessation of that is precisely the arising of non-existence.

analyzed: katham anyasya utpāde nyasya nivṛttiḥ
translated: How can there be the cessation of one thing in the arising of another?

original: atra svabhāvabhedairuttaraṃ vācyam ye parasparaparihārasthitayaḥ svahetubhyo jāyante /
analyzed: atra svabhāva bhedaiḥ uttaram vācyam ye paraspara parihāra sthitayaḥ sva hetubhyaḥ jāyante
translated: Here, the answer should be given by distinguishing the nature of the two [types of otherness].

original: na hi svato 'nyasyāṅkurasya vahnirna kāraṇamityanyatvāviśeṣād bhasmano 'pi na kāraṇam /
analyzed: na hi svatas nyasya aṅkurasya vahniḥ na kāraṇam iti anya tva aviśeṣāt bhasmanaḥ api na kāraṇam
translated: For fire is not the cause of a sprout that is different from itself, and due to the non-distinction of difference, ash is also not the cause [of a sprout].

analyzed: svabhāva bhedena tu kārya kāraṇa bhāva samarthanam paraspara parihāra sthiti niyame tulyam
translated: But the establishment of the relation of cause and effect by distinguishing the nature [of the two] is the same even in the case of [two things] that are mutually exclusive.

original: yathā cotpādasya purastādakhilasāmarthyarahitasyāṅkuraprāgabhāvasyāpakāraṃ kañcidakurvanto 'pi bījādayo 'ṅkuramārabhamāṇāḥ prāgabhāvaṃ nivartayanti /
analyzed: yathā ca utpādasya purastāt akhila sāmarthya rahitasya aṅkura prāgabhāvasya apakāram kañcid akurvantaḥ pi bīja ādayaḥ ṅkuram ārabhamāṇāḥ prāgabhāvam nivartayanti
translated: And just as seeds and so on, even though not doing any harm to the non-existence of the sprout which is devoid of all ability prior to [the sprout's] production, produce the sprout and remove the non-existence of the sprout.

analyzed: tad utpādasya eva tad prāgabhāva nivṛtti rūpa tvāt  evam tad abhāva hetavaḥ pi bhāva rūpe kiñcitkarā
translated: Because the production of that [sprout] itself has the form of the removal of the non-existence of that [sprout].🔽In the same way, even though the causes of that non-existence do nothing to the existence [of the sprout],

analyzed: api tad abhāvam ādadhānāḥ tat nivartayanti
translated: they establish the non-existence [of the sprout] and remove it.

analyzed: abhāva utpādasya eva bhāva nivṛtti rūpa tvāt
translated: Because the production of the non-existence [of the sprout] itself has the form of the removal of the existence [of the sprout].

analyzed: tena pūrvavat na artha kriyā karaṇa prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, as before, there is no problem of performing a function.

original: taducitaṃ syād yadi kāryakāraṇayorivāsyā pyātmā pramāṇapratītaḥ syāt /🔽kevalaṃ dṛśyānupalambhagraste 'pyetasminnupalabhyata iti pralāpo vyaktamiyaṃ bhaṇḍavidyetyuktam /
analyzed: tat ucitam syāt yadi kārya kāraṇayoḥ iva asyāḥ pi ātmā pramāṇa pratītaḥ syāt  kevalam dṛśya anupalambha graste pi etasmin upalabhyate iti pralāpaḥ vyaktam iyam bhaṇḍa vidyā iti uktam
translated: It would be proper if this [non-existence] were cognized by a means of valid knowledge, like the relation of cause and effect.🔽It is said that this is clearly a false doctrine, as it is only a lament that this [non-existence] is perceived even when it is refuted by the non-perception of the perceptible.

original: arthāpattirapi kṣīṇetyapi prāgabhāvasya ca dṛṣṭāntatvenopanyāso bhaṇḍālekhyanyāyaḥ /
analyzed: arthāpattiḥ api kṣīṇā iti api prāgabhāvasya ca dṛṣṭānta tvena upanyāsaḥ bhaṇḍālekhyanyāyaḥ
translated: It is also said that presumption is exhausted, and the mention of the prior non-existence as an example is the principle of a false record.

analyzed: kim ca kaḥ punar atra virodhaḥ
translated: Moreover, what is the contradiction here?

analyzed: saha sthāna abhāvaḥ yadi tava virodhaḥ rtha vipadoḥ
translated: If the contradiction between the two [existence and non-existence] is the absence of co-existence,

analyzed: saha sthāna āsaṅgaḥ kṣaṇam api yathā śīta śikhinoḥ
translated: The non-connection of co-existence even for a moment, like cold and fire,

original: sa ca dhvaṃso dhvaṃsāntaramupanayan saṃprati bhaved
analyzed: sa ca dhvaṃsaḥ dhvaṃsa antaram upanayan saṃprati bhavet
translated: And if that destruction, bringing about another destruction, were to exist now,

original: virodhī so 'pyanyaṃ kṣayamiti na nāśaḥ kathamapi //
analyzed: virodhī saḥ u pi anyam kṣayam iti na nāśaḥ katham api
translated: That contradiction would also bring about another destruction, so destruction is not in any way.

original: anyathā siddhasattāmātreṇa virodhitve sarvaṃ sarveṇa viruddhaṃ prasajyeta /
analyzed: anyathā siddha sattā mātreṇa virodhi tve sarvam sarveṇa viruddham prasajyeta
translated: Otherwise, if it were to be a contradiction by mere established existence, everything would be contradictory with everything.

analyzed: svabhāva ālambanam api adarśanāt eva nirastam iti  atha anyonya abhāva prakṛtika tayā arthe sataḥ tadā
translated: The object-based [non-existence] is also refuted by non-perception alone.🔽Now, if it exists as an object with the nature of mutual non-existence,

analyzed: kṣayasya eva abhāvaḥ saha bhavatu vā hetu balataḥ
translated: Let the non-existence of destruction itself exist together by the power of the cause.

analyzed: anena dhvaṃse ca prakṛta hatiḥ asya tu anudaye
translated: By this, even in destruction, the negation of the original is not effective,

analyzed: balīyān eva arthaḥ svayam apacaye kim iha
translated: and the stronger meaning is itself in decline, what is the use of another here?

original: saccāsacca kimastu vastviti tu prasaṅgaḥ trilocanaprastāve nirākaraṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: sat ca asat ca kim astu vastu iti tu prasaṅgaḥ trilocana prastāve nirākaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Whether it be real or unreal, let it be an entity - this is a consequence to be refuted in the context of the three-eyed one.

original: ata evātra prastāve bhuvanaikagurūn bhagavataḥ kīrtipādānavamanyamānaḥ śaṅkaraḥ paśorapipaśuriti kṛpāpātramevaiṣa jālmaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva atra prastāve bhuvana eka gurūn bhagavataḥ kīrti pādān avamanyamānaḥ śaṅkaraḥ paśoḥ apipaśuḥ iti kṛpā pātram eva eṣa jālmaḥ
translated: For this very reason, in this context, Shankara, disregarding the revered feet of the sole guru of the world, is indeed a rogue, a mere animal among animals, a fit object of compassion.

analyzed: yat api āha trilocanaḥ bhāva vyatiriktām nivṛttim an icchadbhiḥ aśakyā svarūpa nivṛttiḥ avasthāpayitum
translated: What the three-eyed one says is also this: Those who do not accept cessation separate from existence cannot establish mere cessation of nature.

original: yā hi tasya prāktanī kācidavasthā bhavadbhirarthakriyānirvartanayogyā dṛṣṭā saiva yadyuttarakālamapyanuvartate tarhi svarūpeṇaiva nivṛtto bhāvaḥ
analyzed: yā hi tasya prāktanī kācid avasthā bhavadbhiḥ arthakriyā nirvartana yogyā dṛṣṭā sā eva yadi uttara kālam api anuvartate tarhi sva rūpeṇa eva nivṛttaḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: For whatever prior state of it you have seen to be fit for accomplishing a purpose, if that very [state] continues even after that time, then the existent is ceased in its own nature.

analyzed: katham avasthāpyate
translated: How is it established?🔽At that time, if this so-called destroyed one were to produce some state separate from the nature acquired from its own cause,

original: tadānīmayaṃ naṣṭo nāma yadi svahetupratilabdhasvarūpavyatirekiṇī tasya kācidavasthotpadyeta /
analyzed: tadānīm ayam naṣṭaḥ nāma yadi sva hetu pratilabdha svarūpa vyatirekiṇī tasya kācid avasthā utpadyeta
translated: then it would be established.

original: utpattau saiva tasyātmāntaraṃ jātamityatādavasthyamevāsya vināśaṃ brūmaḥ /
analyzed: utpattau sā eva tasya ātmāntaram jātam iti atādavasthyam eva asya vināśam brūmaḥ
translated: In origination, that very thing is produced as another self. Thus, we say that its non-abiding is its destruction.

original: tādavasthye tādātmye ca svarūpeṇa nivṛtto bhāva ityasya śabdasya satyamarthaṃ na vidmaḥ /
analyzed: tādavasthye tādātmye ca svarūpeṇa nivṛttaḥ bhāvaḥ iti asya śabdasya satyam artham na vidmaḥ
translated: In abiding and identity, we do not know the true meaning of the word cessation of an entity by its own nature.

original: svarūpanivṛttiḥ khalviyaṃ bhavantī bhāva eva syāt /
analyzed: sva rūpa nivṛttiḥ khalu iyam bhavantī bhāvaḥ eva syāt
translated: For this cessation of own nature, being such, would be an entity itself.

analyzed: bhāvāt anyā vā
translated: Or would it be different from an entity?

analyzed: tattve sva kāraṇebhyaḥ niṣpannasya arthasya anyathā anupapattau utpatteḥ ārabhya sattvāt nitya tvam prasajyeta
translated: If so, then the entity produced from its own causes, not being otherwise possible, would be eternal from the time of its origination.

analyzed: anya tve ca tat eva nivṛtteḥ anya tva nivṛttiḥ iti
translated: And if it were different, then that itself would be different from cessation, and the cessation of difference

analyzed: priyam anuṣṭhitam priyeṇa
translated: would be accomplished by the dear one through the dear one.

analyzed: tasmāt utsṛjya vibhramam nāśa utpattiḥ eva naṣṭa tvam abhyupagantavyam iti
translated: Therefore, abandoning delusion, one should accept that origination and destruction itself is the state of having been destroyed.

analyzed: nibandh
translated: Bondage

analyzed: tat etat ajñāna phalam tathā hi
translated: This is the fruit of ignorance. For thus:

analyzed: sva kāraṇāt eva yathā anya deśa vicchinna rūpaḥ samudeti bhāvaḥ
translated: An entity arises from its own cause with a form separated from another place.

analyzed: vicchinna bhinna kṣaṇa vṛttiḥ evam sva kāraṇāt eva na jāyate kim
translated: Why does it not arise from its own cause in the same way with a form separated from different moments?

analyzed: abhāvataḥ ṛtha antara rūpa bādhe tatra api ca artha antaram īkṣaṇīyam
translated: In the negation of an external form due to non-existence, another external thing should also be seen there.

analyzed: pradīpa dṛṣṭānta matam na kāntam sva rūpa saṃdarśana viprayogāt
translated: The lamp analogy is not appealing, because it is incompatible with the manifestation of its own nature.

original: yathā hi deśāntaraparāvṛttamanīlādiparāvṛttaṃ ca svahetorutpannaṃ vastu tathā dvitīyakṣaṇāntaraparāvṛttamapi /
analyzed: yathā hi deśa antara parāvṛttam anīla ādi parāvṛttam ca sva hetoḥ utpannam vastu tathā dvitīya kṣaṇa antara parāvṛttam api
translated: Just as an object arises from its own cause, having changed to another place and having changed from being non-blue, etc., so also it has changed to another second moment.

analyzed: yathā ca anya deśa anavasthāyi tvam tad deśa avasthāyi tvena aviruddham
translated: And just as the impermanence of remaining in another place is not contradictory to remaining in that place,

original: viruddhaṃ ca deśāntarāvasthāyitvenaiva tathā dvitīyakṣaṇāvasthāyitvaṃ prathamakṣaṇāvasthāyitvenāviruddham /
analyzed: viruddham ca deśa antara avasthāyi tvena eva tathā dvitīya kṣaṇa avasthāyi tvam prathama kṣaṇa avasthāyi tvena aviruddham
translated: and is contradictory only to remaining in another place, in the same way, the impermanence of remaining in the second moment is not contradictory to remaining in the first moment,

analyzed: viruddham punar dvitīya kṣaṇa avasthāyi tvena eva
translated: but is again contradictory only to remaining in the second moment.

analyzed: kevalam deśa antara dvitīya kṣaṇayoḥ tat pracyuti mātram vyavahriyate  tad anyonya abhāva pradhvaṃsa abhāvayoḥ padārthayoḥ sadbhāve pi avāryam
translated: Only the mere passing away of that [object] in another place and the second moment is conventionally designated.🔽Even if the existence of the two objects, mutual non-existence and destruction, is accepted, it is undeniable.

analyzed: abhāva antara asvīkāre pi bhāva abhāvayoḥ api amiśra tva asvīkāre tādātmya prasaṅgāt
translated: Even if another type of non-existence is not accepted, if the non-mixing of existence and non-existence is not accepted, there would be the consequence of identity.

analyzed: tasmāt bhāva abhāvayoḥ tādātmyam iti
translated: Therefore, existence and non-existence are identical.

analyzed: yathārtha kriyā kāri tvasya tad deśa varti tva nīla tva ādi bhinna virodhaḥ tathā dvitīya kṣaṇa anavasthāyi tvena api iti vivakṣitam
translated: The intended meaning is that the performance of a function in accordance with reality is contradictory with being different from existing in that place, being blue, etc., and also with not remaining in the second moment.

original: paramārthatastu dharmidharmayostādātmyaṃ vyāvṛttikṛto bhedavyavahāra iti apohasiddhau prasādhitam /
analyzed: paramārthataḥ tu dharmi dharmayoḥ tādātmyam vyāvṛtti kṛtaḥ bheda vyavahāraḥ iti apoha siddhau prasādhitam
translated: But in reality, it has been established in the Apoha Siddhi that the property and the property-possessor are identical, and the convention of difference is made by exclusion.

analyzed: etat ca ukta krameṇa aviruddham āpāditam
translated: And this has been shown to be non-contradictory in the stated order.

original: etāvati tu tattve vākchalamātrapravṛttā dveṣaviṣajvalitātmānaḥ kṣudrāḥ pralapantīti kimatra brūmaḥ /
analyzed: etāvati tu tattve vāc chala mātra pravṛttāḥ dveṣa viṣa jvalita ātmānaḥ kṣudrāḥ pralapanti iti kim atra brūmaḥ
translated: But when it comes to this much of truth, the petty ones, whose minds are inflamed by the poison of hatred, engage in mere verbal trickery and prattle. What can we say about this?

original: tataśca vyatiriktanivṛttyutpattimantareṇa svarūpanivṛtterupapatteḥ kathaṃ kṣaṇādūrdhvaṃ prāktanasattāvasthitiḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca vyatirikta nivṛtti utpattim antareṇa svarūpa nivṛtteḥ upapatteḥ katham kṣaṇāt ūrdhvam prāktana sattā avasthitiḥ
translated: And therefore, since the cessation of one's own nature is possible without the arising of cessation by exclusion, how can there be a prior state of existence after the moment?

analyzed: tasmāt utsṛṣṭa vibhramam naṣṭa vyavahāra mātram astu
translated: Therefore, let there be mere cessation of usage, free from confusion.

analyzed: na tu asya anyat kiñcid jāyeta
translated: But nothing else should be produced from it.

analyzed: bhāvasya tādavasthya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the existent would remain as it is.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ katham niṣidhyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked how non-existence can be negated,

original: na / tadanutpattimātraviṣayasya vācāniścayena ca paścādabhāvavyavahāramātrapravartanasyeṣṭatvād vastūtpattereva niṣiddhatvāt /
analyzed: na tad anutpatti mātra viṣayasya vācā aniścayena ca paścāt abhāva vyavahāra mātra pravartanasya iṣṭa tvāt vastu utpatteḥ eva niṣiddha tvāt
translated: No, because it is accepted that the mere usage of non-existence later is due to the uncertainty of speech about mere non-arising, and because the arising of an entity is itself denied.

analyzed: nanu kā iyam vācoyuktiḥ
translated: But what is this verbal trickery?

analyzed: abhāva vyavahāra mātram iṣyate paścāt na abhāvaḥ iti
translated: It is accepted that the mere usage of non-existence is later, not non-existence.

analyzed: evam sati visaṃvādi tā prasaṅgaḥ bhāva vyavahārasya
translated: If that were so, there would be the consequence of contradiction for the usage of non-existence.

original: abhāvaśca mithyeti bhāva eva pratiṣedhyasya syāt /
analyzed: abhāvaḥ ca mithyā iti bhāvaḥ eva pratiṣedhyasya syāt
translated: And non-existence is false, so the object of negation would be an existent.

analyzed: sa ca abhāvaḥ paścāt
translated: And that non-existence occurs later,

analyzed: bhavati iti sphuṭataram asya kādācitka tvāt sa hetuka tvam
translated: so its occasional nature and causal nature are very clear.

analyzed: vastu tvam ca iti
translated: And it is a real entity.

analyzed: asat etat abhāva ākhya vastu antara asvīkāre pi pracyuti mātra apekṣayā api vyavahārasya caritārtha tva pratipādanāt
translated: This is not so, because even if another real entity called non-existence is accepted, it is shown that the usage is fulfilled even in relation to mere cessation.

analyzed: yat tu tad vivikta bhū tala ādeḥ viṣaya tvam āśaṅkya uktam
translated: But what was said out of doubt about its being the object of the ground devoid of that,

analyzed: na bhū tala ādeḥ vastu antara tvāt
translated: is not so, because the ground is not a different real entity.

original: na ca vastvantare pratipādite pratīte vā ghaṭādi vastubhūtamiti pratipāditaṃ pratītaṃ
analyzed: na ca vastu antare pratipādite pratīte vā ghaṭa ādi vastu bhūtam iti pratipāditam pratītam
translated: And when a different real entity is indicated or cognized, the real entity such as a pot is not indicated or cognized.

analyzed: nibandh vā bhavati
translated: Nor does it become a basis.

original: evaṃ vastvantarameva nāśa iti asmin mate yad dūṣaṇamuktaṃ tat svayameva parihṛtaṃ syāditi /
analyzed: evam vastu antaram eva nāśaḥ iti asmin mate yat dūṣaṇam uktam tat svayam eva parihṛtam syāt iti
translated: Thus, in this view, the refutation stated regarding the view that destruction is a separate entity would be self-refuted.

analyzed: tat api asaṃbaddham
translated: That too is irrelevant.

original: kevalaṃ hi bhūtalamasya viṣaya iti kathaṃ na ghaṭāderabhūtatvabodhaḥ /
analyzed: kevalam hi bhū talam asya viṣayaḥ iti katham na ghaṭa ādeḥ abhūta tva bodhaḥ
translated: How then is the non-existence of the pot, etc. not understood, when only the ground is its object?

original: yaiva hi ghaṭādyapekṣayā kaivalyāvasthā pradeśasya sa eva ghaṭavirahaḥ /
analyzed: yā eva hi ghaṭa ādi apekṣayā kaivalya avasthā pradeśasya saḥ eva ghaṭa virahaḥ
translated: For the state of isolation of the region, in relation to the pot, etc., is itself the absence of the pot.

original: vacanādināpyevaṃ kevalapradeśapratipādane kathamiva na prakṛtaghaṭādyabhāvapratipādanam /🔽kaivalyaṃ cāsahāyapradeśādavyatibhinnameva //
analyzed: vacana ādinā api evam kevala pradeśa pratipādane katham iva na prakṛta ghaṭa ādi abhāva pratipādanam  kaivalyam ca asahāya pradeśāt avyatibhinnam eva
translated: And when only the region is presented by words, etc., how can it not present the absence of the pot, etc. that are present?🔽And isolation is not different from the region without a companion.

original: na ceha ghaṭo nāstīti pratyayasya ghaṭavatyapi pradeśe prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: na ca iha ghaṭaḥ na asti iti pratyayasya ghaṭavati api pradeśe prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And the cognition there is no pot here does not apply even to a region with a pot.

analyzed: sva hetoḥ tathā utpannasya sa ghaṭa pradeśasya kevala pradeśāt anya tvāt
translated: Because the region with a pot, which arises from its own cause, is different from the isolated region.

analyzed: na ca pratyabhijñānataḥ sa ghaṭa aghaṭa pradeśayoḥ ekatvam
translated: And the identity of the region with and without a pot is not due to recognition.

analyzed: pūrvam asya nirākaraṇāt
translated: Because this has been refuted earlier.

analyzed: na ca vināśa hetoḥ asāmarthya vaiyarthya abhidhāne ṅkura ādi hetoḥ api tathā abhidhātum ucitam
translated: And when the incapacity and uselessness of the cause of destruction are stated, it is not proper to state the same for the cause of the sprout, etc.

analyzed: asiddhe hi kārye hetoḥ āśrayaṇam ava artham
translated: For if the effect is not established, the reliance on the reason is meaningless.

analyzed: siddhe ca iyam cintā
translated: And this consideration is when it is established.

original: yadi hetornityo 'nityo vārtho jātaḥ kiṃ nāśakāraṇeneti hetupuraskāreṇaiva pravṛtteḥ /
analyzed: yadi hetoḥ nityaḥ nityaḥ vā arthaḥ jātaḥ kim nāśa kāraṇena iti hetu puraskāreṇa eva pravṛtteḥ
translated: If the effect of the reason is either eternal or non-eternal, what is the use of a cause of destruction? Because it operates only by placing the reason first.

analyzed: na ca evam asiddhe ṅkura ādau kārye śakyam abhidhātum
translated: And it is not possible to say this when the effect such as the sprout is not established.

analyzed: sva rūpasya eva ābhāt tad dharmaka tvāt tad
translated: Because its own nature is not manifested, because it is the property of that,

analyzed: dharmaka tva ādi paryanuyogasya nirviṣaya tvāt
translated: because the objection that it is the property of that and so on is devoid of an object.

analyzed: nanu tvayā api bhāva abhāvayoḥ lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: But you have also stated the difference in the characteristics of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: tat katham eka tvam sarva arthānām
translated: Then how is there oneness of all things?

analyzed: lakṣaṇa bhedāt eva bheda vyavasthā
translated: The determination of difference is only due to the difference in characteristics.

analyzed: ced na bheda vyavasthitiḥ
translated: And if even from that there is no determination of difference,

original: na kasyacit kutaścid bhedavyavasthitirityadvaitaprasaṅga iti cet / na /
analyzed: na kasyacid kutaścid bheda vyavasthitiḥ iti advaita prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: then there is the undesirable consequence of non-duality, because the determination of difference of anything from anything is not possible. If this is argued, it is not so.

original: yo hi naśvarasvabhāvaḥ sa eva nāśoḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ hi naśvara svabhāvaḥ saḥ eva nāśoḥ
translated: For that which has the nature of perishing is indeed destruction.

analyzed: naśyati iti bahula adhikārāt kartari ghañaḥ prasādhanāt
translated: Because of the frequent occurrence of the causative suffix ṇya in the sense of the agent,

analyzed: tam nāśam bhāva svabhāvam icchāmaḥ
translated: we assert that destruction is the nature of an existent thing.

original: naśanaṃ nāśa iti tu prasajyātmā dvidhā kartavyaḥ /
analyzed: naśanam nāśaḥ iti tu prasajya ātmā dvidhā kartavyaḥ
translated: But in the case of naśanam (perishing), the causative suffix ṇya should be used in the sense of the agent.

original: tattvatastāvad vastutvavirahāt tattvānyatvavirahita evāsau bhāvo na bhavatīti tadbhāvaniṣedhamātrapātaṃ tu bhavati kharaśṛṅgādivat /
analyzed: tattvataḥ tāvat vastu tva virahāt tattva anya tva virahitaḥ eva asau bhāvaḥ na bhavati iti tad bhāva niṣedha mātra pātam tu bhavati khara śṛṅga ādi vat
translated: In reality, however, it is devoid of existence, being devoid of identity and difference due to the absence of substantiality. But it is merely the negation of its existence, like the horn of a donkey.

original: saṃvṛtau tu yathā kālabhedena vikalpyamānaḥ kādācitka iva pratibhāti tathā sarvopākhyāviraharūpatayā bhāvādbhinna iva pratibhātīti nāvastutvopalakṣaṇabhedākhyānavirodhaḥ
analyzed: saṃvṛtau tu yathā kāla bhedena vikalpyamānaḥ kādācitkaḥ iva pratibhāti tathā sarva upākhyā viraha rūpa tayā bhāvāt bhinnaḥ iva pratibhāti iti na avastu tva upalakṣaṇa bheda ākhyāna virodhaḥ
