original: tathā kṛtakatvasyānityatvavastutvādibhirabhede kṛtakatvamevānityatvameva vā syādityapi prasaṅgo vaktavya āpadyeta /
analyzed: tathā kṛtaka tvasya anitya tva vastu tva ādibhiḥ abhede kṛtaka tvam eva anitya tvam eva vā syāt iti api prasaṅgaḥ vaktavyaḥ āpadyeta
translated: Similarly, when the fabricated nature is not different from impermanence, substantiality etc., fabricated nature itself would be impermanence, or it would be impermanence only. This consequence should also be stated.

analyzed: sāmānya vyaktyoḥ iva tayoḥ vastutas khaṇḍa ātma tvāt
translated: Just as there is no real difference between the universal and the individual, because of their undivided nature.

analyzed: vyāvṛtti bhedaḥ eva param iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the difference of exclusion alone is supreme,

original: yadyevaṃ prakāśanīlādyorapyayameva kramo jāgartītyekāvaśeṣaprasaṅgo bālapralāpaḥ / tadevaṃ
analyzed: yadi evam prakāśa nīla ādyoḥ api ayam eva kramaḥ jāgarti iti eka avaśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ bāla pralāpaḥ tat evam
translated: if so, this very sequence of the illuminating and the blue etc. is awake, so the consequence of the remainder of one is the prattle of a child. Thus

analyzed: nibandh
translated: binding

analyzed: bāhyam na naśyati bhidā aṇu tayā api sattvāt artha ktriyā viraha saṃkara tā ātma bhede
translated: The external does not perish even by the atom of difference, because of the existence of the self-difference of the mixture of the absence of the function of the object.

original: buddhistu naśyati bhidaiva vidaiva sattvāccitrāpyato na bhidameti kimatra kurmaḥ //
analyzed: buddhiḥ tu naśyati bhidā eva vidā eva sattvāt citrā api atas na bhidam eti kim atra kurmaḥ
translated: But the cognition is destroyed by the very division, and is variegated, therefore what can we do about its non-division?

analyzed: nanu deśa vitāna āptiḥ na ātma antara viyoginaḥ
translated: But the attainment of the expanse of space is not for one who is not separate from another self.

analyzed: deśa vitāna hānau na bhāsaḥ iti api śakyate
translated: If there is a loss of the expanse of space, it is possible to say that there is no light.

analyzed: iti ced
translated: If this is so,

analyzed: na sva ātma antaram anya ātmā sa bāhyasya eva yujyate
translated: the other self is not one's own self, it is proper only for the external.

original: buddheḥ svavittiniṣṭhāyāḥ yaḥ parastasya kā gatiḥ //
analyzed: buddheḥ sva vitti niṣṭhāyāḥ yaḥ paraḥ tasya kā gatiḥ
translated: What is the state of one who is beyond the cognition that is fixed in its own knowledge?

original: hanta tathāpi🔽nīlādivattadekaṃ ca kathametat sametu cet /
analyzed: hanta tathā api  nīla ādi vat tat ekam ca katham etat sametu ced
translated: Well, even so,🔽if it is said that it is one like blue and so on, how can this be consistent?

original: nīlamaṃśāntaraṃ caikaṃ kathaṃ tadbhāti saṅgatam //🔽neṣṭaṃ tadapi cet tarhi kvāṇvantarbhidi bhāsanam /
analyzed: nīlam aṃśa antaram ca ekam katham tat bhāti  na iṣṭam tat api ced tarhi kvāṇu antar bhidi bhāsanam
translated: And how does that blue appear as consistent with another part that is one?🔽If that is not accepted, then where is the appearance contained within the atom?

original: na parīkṣākṣamaṃ cāṇuḥ kutastasya tadā bhidā //
analyzed: na parīkṣā kṣamam ca aṇuḥ kutas tasya tadā bhidā
translated: The atom is not capable of examination, how then is there division for it at that time?

analyzed: mā bhūt avastu bhāvāt ced saḥ u pi ekatva hatau bhavet
translated: If it is said that it should not be due to the non-existence of the object, that would be in the destruction of oneness.

analyzed: nirbhāsāt eka tā siddhau sva vitteḥ vastu tā sthitā
translated: When oneness is established by appearance, the reality of one's own knowledge remains.

analyzed: na pratītyasamutpādaḥ nutpādaḥ vā asya bādhakaḥ
translated: Dependent origination or non-origination is not a refutation of this.

analyzed: eka aneka viyoge sphūrti mātreṇa sattvataḥ
translated: Even in the absence of oneness and manyness, there is existence by mere appearance.

analyzed: kim ca pūrva apara jñānam advaite yat na vidyate
translated: Moreover, the knowledge of past and future does not exist in non-duality.

analyzed: pratītya utpanna tā tasmāt asiddheḥ api asādhanam
translated: Therefore, the non-establishment of dependent origination is also not a proof.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa rūpakam
translated: Non-arising is also inconclusive, as it has the form of neither cause nor effect.

analyzed: hāne pi hetu phalayoḥ sphurat rūpam kva gacchatu
translated: Even if the cause and effect are lost, where does the shining form go?

analyzed: eka aneka tayā vastu vyāptiḥ siddhā yadi kvacid
translated: If the pervasion of existence by one or many is established somewhere,

analyzed: sarva śūnyatva samaye hetuḥ iṣṭa vighāta kṛt
translated: then at the time of the emptiness of everything, the reason is a hindrance to the desired [conclusion].

analyzed: atha loka prasi  dhau ca na sarva loka kalpitam
translated: Or if it is accepted in worldly renown,

original: vastuvyavasthā śaraṇaṃ kiṃ tu mānena saṅgatam //
analyzed: vastu vyavasthā śaraṇam kim tu mānena saṅga tam
translated: then the establishment of existence is not imagined by all the world, but rather is supported by valid cognition.

analyzed: na ca adhyakṣa anumānābhyām anaṅgam kvacid īkṣitam
translated: And by perception and inference, nothing is seen anywhere that is not a part [of the whole].

original: yasya rāśiranekaṃ syānnāpi vastu ca kiñcina //🔽yasya caikataratvābhyāṃ sattvavyāptiḥ sa hanyatām /
analyzed: yasya rāśiḥ anekam syāt na api vastu ca  yasya ca ekatara tvābhyām sattva vyāptiḥ sa hanyatām
translated: For whom there would be a collection of many, nor any existent thing at all.🔽And for whom existence is pervaded by either one or many, let him be refuted.

analyzed: abhrānta vitti mātreṇa sattā vādī tu jitvaraḥ
translated: But the proponent of existence, by mere non-erroneous cognition, is quick to win.

analyzed: samāptaḥ citra advaita prakāśa vādaḥ yam
translated: This exposition of the non-duality of the picture is complete.

analyzed: grāhayam na tasya grahaṇam na
translated: It is not grasped by that which grasps it, nor

analyzed: tena jñāna antara grāhayatā api śūnyaḥ
translated: by another cognition, therefore it is not empty.

original: tathāpi ca jñānamayaḥ prakāśaḥ pratyakṣapakṣastu tavāvirāsīt // 🔽Nibandh // //
analyzed: tathā api ca jñāna mayaḥ prakāśaḥ pratyakṣa pakṣaḥ tu tava āvirāsīt
translated: Nevertheless, the light consisting of knowledge has appeared for you in the form of perception.🔽The Bondage

analyzed: santāna antara dūṣaṇam
translated: The Critique of Other Continuums

analyzed: atha iha prakāśa sahopalambha ādi sādhana balena jaḍa padārtha rāśau apāste nīla pīta ādi aśeṣa padārtha jāte
translated: Now, by the power of the proofs such as the simultaneous apprehension of light, in the mass of inert objects, the entire class of blue, yellow, etc. objects has been refuted,

analyzed: ca sva citta pratibhāsa ātmani svapna māyā ādi vat advaya rūpe siddhe santāna antara sat asat tā nirūpaṇa artham idam ārabhyate
translated: and it has been established that they are of the nature of the appearance in one's own mind, like a dream, an illusion, etc., and are non-dual. In order to determine the existence or non-existence of other continuums, this [discussion] is begun.

analyzed: evam hi kecid āhuḥ
translated: For some say this:

analyzed: asti eva santāna antaram anumāna pratītam  tathā hi icchā citta samanantara vyāhāra vyavahāra ābhāsasya darśanāt tad abhāve ca adarśanāt upalambha anupalambha sādhanam anvaya vyatireka śarīram icchā cittena
translated: Other continuums do exist, as is known through inference.🔽For example, because the appearance of speech and conduct is seen immediately after the mind of desire, and because it is not seen in the absence of that, the means of apprehension and non-apprehension, which have the body of positive and negative concomitance, determine the relation of cause and effect between the appearance of speech, etc. and the mind of desire

analyzed: saha vyāhāra ādi ābhāsasya kārya kāraṇa bhāvam ātma santāne vadhārya icchā cittasya a pratisaṃvedana samaye
translated: in one's own continuum. When the mind of desire is not experienced,

analyzed: vicchinna vyāhāra ādi ābhāsa darśanāt tad kāraṇa bhūtam icchā cittam anumīyamānam santāna antaram eva vyavatiṣṭhate iti
translated: because the appearance of disconnected speech and so on is seen, the desirous mind that is the cause of that is inferred, and it is established as a different continuum.

analyzed: atra idam ālocyate  tat icchā cittam vyāhāra ādi ābhāsasya kāraṇa tayā vyavasthāpyamānam anumātuḥ darśana yogyam atha dṛśya adṛśya viśeṣaṇa anapekṣam icchāmātram
translated: Here this is considered.🔽That desirous mind, which is being established as the cause of the appearance of speech and so on, is either suitable to be seen by the inferrer, or it is mere desire that does not depend on the distinction of being visible or invisible.

analyzed: yat itāvat ādyaḥ vikalpaḥ tadā anumātuḥ darśana yogya tvāt icchā cittasya anumāna kāle nupalabdhiḥ abhāvam eva gamayati iti anupalambha ākhya pratyakṣa bādhita tvāt
translated: If the first alternative is the case, then because the desirous mind is suitable to be seen by the inferrer, its non-apprehension at the time of inference indicates its non-existence. Therefore, being contradicted by perception called non-apprehension,

analyzed: kva anumāna avakāśaḥ tasya
translated: where is there an opportunity for inference?

analyzed: yadi punar icchā cittam anumāna kāle pi anubhūyeta
translated: But if the desirous mind were also experienced at the time of inference,

analyzed: tadā kim asya anumānena
translated: then what is the use of inference for that?

analyzed: atha evam agni dhūmayoḥ tad utpatti siddhi anantaram naga nikuñje dhūmam upalabhamānaḥ na agnim api anuminuyāt  tatra api agneḥ anupalabdhi bādhita tvāt
translated: Or, if it were so, then one who perceives smoke in a mountain ravine after the establishment of its arising from fire would not infer fire either,🔽because that is contradicted by the non-apprehension of fire.

analyzed: upalambhe ca anumāna vaiphalyāt
translated: And because inference would be fruitless if it were apprehended.

analyzed: na evam anumāna samaye deśa viprakarṣavataḥ vahneḥ darśana ayogya tvena dṛśya anupalabdhi virahāt
translated: No, because at the time of inference, fire, which is far away in space, is not suitable to be seen, so the non-apprehension of the visible is absent.

analyzed: adṛśya anupalambhasya ca abhāva sādhana tva virodhāt
translated: And because the non-apprehension of the invisible contradicts being a proof of non-existence.

analyzed: icchā cittasya tu na asti deśa viprakarṣaḥ
translated: But there is no remoteness in space for the desirous mind.

analyzed: icchā cittam hi su asaṃbaddham eva anumātuḥ darśana yogyam
translated: For the desirous mind, which is connected with itself, is suitable to be seen by the inferrer.

analyzed: tasya ca deśa ādi viprakarṣaḥ iti alaukikam etat
translated: And that has remoteness in space, etc., so this is not ordinary.

analyzed: atha dvitīyaḥ vikalpaḥ
translated: Now, if the second alternative is accepted.

analyzed: tathā hi icchā citta mātram sva para santāna sādhāraṇa dṛśya adṛśya viśeṣaṇa anapekṣam vyāhāra ādi ābhāsam prati kāraṇatayā avadhāryate
translated: Thus, the mere desirous mind, without regard to the specific visible or invisible common to one's own and others' continua, is ascertained as the cause of the appearance of speech, etc.

analyzed: tad avadhāraṇam kena pramāṇena
translated: By what means of valid cognition is that ascertainment made?

analyzed: vyāhāra ādi ābhāsasya hi icchā mātra abhāve bhāvam pratītya tad utpatti siddhi gaveṣaṇā
translated: For the appearance of speech, etc., upon realizing its absence in the absence of mere desire, the investigation of the establishment of its arising is undertaken.

original: na cecchāmātrasya svaparasantānasādhāraṇasya svasaṃvedanenānyena vābhāvaḥ śakyāvagamaḥ /
analyzed: na ca icchā mātrasya sva para santāna sādhāraṇasya sva saṃvedanena anyena vā abhāvaḥ śakya avagamaḥ
translated: And the absence of mere desire, common to one's own and others' continua, cannot be understood by self-awareness or any other means.

original: yathā hi vahnimātrasya deśakālavyavahitasyāpi dhūmotpādadeśakālayoryadi syādupalabhyetaiva mayeti saṃbhāvitasyānumātṛpuruṣendriyapratyakṣeṇa
analyzed: yathā hi vahni mātrasya deśa kāla vyavahitasya api dhūma utpāda deśa kālayoḥ yadi syāt upalabhyeta eva mayā iti saṃbhāvitasya anumātṛ puruṣa indriya pratyakṣeṇa
translated: For, even if a fire, separated in space and time, were to exist at the place and time of the production of smoke, it would certainly be perceived by the sense-perception of the inferring person who entertains the possibility [of its existence].

original: Nibandh dhūmotpādāt prāgabhāve 'vadhāryamāṇastadutpattisiddhimadhyāsayatīti vyavahitadeśakālasyāpi vahnerdhūmamātraṃ prati kāraṇatvāvadhāraṇam /
analyzed: dhūma utpādāt prāgabhāve adhāryamāṇaḥ tad utpatti siddhim adhyāsayati iti vyavahita deśa kālasya api vahneḥ dhūma mātram prati kāraṇatva avadhāraṇam
translated: The smoke produced after the ascertainment of the prior non-existence of smoke causes the ascertainment of the existence of its production. Thus, even a fire separated in space and time is ascertained as the cause of mere smoke.

original: svabhāvaviprakṛṣṭasya tu jaṭharabhavādisādhāraṇasya sarvathānumātṛpuruṣāśakyābhāvapratītikasya vyāptibahirbhāva eva /🔽tathātrāpīcchācittaṃ parasantānasādhāraṇamapi yāvadyadīya syādupalabhyetaiva mayeti yadi saṃbhāvayituṃ śakyeta tadā tadvyatirekasiddhidvāreṇa
analyzed: svabhāva viprakṛṣṭasya tu jaṭhara bhava ādi sādhāraṇasya sarvathā anumātṛ puruṣa aśakya abhāva pratītikasya vyāpti bahirbhāvaḥ eva  tathā atra api icchā cittam para santāna sādhāraṇam api yāvat syāt upalabhyeta eva mayā iti yadi saṃbhāvayitum śakyeta tadā tad vyatireka siddhi dvāreṇa
translated: But in the case of what is remote in nature, common to the stomach and other [causes], which is entirely beyond the capacity of the inferring person to cognize its non-existence, it is simply outside the pervasion.

analyzed: kāraṇatayā avadhāryate
translated: Similarly, here also, even the desire-mind common to the continuum of another, if it could be entertained as something that would certainly be perceived by me if it were to exist, then it is ascertained as the cause by the means of establishing its absence from that [perceiver].

analyzed: kevalam svabhāva viprakṛṣṭe cittamātre stamitā iyam kathā iti
translated: It is simply that this story is lost in the mere mind that is remote in nature.

analyzed: na ca para cittam kāla viprakṛṣṭam vartamāna tvāt asya
translated: And the other's mind is not remote in time, because it is present.

analyzed: atīta anāgatayoḥ eva kāla viprakṛṣṭa tvena vyavahārāt
translated: Because there is usage in terms of time being distant for only the past and future.

original: nāpi deśaviprakṛṣṭam /🔽yasminneva hi śuklaśaṅkhādideśe svacittaṃ śuklākārapratibhāsi svasaṃvedanena vedyate taddeśavartyeva pītākārapratibhāsi parasantānabhāvi cittaṃ
analyzed: na api deśa viprakṛṣṭam  yasmin eva hi śukla śaṅkha ādi deśe sva cittam śukla ākāra pratibhāsi sva saṃvedanena vedyate tad deśa varti eva pīta ākāra pratibhāsi para santāna bhāvi cittam
translated: Nor is it distant in space.

analyzed: na vedyate
translated: For in the very place where the white conch, etc., are, the mind appearing as the form of white is known by self-awareness, and the mind appearing as the form of yellow belonging to another continuum is not known to exist in that very place.

analyzed: tat katham eṣa deśa viprakarṣaḥ
translated: So how is there this distance in space?

analyzed: atha icchā citta mātram sva saṃvedana mātra apekṣayā na svabhāva viprakṛṣṭam
translated: If, on the other hand, the desiring mind is not distant in nature in relation to self-awareness alone,

original: na hyagnirapyeko yenaivendriyavijñānena dṛśyate tenaivānyo 'pi dṛśyam /
analyzed: na hi agniḥ api ekaḥ yena eva indriya vijñānena dṛśyate tena eva dṛśyam
translated: then fire is also not one, for by the same sense consciousness that one is seen, another is also seen.

original: tatra yathā cakṣurvijñānamātrāpekṣayā agnimātraṃ dṛśyamiti vyavasthāpyate tathātrāpi svasaṃvedanamātrāpekṣayā icchācittamātraṃ svaparasantānasādhāraṇamapi
analyzed: tatra yathā cakṣuḥ vijñāna mātra apekṣayā agni mātram dṛśyam iti vyavasthāpyate tathā atra api sva saṃvedana mātra apekṣayā icchā citta mātram sva para santāna sādhāraṇam api
translated: Just as fire is established as seen in relation to eye consciousness alone, so here also, in relation to self-awareness alone, the desiring mind, common to one's own and other continuums,

analyzed: dṛśyam eva iti
translated: is seen.

original: atrocyate / kimatra mātraśabdenānumātṛpuruṣasaṃbandhāsaṃbandhābhyāmaviśeṣitaṃ yasya kasyacit puruṣasyendriyajñānaṃ vastuviṣayīkurvāṇamasya
analyzed: atra ucyate kim atra mātra śabdena anumātṛ puruṣa saṃbandha asaṃbandhābhyām aviśeṣitam yasya kasyacid puruṣasya indriya jñānam vastu viṣayīkurvāṇam asya
translated: To this we reply: What is meant by the word 'only' here is that the sense-perception of any person whatsoever, not qualified by the connection or non-connection with the inferring person, when making the object its object,

analyzed: dṛśya tā saṃbhave pinā nimitam abhimatam
translated: is not accepted as having no cause, even if the possibility of being seen is not present.

analyzed: yadi evam piśāca ādiḥ api dṛśyaḥ syāt
translated: If it were so, even a ghost would be visible.

original: so 'pi hi kasyacit puṃso yogyādeḥ svajātīyasya vā piśācāntarasya bhavatyevendriyajñānagocara iti na kaścit svabhāvaviprakṛṣṭaḥ syāt /
analyzed: saḥ u pi hi kasyacid puṃsaḥ yogi ādeḥ sva jātīyasya vā piśāca antarasya bhavati eva indriya jñāna gocaraḥ iti na kaścid svabhāva viprakṛṣṭaḥ syāt
translated: For that also is indeed the sphere of sense-perception for some person, such as a yogi, or for another ghost of the same species. Thus nothing would be inherently remote.

original: tasmādanumātṛpuruṣasaṃbandhitvamanapāsya vijñānasya svalakṣaṇādibhedanirāsapara eva mātraśabdo yuktaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt anumātṛ puruṣa saṃbandhi tvam an apāsya vijñānasya sva lakṣaṇa ādi bheda nirāsa paraḥ eva mātra śabdaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word 'only' is rightly taken to exclude the difference of specific characteristics etc. of consciousness, without setting aside its connection with the inferring person.

analyzed: etat eva āśaṅkaya dharmottareṇa abhihitam
translated: Fearing just this, it has been stated by Dharmottara:

analyzed: eka pratipattra apekṣam ca idam pratyakṣa lakṣaṇam
translated: And this definition of perception depends on a single cognizer.

original: ityādi / tenaivaṃ dṛśyatāsaṃbhāvanā yadīha deśe kāle vā syād ghaṭādirniyamenopalabhyeta /
analyzed: ityādi tena evam dṛśya tā saṃbhāvanā yadi iha deśe kāle vā syāt ghaṭa ādiḥ niyamena upalabhyeta
translated: Thus, the possibility of being seen is as follows: If a pot etc. were here in this place or time, it would certainly be perceived.

analyzed: madīyasya cakṣuḥ vijñāna mātrasya viṣayībhavet iti
translated: It would become the object of my mere visual consciousness.

analyzed: para citte tu na śakyam evam
translated: But in the case of another's mind, it is not possible to say this.

original: yadīha paracittaṃ syāt niyamena madīyasya svasaṃvedana🔽mātrasya viṣayi syāditi //
analyzed: yadi iha para cittam syāt niyamena madīyasya sva saṃvedana  mātrasya viṣayi syāt iti
translated: If there were another's mind here, it would certainly be the object of my mere self-awareness.

analyzed: yadi ca icchā citta mātram tad utpatti grahaṇa samaye dṛśya tayā saṃbhāvayitavyam
translated: If it were mere desire-mind, it should be conceived as visible at the time of grasping its arising.

original: tadānumānakāle 'pi dṛśyatayā saṃbhāvya tadanupalambhenābhāvasādhane kathamanumānaṃ pravartayitumidamārabdham /
analyzed: tadā anumāna kāle pi dṛśya tayā saṃbhāvya tad anupalambhena abhāva sādhane katham anumānam pravartayitum idam ārabdham
translated: Then, even at the time of inference, it would be conceived as visible. How could inference be started by establishing its non-existence through non-apprehension of it?

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa eva pakṣa bādhāt
translated: Because the thesis is contradicted by perception itself.

analyzed: na ca kāla bhedena svabhāva viprakarṣa itarau iti yat kiñcid etat
translated: And it is not the case that there is a difference in time or a difference in nature. This is just something.

analyzed: tasmāt icchā citta mātrasya sva para santāna sādhāraṇasya dṛśya tayā saṃbhāvayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Therefore, because mere desire-mind, which is common to one's own and others' continua, cannot be conceived as visible,

analyzed: vyahāra ādi utpādāt prāk anupalambhe pi abhāva siddhau na tad abhāva prayuktaḥ vyāhāra ādi abhāvaḥ
translated: even though it is not apprehended before the production of worldly conventions, when its non-existence is established, the non-existence of worldly conventions and so on, which is caused by its non-existence,

analyzed: pratīyate iti katham kāraṇatva siddhiḥ yatas kārya hetu dvāreṇa anumīyeta
translated: is not understood. How then is the establishment of causality accomplished, from which it would be inferred through the means of the effect-reason?

analyzed: icchā citta viśeṣaḥ tu sva santāna bhāvī na bhavati eva anumātuḥ dṛśyaḥ
translated: But a particular desire-mind that exists in one's own continuum is not at all visible to the inferrer.

original: kiṃ tu tasya dṛśyānupalambhājjijñāsitaviśeṣe dharmiṇi bādhitasya kathamanumānamityuktameva // 🔽Nibandh
analyzed: kim tu tasya dṛśya anupalambhāt jijñāsita viśeṣe dharmiṇi bādhitasya katham anumānam iti uktam eva  nibandh
translated: But how can it be an inference when it is contradicted in the subject whose specific property is being investigated due to the non-apprehension of what is perceptible? This has already been stated.

analyzed: tat evam icchā citta viśeṣe sva santāna bhāvini sādhye pakṣasya pratyakṣa bādhaḥ
translated: Thus, in the case of the probandum being a particular mental state of desire belonging to one's own continuum, there is contradiction by perception of the subject.

original: icchācittamātre 'pi svaparasantānasādhāraṇe sādhye yadyanupalambhamātreṇa dṛśya viśeṣaṇānapekṣeṇa pratibandhasiddhisamaye tasyābhāvaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: icchā citta mātre sva para santāna sādhāraṇe sādhye yadi anupalambha mātreṇa dṛśya viśeṣaṇa anapekṣeṇa pratibandha siddhi samaye tasya abhāvaḥ pratīyate
translated: Even in the case of the probandum being mere mental state of desire common to one's own and others' continua, if its absence is cognized at the time of establishing the relation by mere non-apprehension without regard to the qualification of what is perceptible,

original: tadā pakṣīkṛte dharmiṇi tatheti sa eva doṣaḥ /🔽atha na pratīyate tadā sandigdhavyatireko hetvābhāso vyāhārādiriti sthitam /
analyzed: tadā pakṣīkṛte dharmiṇi tathā iti saḥ eva doṣaḥ  atha na pratīyate tadā sandigdha vyatirekaḥ hetvābhāsaḥ vyāhāra ādiḥ iti sthitam
translated: then the same fault applies to the subject that has been made the subject, as it is in that way.🔽But if it is not cognized, then it is a fallacious reason with a doubtful negative example, due to speech and so on. This is the established position.

original: evaṃ tarhi santānāntarasādhakasyābhāvād bādhakasyāpi kasyacidadarśanādbhavatu tatra sandeha eveti kecit /
analyzed: evam tarhi santāna antara sādhakasya abhāvāt bādhakasya api kasyacid adarśanāt bhavatu tatra sandehaḥ evā iti kecid
translated: In that case, since there is no proof of another continuum and no apparent contradiction, let there be doubt in that case, some say.

analyzed: taiḥ idam bādhakam abhidhīyamānam avadhīyatām
translated: Let them listen to this contradiction being stated by them.

original: yadi hi santānāntaraṃ saṃbhavet tadā tato bhedena svasantānasyāvaśyaṃ bhavitavyam /
analyzed: yadi hi santāna antaram saṃbhavet tadā tatas bhedena sva santānasya avaśyam bhavitavyam
translated: If another continuum were possible, then it would necessarily be different from it, belonging to one's own continuum.

original: anyathā svasantānādapi prakāśamānāttasya parasantānābhimatasya bhedo na syāt /
analyzed: anyathā sva santānāt api prakāśamānāt tasya para santāna abhimatasya bhedaḥ na syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would not be different from what appears in one's own continuum, which is accepted as another's continuum.

original: na cābhedastayoriti svasantānād bhedābhedābhyāmabādhyasya parasantānasya sāmānyaśaśaviṣāṇādivadabhāva evāyāta iti kathaṃ sandehaḥ /
analyzed: na ca abhedaḥ tayoḥ iti sva santānāt bheda abhedābhyām abādhyasya para santānasya sāmānya śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat abhāvaḥ eva āyātaḥ iti katham sandehaḥ
translated: And there is no non-difference between the two. Thus, the other continuum, which is not contradicted by difference and non-difference from one's own continuum, comes to be non-existent, like a general or a rabbit's horn. How then is there doubt?

analyzed: tasmāt para santāna apekṣayā sva santānasya bhedaḥ api avaśyambhāvyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the difference of one's own continuum in relation to another's continuum must necessarily exist.

original: sa ca bhedaḥ santānasya svabhāvaḥ svasantāne pratibhāsamāne niyamena pratibhāseta /
analyzed: sa ca bhedaḥ santānasya svabhāvaḥ sva santāne pratibhāsamāne niyamena pratibhāseta
translated: And that difference is the nature of the continuum. It would necessarily appear when one's own continuum appears.

analyzed: katham aparathā pratibhāna apratibhāna lakṣaṇa viruddha dharma adhyāse pi sva santānasya para santānāt bhedaḥ svabhāva tām āsādayet
translated: Otherwise, how could the difference of one's own continuum from another's continuum attain the nature of being different, even when contradictory properties such as appearance and non-appearance are superimposed?

analyzed: na ca asau bhedaḥ pratibhāsate
translated: And that difference does not appear.

original: bhedapratibhāse hi upagamyamāne tadavadhibhūtasyāpi parasantānasya pratibhāso durapahnavaḥ syāt /
analyzed: bheda pratibhāse hi upagamyamāne tad avadhi bhūtasya api para santānasya pratibhāsaḥ durapahnavaḥ syāt
translated: For if the appearance of difference is accepted, then the appearance of the other continuum, which is its limit, would be unavoidable.

analyzed: asmāt bhinnam iti idam ced svarūpam svasya cetasaḥ
translated: If this is the nature of one's own mind as different from that,

original: sāvadherasya bhāsaḥ syānna vā grāhyaṃ tadātmanā //
analyzed: sa avadheḥ asya bhāsaḥ syāt na vā grāhyam tad ātmanā
translated: The light of this [consciousness] would be limited, or it should not be grasped by itself.

analyzed: bhede na eti kutas bhinnaḥ
translated: In difference, not even a trace of the other is found, so how can it be different?

analyzed: evamādikam aśeṣam iha pravacana pradīpa śrī sa ākāra saṅgraha ādi vacanam anusmaryatām
translated: Remember all this and more, such as the words of the glorious Śākyamitra in the Commentary on the Illuminating Lamp of the Esoteric Communion Tantra.

original: yathā hi svasantānamātre parisphurati śaśaviṣāṇādasphurato na bhedaḥ pratibhāti tathā parasantānādapi sphuraṇavirahiṇo na bhātyeva bhedaḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi sva santāna mātre parisphurati śaśaviṣāṇāt asphurataḥ na bhedaḥ pratibhāti tathā para santānāt api sphuraṇa virahiṇaḥ na bhāti eva bhedaḥ
translated: Just as the difference does not appear between a horn of a rabbit and what shines forth only in one's own continuum, so the difference does not appear between what is devoid of shining forth and what shines forth from another continuum.

original: na hi parasantānāpekṣayā kaścid viśeṣaleśaḥ svasantānasya parisphurati yo nāsti śaśaviṣāṇāpekṣayā /
analyzed: na hi para santāna apekṣayā kaścid viśeṣa leśaḥ sva santānasya parisphurati yaḥ nā asti śaśa viṣāṇa apekṣayā
translated: For no trace of a difference whatsoever appears in one's own continuum in relation to another continuum, which does not exist in relation to a horn of a rabbit.

original: na ca śaśaviṣāṇaparasantānāvapekṣya samāne svasantānapratibhāse śaśaviṣāṇāpekṣayā na bhedo nāpyabhedaḥ pratibhāti /
analyzed: na ca śaśa viṣāṇa para santānau apekṣya samāne sva santāna pratibhāse śaśa viṣāṇa apekṣayā na bhedaḥ na api abhedaḥ pratibhāti
translated: And the difference does not appear in the same shining forth of one's own continuum in relation to a horn of a rabbit and another continuum, nor does the non-difference appear.

original: parasantānāpekṣayā tu bheda eva bhātītyevamavasthāpayituṃ śakyam /
analyzed: para santāna apekṣayā tu bhedaḥ eva bhāti iti evam avasthāpayitum śakyam
translated: But it is possible to establish that the difference appears in relation to another continuum.

original: bhedābhedayorabhāvaparihāreṇa hi yathā bhedo vyavasthitaḥ tadvad bhedapratibhāso 'pi bhedābhedābhāvapratibhāsavilakṣaṇa evocito bhavitum /
analyzed: bheda abhedayoḥ abhāva parihāreṇa hi yathā bhedaḥ vyavasthitaḥ tadvat bheda pratibhāsaḥ api bheda abheda abhāva pratibhāsa vilakṣaṇaḥ eva ucitaḥ bhavitum
translated: For just as difference is established by the exclusion of non-difference, in the same way, the appearance of difference should also be different from the appearance of non-difference and non-difference.

original: na ca tathānubhūyate /🔽tathāpi bhedaḥ pratibhātīti vacanaracanametat /
analyzed: na ca tathā anubhūyate  tathā api bhedaḥ pratibhāti iti vacana racanam etat
translated: But it is not experienced in that way.🔽Nevertheless, this statement is made that difference appears.

analyzed: bhāṣyakāra nyāyaḥ u pi atra bheda pratibhāsa dūṣaṇe vistarataḥ vagantavyaḥ  nibandh
translated: The reasoning of the commentator should also be understood in detail here in the refutation of the appearance of difference.

analyzed: yadi ca avadhi pratibhāsa virahe bheda pratibhānam idam para citta anukampayā
translated: If, even in the absence of the appearance of the limit, this appearance of difference is to be accepted out of compassion for the minds of others,

analyzed: kṣamitavyam tarhi
translated: then

analyzed: bahis arthasya api katham abhāvaḥ sidhyati
translated: how can the non-existence of external objects be established?

analyzed: śakyam hi tatra api sandeham avatārayitum
translated: For doubt can also be introduced there:

analyzed: na bahis arthaḥ kasyacid ābhāsate
translated: No external object appears to anyone.

analyzed: para santānaḥ tu parasya pratibhāsate eva
translated: But another's continuum appears to another.

original: tataścātraiva sandeho na bahirartha iti cet /
analyzed: tatas ca atra eva sandehaḥ na bahis arthaḥ iti ced
translated: Therefore, doubt is only about this, not about external objects.

analyzed: etat api sakalam sandigdham eva
translated: All of this is doubtful.

analyzed: na hi avaśyam para santānaḥ parasya ābhāsate
translated: For another's continuum does not necessarily appear to another.

original: kadācidasau nāstyeva na cāsāvavabhāsata ityapi vaktuṃ śakteḥ /
analyzed: kadācid asau nā asti eva na ca asau avabhāsate iti api vaktum śakteḥ
translated: It is also possible to say that sometimes it does not exist at all and does not appear.

original: kiṃ ca mā nāma bhāsīṣṭa bahirarthaḥ kasyacidapi tathāpi kathaṃ tadabhāvasiddhirbhedapratibhāsābhyupagamavādina itīyanmātramiha vivakṣitam /
analyzed: kim ca mā nāma bhāsīṣṭa bahis arthaḥ kasyacid api tathā api katham tad abhāva siddhiḥ bheda pratibhāsa abhyupagama vādinaḥ iti iyat mātram iha vivakṣitam
translated: Moreover, let it not appear to anyone that an external object exists. Even so, how can the establishment of its non-existence be accepted by one who admits the appearance of difference? This much is intended here.

original: na cātra kaścid doṣaḥ /🔽tasmād bahirarthena sādhāraṇaṃ santānāntaramiti kathaṃ vijñaptivādināmapi saṃmataṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: na ca atra kaścid doṣaḥ  tasmāt bahis arthena sādhāraṇam santāna antaram iti katham vijñapti vādinām api saṃmatam bhaviṣyati
translated: And there is no fault in this.🔽Therefore, how can it be accepted even by the Vijñānavādins that the other continuum is common to the external object?

original: kiṃ ca kāryakāraṇabhāvo 'pi vijñānadvayasya bhedapratibhāsavādinā bādhitumaśakyaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ vijñāna dvayasya bheda pratibhāsa vādinā bādhitum aśakyaḥ
translated: Moreover, the relation of cause and effect between the two cognitions cannot be denied by one who admits the appearance of difference.

original: pūrvabhāvinī hi saṃvittiḥ parasaṃvittyapekṣayā bhedaṃ pūrvatvaṃ cātmano gṛhṇātyevāvadhipratibhāsavigame 'pi //
analyzed: pūrva bhāvinī hi saṃvittiḥ para saṃvitti apekṣayā bhedam pūrva tvam ca ātmanaḥ gṛhṇāti eva avadhi pratibhāsa vigame pi
translated: For the prior cognition grasps the difference and priority of itself in relation to the subsequent cognition, even in the absence of the appearance of the limit.

original: parabhāvinyapi saṃvittiḥ pūrvasaṃvittyapekṣayā bhedaṃ paratvaṃ cātmano 'dhigacchatyeva
analyzed: para bhāvinī api saṃvittiḥ pūrva saṃvitti apekṣayā bhedam paratvam ca ātmanaḥ dhigacchati eva
translated: And the subsequent cognition also ascertains the difference and posteriority of itself in relation to the prior cognition,

analyzed: santāna antara vat iti niyata pūrva apara bhāva lakṣaṇe kārya kāraṇa bhāve vabhāsamāne vasīyamāne
translated: just like a different continuum. Thus, when the relation of cause and effect characterized by the definite prior and posterior existence appears and is ascertained,

analyzed: ca nīla ādi citra ākāra vat katham
translated: How can it be like the variegated form of blue etc.?

analyzed: saṃvṛttyāḥ tu yathā tathā
translated: But let it be so conventionally.

original: iti bhagavato vārtikakārasya vacanena phalitamatra mate /
analyzed: iti bhagavataḥ vārtikakārasya vacanena phalitam atra mate
translated: Thus, the conclusion in this view is stated by the words of the revered Vārtikakāra (i.e. Patañjali).

analyzed: api ca citra ākāra cakre dharmiṇi advaita sādhana artham upanyastasya prakāśamāna tva ādi hetoḥ bheda grāhaka pratyakṣa apahṛta viṣaya tvam udbhāvayataḥ
translated: Moreover, when the reason of being manifest etc. is presented for the purpose of proving non-duality in the subject which is a variegated wheel of forms, by one who points out that it has a subject matter taken away by perception which grasps difference,

original: prativādino bhedagrahaṇamanumanyamānena santānāntarasandehaṃ ca vinā kathamuttaritavyaṃ bhavatā //
analyzed: prativādinaḥ bheda grahaṇam anumanyamānena santāna antara sandeham ca vinā katham uttaritavyam bhavatā
translated: how can you, accepting the grasping of difference, answer without admitting doubt about another continuum?

analyzed: nanu evam api santāna antara abhāvaḥ kena pramāṇena siddhaḥ
translated: Even so, by what means of valid knowledge is the absence of another continuum established?

analyzed: na tāvat pratyakṣeṇa
translated: Not by perception.

analyzed: tasya vidhi viṣayasya pratiṣedha sādhanāt adhikārāt
translated: Because it is not the province of perception, which has a positive object, to establish a negative.

analyzed: na api anumānena
translated: Nor by inference.

analyzed: tasya dṛśya abhāva sādhana niyatasya atīndriya para citta abhāva sādhane nava tārāt iti ced
translated: Because inference, which is restricted to establishing the absence of what is visible, cannot establish the absence of another's mind which is beyond the senses. If this is argued,

original: atra brūmaḥ /🔽santānāntarasaṃbhave niyatabhāvaḥ tatao bhedaḥ svacittasya /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ  santāna antara saṃbhave niyata bhāvaḥ tatas bhedaḥ sva cittasya
translated: we say this.🔽The difference of one's own mind is necessarily existent if another continuum exists.

analyzed: abhede sva santānāt para santānaḥ eva syāt
translated: If there were no difference, the other continuum would be just one's own continuum.

original: yathā ca yadupalabhyamānaṃ yenaṃ rūpeṇa na bhāsate na tat tena rūpeṇa sadvyavahārayogyaṃ yathā nīlaṃ pītarūpeṇa /
analyzed: yathā ca yat upalabhyamānam yena idam rūpeṇa na bhāsate na tat tena rūpeṇa sat vyavahāra yogyam yathā nīlam pīta rūpeṇa
translated: And whatever is perceived does not appear in a certain form, it is not fit to be spoken of as existent in that form, as blue does not in the form of yellow.

analyzed: na upalabhyate ca sva cittam upalabhyamānam para santānāt bhinnena
translated: And the perceived mind is not perceived as different from another's continuum

analyzed: rūpeṇa iti bhedasya sva citta tādātmya niṣedhe dṛśya viśeṣaṇa prayoga anapekṣā svabhāva anupalabdhiḥ iyam
translated: in form. Thus, in the negation of difference as the same nature as one's own mind, this is a non-apprehension of own nature, not requiring the use of a qualifying term for the visible.

analyzed: na api asiddhiḥ
translated: Nor is it unestablished.

analyzed: bheda pratibhāse tad avadheḥ api pratibhāsa prāpteḥ
translated: Because even the limited is attained as appearing in the appearance of difference.

original: avadhyapratibhāse tu bhedapratibhāsābhāvaḥ śaśaviṣāṇabhedapratibhāsābhāvavat siddha eva /
analyzed: avadhya pratibhāse tu bheda pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ śaśaviṣāṇa bheda pratibhāsa abhāva vat siddhaḥ eva
translated: But in the appearance of the unlimited, the appearance of difference is absent, just as the appearance of difference from a rabbit's horn is absent. It is established.

original: evamanena pramāṇena santānāntarasya svacittāpekṣayā bhede pratikṣipte abhede ca svayamevāsaṃbhavini bhedābhedābhyāmavācyatvaṃ siddham /
analyzed: evam anena pramāṇena santāna antarasya sva citta apekṣayā bhede pratikṣipte abhede ca svayam eva asaṃbhavini bheda abhedābhyām avācya tvam siddham
translated: Thus, by this means of valid knowledge, when the difference of another continuum in relation to one's own mind is refuted, and non-difference is itself impossible, inexpressibility by difference and non-difference is established.

analyzed: sāmānya ādi vat vastu tā apahatiḥ iti katham
translated: Like a universal and so on, there is no loss of reality. How?
The doubt regarding another continuum is stated due to the absence of a reason for refutation.

analyzed: etat ca śāstrīya prameya smāraṇa mātra phalam kiñcid likhitam iti
translated: And this is written only to remind us of the doctrine of the scriptures.

analyzed: param iha svayam anusandheyam
translated: The rest should be understood by oneself here.

original: api ca santānāntare tāvadarvāgdṛśāṃ sandeho bhavadbhiranumanyate /
analyzed: api ca santāna antare tāvat arvāk dṛśām sandehaḥ bhavadbhiḥ anumanyate
translated: Moreover, the doubt of those who see only a limited range of things is admitted by you in the case of another continuum.

analyzed: bhagavataḥ tu kim avasthāpyatām
translated: But what is to be said of the Blessed One?

analyzed: saṃdeha avasthāpane katham sarvajña tā
translated: If he is left in a state of doubt, how can he be omniscient?

original: vidyamānameva kadācit santānāntaraṃ bhagavatā nāvadhāryate tathāpyasau sarvajña iti kathametat /
analyzed: vidyamānam eva kadācid santāna antaram bhagavatā na avadhāryate tathā api asau sarvajñaḥ iti katham etat
translated: Sometimes the Blessed One does not ascertain the existing other continuum. Even so, how can he be omniscient?

analyzed: anumānam ca santāna antara viṣayam prāk eva cintitam
translated: And the inference regarding the other continuum has already been considered earlier.

analyzed: na ca anumānena pratītau api sarvajña tā bhavitum arhati
translated: And even when it is cognized by inference, it cannot be omniscience.

original: pratyakṣeṇa paracittapratītau grāhyagrāhakabhāvo 'pi paracittasya bhagavaccittena sahāyāta iti bahirarthavāda eva mukhāntareṇopagataḥ syāt /
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa para citta pratītau grāhya grāhaka bhāvaḥ pi para cittasya bhagavat cittena saha āyātaḥ iti bahis artha vādaḥ eva mukha antareṇa upagataḥ syāt
translated: When the other mind is cognized by perception, the relation of the object and subject between the other mind and the mind of the Blessed One is also established. Thus, the theory of external objects would be accepted again through a different door.

original: kathamayaṃ vañcayati vādaḥ //🔽asmadīyamatena tu paracittaṃ nāstyeveti tadavadhāraṇakṛtona
analyzed: katham ayam vañcayati vādaḥ  asmadīya matena tu para cittam na asti eva iti
translated: How does this theory deceive?

analyzed: bhagavataḥ sarvajña tā kṣati doṣaḥ
translated: But according to our view, the other mind does not exist at all. Therefore, the fault of damaging the omniscience of the Blessed One is not created by the ascertainment of that.

original: yāvacca bhedagrahaṇābhimānarūpā saṃvṛsttitāvat santānāntare sandehāttadavabodhanārthaṃ vacanādirapi pravartata iti svavacanavirodho 'pi na
analyzed: yāvat ca bheda grahaṇa abhimāna rūpā saṃvṛt tti tā vat santāna antare sandehāt tad avabodhana artham vacana ādiḥ api pravartate iti sva vacana virodhaḥ na
translated: And as long as there is the appearance of the apprehension of difference, so long there is doubt regarding another continuum, and speech etc. also function for the purpose of understanding that, so there is also contradiction with one's own words.

original: na khalu santānāntaraviṣayaḥ sarvathā sandeho nāstyevetyabhimatamasmākam /
analyzed: na khalu santāna antara viṣayaḥ sarvathā sandehaḥ na asti eva iti abhimatam asmākam
translated: It is not the case that we consider that doubt regarding another continuum does not exist at all.

analyzed: api tu paramārtha gatiḥ iyam upadarśitā
translated: But this is shown to be the way of ultimate reality.

original: idaṃ hi santānāntarābhāvasādhanamadvayasādhanena sādhāraṇamiti naikaniyataḥ svavacanādivirodhastatparihāro vā /
analyzed: idam hi santāna antara abhāva sādhanam advaya sādhanena sādhāraṇam iti na eka niyataḥ sva vacana ādi virodhaḥ tad parihāraḥ vā
translated: For this proof of the absence of another continuum is common to the proof of non-duality, so the contradiction with one's own words etc. is not restricted to one, nor is the avoidance of that.

original: citrākārasaṃbhavamātreṇāpi ca vedāntadhvāntāpasāro bhāṣyakāreṇa darśitaḥ / tathā ca
analyzed: citra ākāra saṃbhava mātreṇa api ca vedānta dhvānta apasāraḥ bhāṣyakāreṇa darśitaḥ tathā ca
translated: And the author of the commentary has shown the removal of the darkness of the Vedanta merely by the possibility of various forms. Thus:

original: ātmā sa tasyānubhavaḥ sa ca nānyasya kasyacit
analyzed: ātmā sa tasya anubhavaḥ sa ca nā anyasya kasyacid
translated: That is the self, that is its experience, and that does not belong to anyone else.

analyzed: ityādi vārtika vyākhyāna bhāṣyam
translated: This is the commentary on the aphorism.

analyzed: ātmavādaḥ tarhi prasaktaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the doctrine of the self is then implied,

original: na citrākārasaṃvedanāt ityādi dveṣavikaluṣāśeṣā eva tuṣākāro 'pi vedāntasiddhānta iti alakṣita tadgranthānutthāpayantī santānāntarāpekṣayā
analyzed: na citra ākāra saṃvedanāt ityādi dveṣa vikaluṣa aśeṣāḥ eva vedānta siddhāntaḥ iti santāna antara apekṣayā
translated: it is not so, because of the awareness of various forms. But those who are defiled by hatred have the Vedanta conclusion as a husk. Not understanding that, they do not raise the texts.

analyzed: sarvā saṃvṛti satya antar pātinī hi eva apaitī  ti sakalam an ākulam iti
translated: All [the other means of valid knowledge] are included within conventional truth, and are excluded [from being valid cognition of ultimate truth].🔽Thus, everything is without confusion.

analyzed: santāna antara dūṣaṇam samāptam
translated: The refutation of other continuums is complete.
